Some scenes did remind me of '2001: A Space Odyssey'. The arrival of the spaceship and the way George Clooney looks in his helmet. In a way it is the same kind of science fiction movie, both without the usual sci-fi action, both inviting the audience talk about it after it is seen.Soderbergh and Clooney take a risk with this movie and I like it. It is no block-buster like 'Ocean's Eleven' or a intelligent movie but still made for large audiences like 'Out of Sight'. For some reason Soderbergh can handle a lot of different things and Clooney as an actor can as well. Fortunately there are still people who like to take the risk to make this kind of movie.Like I said Clooney stars as Chris Kelvin. He must visit the planet Solaris because strange things are happening. When he gets there he meets two survivors both a little strange. The first is Gordon (Viola Davis) who doesn't want a discussion with him until "it happens to him". The other is Snow (Jeremy Davies), who seems to be nervous whole the time. After Kelvin's first night his wife wakes up next to him. She committed suicide a few years earlier. In nice flashbacks we see how they met and hooked up on earth, where it is raining in every scene. His wife, played by Natasche McElhone, knows there is something wrong. She remembers things but she doesn't remember experiencing those things. She is not an imagination by Kelvin. Snow and Gordon see her and both had their own visitors. From this moment the story gets interesting every minute.I can understand many people will not like this movie. It doesn't come with a real solution, it moves slowly, there is not much talking, most things are not sure. But it also looks amazing, is very fascinating and you can talk about it for hours. If you liked the last sentence you will like this movie.

It was said that Jim Cameron was the original director on this project, but chose to remain a producer. I think that Solaris would have been competent in Cameron's hands. Instead that task goes to director Steven Soderberg, whose attempts to craft an emotionally complex story just turn sloppy and dull, with torpid performances from a descent cast, and no life.The story is essentially about an astronaut sent out to explore an abandoned ship orbiting a celestial body known as Solaris which has mystical powers, once on board, he sees hallucinations of his long dead wife, and his past slowly comes back to haunt him.Solaris does succeed in looking mystical and sometimes dreamy, but many of the sets feel just as hollow and empty as the story. Nonlinear, unengaging, and totally unclear, in the end Solaris amounts to nothing but a reminder of how brilliant '2001' is.

Review title: Yawnaris AKA Steven Soderbergh shouldn't be allowed behind a camera.
Review_body: Solaris Someone warned me not to watch this movie. Steven Soderbergh shouldn't be allowed behind a camera. The man just can not direct anything with a budget of over 10 million dollars. Anyway, the biggest problem with this movie is that it is needlessly boring. The acting is wasted thanks to quick camera work sprinkled with bad angles, over exposed close ups and basically everything a fresh out of film school director would do when he is trying too hard to be artistic for the sake of being artistic. The actual story that this movie is based on is a solid enough novel with an actual plot but we only get to see it during the first 5 minutes and the final 7 minutes of the film. The rest of the film is just filler. Avoid this film. It is pointless and you'll get nothing out of it.

Review title: After 30 years, Hollywood has yet to learn from Tarkovsky
Review_body: I congratulate producer James Cameron and Steven Soderberg for deciding to film Stanislaw Lem's book. I congratulate Soderberg for being more intelligent than George Lucas and company who reduced Hollywood science fiction in space to literally loud films for the aural senses and special effects feasts for the visual senses. And yet...what a disaster Soderberg's Solaris turned out to be!!If you liked this film see Andrei Tarkovsky's film made 30 years ago when most moviegoers around the world thought Russians only made third rate propaganda war movies.Tarkovsky's film gripped you in so many ways that Soderberg cannot. Tarkovsky's choice of Bach's music "Chorale in F minor", his casting of the brilliant Estonian actor Yuri Jarvet (Grigori Kozintsev's choice of King Lear that had Lord Laurence Olivier doffing his cap) as Dr Snauth a character Soderberg tried to recreate ineffectively in Snow (Jeremy Davis), Tarkovsky's brilliant visuals (Soderberg does copy the rain on the windows)--give you sufficient reasons to realize that Andrei Tarkovsky remains one of the finest filmmakers of the century--a filmmaker who most moviegoers do not adequately know about in the US and elsewhere.What amused me is that before the film was released there were the publicity about how Soderberg wanted to make the film as one superior to Tarkovsky. Soderberg is no Tarkovsky and will never be.Tarkovsky did not use nudity to make his film sell--his film has made waves even when the Communists were afraid of Tarkovsky's messages and suppressed his work in the Seventies in many ways--all because of the care he took with the direction, the script, the editing, the photography and the music. His script, so different from that of the Soderberg film, delivered more punch without a Clooney and his fabulous voice. Hollywood's answer to Tarkovsky is probably the late Orson Welles and in recent times, Terrence Mallick. Cameron probably knew his limitations as a director and cleverly opted to produce the movie. Soderberg thought he was bigger than he is and attempted to remake Tarkovsky's work without even acknowledging the work of the Russian genius in the few press statements I came across.If the Soderberg film appeals to you, it is Stanislaw Lem that gets you not Soderberg. While the film is better than the average Hollywood product this film does not stand up to great cinema elsewhere in any department save for the above-average sound editing.

Upon arrival at the space station orbiting an ocean world called Solaris a psychologist discovers that the commander of an expedition to the planet has died mysteriously. Other strange events soon start happening as well, such as the appearance of old acquaintances of the crew, including some who are dead.I did not expect for this to be a supernatural-like film. From the looks of it, it looked like Apollo 13, Armageddon, or The Core. Well, when I found out it was something different (by seeing the trailer), I was quite excited, even though I knew James Cameron and Steven Soderbergh were already in on the film. Then comes the huge disappointment.It was BORING. It was UNINTERESTING. It didn't catch any of my attention and the 92 minutes of the film's running time passed by surprisingly quickly. On a positive note, this is unlike any film you've ever seen. It was quite original for being a film that takes place in the future and it pays less attention to the future world than on the story, which I couldn't tell was good or bad.The look of the film is fantastic. Some CGI shots were subtle. The whole love story (which is used for the plot) was bad, in my opinion. I did not feel, whatsoever, that George Clooney and Natascha McElhone had any chemistry together, although their performances were great.Well, there are different perspectives on the film from different people. My perspective on it was boring and uninteresting but others might actually pay attention to the movie and love every bit of it. What also made this film boring is that the film's pace was SLOW. Still, I liked the ending.There are some good moments in the film but mainly many boring and dull moments which did not catch my attention. The performances and cinematography were good and subtle. If you like a small and quiet film, this might be the film for you. For the others, you might get bored.

Directed by Steven Soderbergh, Produced by James Cameron, and with these words written on the DVD Cover 'One of the Great Science Fiction Films of all Time', i didn't hesitate, i just bought it.Now this review is intended to save you money, so here we go>>>>>>>>I found Solaris incredibly slow from start to finish, and it had no tension to speak of, every scene was unnecessarily drawn out and the outcome was boring, yes there is some depth to the story, and i freely confess that i haven't analysed this depth, it's just too dull to bother with.You could argue, that 2001 and Bladerunner are both slow as well, but they have Character, Style and Brilliance that simply are not present in Solaris, so here is the bottom line.Don't spend money on this movie, until you are sure. Perhaps i'm missing something, i don't know, but i never plan to find out.Remember, be sure before you spend.3/10

Review title: A cafe house/minimalist version of Stanislaw Lem's story
Review_body: SOLARIS, directed by Steven Soderbergh, and starring George Clooney, is one of those pointless remakes Hollywood has been making these past decades that adds almost nothing to the original classic. The movie itself is good. Not great or even close to being bad or a misfire, just good.  Soderbergh basically boiled down the complex and epic story, as seen in the Russian film, into a simple MINIMALISTIC love story. Which made me wonder why did they even bother remaking the movie if all the science-fiction and metaphysical elements were thrown out? The story could have easily taken place entirely on earth. And instead of Solaris, the story could have been set in a mystical setting, like a haunted castle or an ancient archeological find. If you're going to set in space, might as well give the outer space aspect some sort of meaning to it. The minimalistic approach is interesting but the result is pointless. Having Rheya come back from the dead, sort of speaking, and her problems adjusting to her new reality reminded me a lot of the replicants' plight in BLADE RUNNER, which is what I think Soderbergh tried to do here. Who's reality is it?My only criticism about the movie is the use of dreams and flashbacks. In the film, the Solaris planet takes a person's main dream while they're sleeping (there's even silly close-up shots of Clooney's cranium). These dreams are seen as "flashback" in the movie. Dreams are rarely that linear. One doesn't dream about one specific thing or person (in this case Kelvin dreaming about Rheya) all the time. And dreams are impressions of reality. So when Rheya comes back, looking exactly like Kelvin's wife, for me this points out to an obvious weakness in the whole concept of the Solaris planet going into a person's mind and grabbing their version of reality. If this was the case, the reincarnated Rheya should have looked slightly different that the Rheya on earth. Oddly enough, the way Soderbergh approached the idea of a planet reincarnating a long lost loved one into flesh reminded me of the SPACE 1999 episode, A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH, more than the Tarkovsky movie. But I find that the SPACE 1999 episode, even with all its faults, was more epic and poignant than Soderbergh's version of the Stanislaw Lem's story. There's just something anal retentive about Soderbergh's direction which prevents any kind of emotions to seep to the surface.Unlike most people though, I wasn't bored at all with SOLARIS. In fact, movies like ARMAGEDDON, THE LOST WORLD: JURASSIC PARK 2 or THE CORE were a thousand times more boring than this  flick. It's just that the film's outcome is so predictable and that the script and filmmaker did nothing to alleviate this predictability that the pointlessness of the whole project comes to the fore. Good beginning. Predictable and flat ending.And then there's another odd point about Soderbergh's SOLARIS: where did the money go? The film reportedly cost $80 to $100 million to make. The cast is tiny (four or five actors). There are very few special effects and the sets look like your standard spaceship sets you see on a TV show like STAR TREK VOYAGER. Why spend that huge amount of money on a simple, predictable love story? The film should have cost $30 to $40 million, not $100.I love the Russian film a lot. But I can't say that Soderbergh create a disaster here or disservice to the Russian version or the book. It is a typically Soderbergh flick, which, on this aspect alone, sets it apart from the Russian movie. And like I've said, the film by itself is good. But in the end, it looks more like an episode of SPACE 1999 or THE TWILIGHT ZONE than a real movie.

I read some terrible reviews for this film, and the fact that I don't think much of George Clooney as an actor, my hopes were very low. Yes, if you want princesses aliens and comic book heroes give this a miss, if however you're wanting an intelligent film looking at human emotions and the afterlife you might enjoy this movie. PS. Still don't rate Clooney as an actor though.

(spoilers)The music is awesome.  Very calming.  But thats about all it's good for.The movie is so wacky, you don't really know whats going on.  Everytime you think you understand something, they blow it away.  I'm not sure what the original is like , but it's probably better than this blob.  I myself probably won't watch it again.  Sure the movie makes you think,  but 9 years from now I'll probably still be thinking.  Score I might buy, but I'd tell others try to stay away.  Not because the acting sucks (it doesn't..  in fact the acting is better than Monster)  But the story/plot is so darn short and the movie flies by so quickly, You are left wondering if you got ripped off or not.4/10Quality: 2/10 Entertainment: 4/10 Replayable: 1/10

Review title: Powerful, thought-provoking metaphysical journey - A great remake.
Review_body: My two favorite examples of Hollywood utterly destroying GREAT foreign films are Vanilla Sky and City of Angels, which were abominations of two of my favorite films - Open Your Eyes and Wings of Desire. If you've seen Tarkovsky's brilliant "Solyaris" this film will seem more like an Americanized tribute than a Hollywoodization of a great piece of Soviet cinema. Some will likely ask why Soderbergh bothered to make this film if he couldn't improve on the original. Personally, I could not care less. This is a great film, and shows that it is possible for Americans to remake classic non-American films sensitively, intelligently and well.To cut to the chase - if you like sci-fi with a soul,which stretches the boundaries of imagination, explores the uncharted realms of the human condition as much as the unknown realities of the universe, and swims upstream against the currents of ethics, physics, and even metaphysics, you will probably enjoy this moody, slow, multi-leveled and heavily textured film. If you're looking for light entertainment, stay away from this. This is a slow, intense film - dominated by dialog - and there is no action to speak of. Also, you need to let this movie pour into you slowly, so if you're not in the right frame of mind to pay attention and be receptive, you should save it for another occasion.The cast is exceptionally good. This is unequivocally the best performance I have seen out of George Clooney, but the supporting cast and the female lead all blew me away. Soderbergh does have a talent for making actor's look good, even mediocre actors, but there is nothing mediocre about any of the performances in this film.Though I recognize his talent, Soderberg's dialogical technique has worn particularly thin with me. The once fresh fast-paced, rapid-fire cuts and close-ups with the low-toned exchange of sentence fragments, and the myriad Soderberg imitators, particularly in television crime drama, have really gotten on my nerves. Solaris, however, is a bit different. There are only a few "Soderbergh moments" in this rich remake of the classic bit of 1970s soviet SciFi "Solyaris". Both films are based on a novella by the brilliant Stanislaw Lem. This film, perhaps even more than Tarkovsky's 1972 edgy, dark, and intense original, will appeal to exactly the sort of movie-goer that Lem's writing appeals to. Neither film captures Lem's quirky sense of humor. I am quite glad that Soderbergh chose to make Solaris with very much the same atmospheric eeriness, plot, and intellectual and emotional depth as the original. It is a tribute to his artistic integrity that he recognizes the brilliance of the original work, and imitates it wherever he can do no better, adding subtle and appropriate nuances and embellishments to make it his own. Some examples are the wonderfully minimalistic soundtrack, and the very Soderbergh symbolic use of lighting and color saturation to shift from the retrospective to the live-action shot. Perhaps the best tribute I can give this film is the fact that I am going to watch the original again in a few days for comparative purposes.In other words, this isn't going to be for everybody, nor, even, for most. I am hardly surprised by the very low (in my opinion) ratings received by this film here on IMDb. Solaris is a love story, a story of exploring the fringes of sanity, and of questioning the very nature of reality, and much more. Enjoy it!

Solaris is the story of a psychologist who encounters what appears to be his dead wife on a space station near an alien planet. The story was brought to life by Soviet director Andrei Tarkovsky in 1972. I saw Tarkovsky's version for the first time recently, and it blew me away. I actually prefer it to its Western counterpart, 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968). So I was curious about how a remake of Tarkovsky's film would hold up.Steven Soderbergh's 2002 version of Solaris doesn't have a lot wrong with it, but throughout I kept asking why the remake was necessary. The original is good enough, why do we need a new one? A desire for a shorter film? A preference not to read subtitles? An old inclination to boycott communism? Such reasons sound lazy or silly to me. At its core we have an intriguing and resonant story of a protagonist who is forming a sick emotional attachment to an illusion, but it's nothing we haven't seen before. All Soderbergh really adds are some extra scenes with the psychologist and his wife on Earth, with glimpses of George Clooney's butt. On a side note, the planet Solaris itself looks dull to me in this version, turned an unimaginative blue and purple. I'm not automatically against any remake. I actually enjoyed King Kong (2005), but that film sufficiently re-imagined the story (better love story, scarier natives, etc.) to be worthwhile. Again, Solaris (2002) doesn't have a lot of problems, but is mainly redundant.

Review title: An interesting statement about the inability to let go
Review_body: As a science fiction film, Solaris follows the same rule as the best of the genre, namely that it isn't the creatures or technology that makes the viewers want to watch, it is the human drama. Which is just as well, because the film itself is slower than the proverbial wet week, in spite of being less than a hundred minutes in length. Nonetheless, I will be very interested to see future projects from Steven Soderbergh.The plot revolves around a psychologist who is suffering deep emotional problems, which mainly seem to revolve around the suicide of his wife. So when he is floating aimlessly around a spaceship that orbits the titular planet, apparitions of his wife begin appearing. From what I am able to discern, an alien intelligence is trying to take over the ship's crew, in the hope that the ship will return to Earth and take them with it. Of course, the crew have other ideas.In essence, it sounds a lot like the basic plot for Alien, minus the violence. Alien has a degree of violence, most of which is implied, and so too does Solaris. The difference here is that the violence is not essential to the plot. In fact, aside from a couple of corpses, you never really get to see any. Instead, we are given a good deal of exposition regarding the doctor's feelings regarding his wife and what he would do to have her back in any shape or form. When the Solaris alien appears in his cabin, it tells him everything he wants to hear, and appears exactly as he desires.The big question posed by the film is whether we are the sum of how we, and more importantly other people, remember us, or whether there's more that defines our reality. Having struggled with other people's wrong impressions of me for most of my life, I have often pondered this question myself. When the apparition-clone of Rheya is suddenly deciding that it would be best for her and Chris if she no longer existed in this form, she asks simply if she has simply been slapped together from Chris' memories or desires. Nobody ever knows all there is to know about another person, and that's what makes the surrealism of the story so compelling.I gave Solaris a seven out of ten. It was slow, and it could have been at least ten minutes longer, but it works as a nice little piece of thinking entertainment. Give it a once over, and you might be pleasantly surprised.

The story had to be remade. Nice questioning about life and reality. Is there another life form and what would we do with it? Good little film. The end is similar to the russian film of the same name and origin, but more virtual. Are we now in heaven in heaven?

I like good sci-fi films, but that was just crap.
So boring that I would give 0/10 if I could.

One of the characters in this hopelessly bad sci-fi stinker says "I don't understand what's going on."  She's certainly not alone. It was the only thing in this muddled monotinous mish mash that I DID understand. The film is deliberately vague about time and place. There is some kind of a problem on some kind of a space vehicle in some part of the universe and some kind of a doctor is sent to see if he can find some kind of a solution. It has all the pretensions, some of the visual gimmicks and none of the significance of 2001, A Space Odyssey. Maybe they could have called this 2002, A Space Odd-see. (Well, that  bad pun is actually better than anything you'll see in the picture.) Actually it does make a small breakthrough in the wretched  litany of science fiction movies --- there never has been a good one! --- with an interstellar heavy breathing scene. A thoroughly AWFUL movie!

Solaris is a film that probably would only be appreciated by hardcore George Clooney fans. If there are such fans, that is. Hey, at least you get to see his butt twice. The butt shots, however, may be some of the more interesting details of this film. The film touches on some interesting ideas and will definitely pull at your heart strings a little. Unfortunately, the sum total elements of the film are only slightly engaging.As far as the plot goes, imagine the film Event Horizon. Now take out the gore and suspense. Turn up the emotional issues for the ladies out there, and you pretty much have Solaris. Clooney plays some sort of a psychiatrist who is called out to a space station to examine some of the odd goings on experienced by the crew already there. It seems that the nearby moon "Solaris" is playing mind games with the people sent to observe it. Basically, the moon can create clones of loved ones for each person that comes to close to it. Clooney, after his first night in the space station wakes up with a clone of his dead wife, for example. Another crew member is visited by a clone of his son. Another by a clone of himself, and so on. Clooney is still very much in love with his wife who committed suicide back on Earth, and now finds himself unable to say goodbye to a woman he knows is not really nor should be there with him.Rather than focus in depth on any possible scientific explanation, the film takes the emotional road more than anything else. We feel Clooney's pain, and that of the other crew members. That leads to a depressing experience watching this film. The film cheats in terms of its futuristic settings by having the majority of its shots be internals. The few externals we get are impressive (Jim Cameron was on board as a producer), but there should have been more of them. Also, too much time is spent with flashbacks to Earth where only people's clothing shows any sense of a futuristic setting. And once again, there are too many internal shots and the sense of wonder that should be found in a science fiction film is all but lost.This is one of those "high concept" sci-fi films, so we are left with some big time ambiguity toward the end. It worked for Stanley Kubrick, but not so well in this case. At only 99 minutes, the film seems half an hour longer. The character played by Jeremy Davies was most certainly meant to be weird, but he comes off more annoying than anything else. The scenes with him are like running over a big speed bump you weren't able to avoid.The film lost a small fortune at the box office, and I find that unfortunate. Not that Solaris is a good film, but it proves once again that films which don't pander to those with tiny brains often fail to make any money.The film had potential, but will ultimately go down as a failure. Too bad. 5 of 10 stars.The Hound.

What a mess... loosing big at the box office.. and rightfully so. Solaris is totally boring, and a complete drag from start to finish. The dialogue for most of the entire movie seems as if it is playing at slow speed. It really could not get much worse without a huge effort. With all the tens of millions this disaster cost to produce, and two-thirds that same amount taken in at the box office worldwide... sooo much more could have been done with those fortunes. Big name, big budget films are no less susceptible to failure than the lowest cost movies.. but the real advantage of the latter is that huge amounts are not squandered in the process.

This film drags on and on and on, and is pretty much a bore throughout.Some kind of attempt to do a modern day 2001, George Clooney is the psychologist who gets to travel to the Solaris spaceship when things go very awry.Just not particularly interesting, you do have to wonder why Clooney took the role as he has shown pretty good judgment in his cinematic career so far.A dud.

Review title: Take the A Train to Solaris: No Thanks!
Review_body: MANDATORY CONFLICT OF INTEREST DISCLOSURE:  I have been to Solaris by teleportation four times and am currently investing in real estate on that planet as part of a secret consortium headed by Donald T***p.*****The original Russian science fiction film wasn't that good - a muddled attempt reflecting the intelligence of a director and the chronic failings of Soviet film making.  This one isn't much better.Set in the future, psychologist George Clooney has some terrific post-Post-Modern Martha Stewart appliances and furnishings in his apartment (note that in the end the zucchini still winds up sliced the old-fashioned way).  Today's therapists and neurotics will be relieved to see that his group sessions attract the same type of losers always to be found in that setting.  And the government hasn't changed either.  In a crisis, two grim visaged men in black come knocking to inform the busy doctor that he must return to service instantly - no one else will do.Clooney is shot into space to investigate a strange call for help from the commander of a research station orbiting Solaris, a distant planet.  Upon arrival he finds the station honcho dead by his own hand and two remaining crew members in need of some kind of rapid intervention therapy.  Weird stuff is happening on the Good Ship Solaris.Sleeping alone hasn't been fun for Clooney since his wife's untimely death so imagine his surprise when the beautiful spouse appears next to him as he awakens.  Natascha McElhone IS beautiful but her appearance makes sense only to those who, after the movie, doggedly invest it with myriad layers of spiritual and humanistic interpretations.Clooney struggles to make sense of his wife's appearance and other strange events on board.  Symbolically, his slightly elevated and well defined naked posterior indicates that director Steven Soderbergh is suggesting that someone is an ass.  Is it the viewer? :)The special effects aren't any big deal and the film moves in fits and starts before ending in a way that allows anyone to proclaim its specialness by finding meaning hidden in the fog of celluloid debris.3/10.  And I'm generous, the holidays drawing near, bringing me into a spirit of giving.

A remake of a little-known (that, of course, is now on DVD) Russian film, Steven Soderbergh's Solaris is a hauntingly beautiful sci-fi masterpiece that borrows from other films, such as 2001.George Clooney is Chris Kelvin, psychiatrist. In the futuristic world of his that doesn't get too over-the-top (such as Minority Report), he must go and try to solve bizarre occurings that are happening on a space station that is around the planet Solaris. He goes up, and, of course, sees a vision of his dead wife Rheya (Natascha McElhone). Soon he becomes transfixed and believes that she is the real deal, while other members Snow (Jeremy Davies) and Gordon (Viola Davis) try to convince him that it's a "visitor" from Solaris. Oddity ensues.This movie is unlike any others I have ever seen. Unlike the mindless blockbusters in the summer or the drek of the fall/spring, this movie is an original piece of work that really makes you think. Don't put your mind on hold. As soon as the art begins, you're transfixed with the escapades of Chris and co. Going into it, I was feeling somewhat apprehensive, because of the mixed review it has been garnering. All of the nay-sayers must not be able to think deeply and consider The Animal the greatest movie of all time.Clooney gives a compassionate performance, while McElhone is also incredable. The supporting characters were great and we can hope that their names go out in the future. The sweeping cinematography was so magnificent-the turns and the flashes and everything else. Its 99-minute runtime seemed long, but I wished it could have been longer.The music score proved that you don't need large booms to make effective. In fact, the point is made with silence a lot of times. The ending was perfect. It isn't cut-and-dry, but also it isn't so muddled and mucked up. It's open to debate, like all good movies should be. You can't really argue about Eight Crazy Nights. Like most classics, the ending is left to the imagination (2001 comes into mind again).Solaris is a spectacular achievement of mind and body with superb acting and an awesome script that leaves much to the imagination. Unfortunately, most audience will not like it because it isn't clear and they don't want to think.My rating: 10/10Rated PG-13 for sexuality/nudity, brief language and thematic elements.

I'm not very much a fan of George Clooney, and therefore never find him a "very good actor" like every body claim him to be. But in this movie I found the different side, I found that he is not as bad as I expected him to be. I like Solaris, especially with it brilliant concepts and idea combine with good acting and directing(weird editing - as least to me). But with no doubt the movie is damn slow and would for sure make you leave your seat after five minutes into the movie. Don't!! . There are more to offer at the last part of the movie. Even with the slow pace of the film I'm sure some of the hard-core fan of Drama/ Sci-fi would love the film and for as the person who's not very much into real drama this is going to be hell.Rating: 7/10 (mostly for the story)

Review title: Jon Monsarrat review: moving, powerful, but poor ending
Review_body: Solaris is a powerful film about the nature of what it means to be human. The acting is good, but the cinematography is especially amazing. The camera jitters a little while filming, and the sets are not brightly lit and clear, which works well to give a visceral sensation of "being there". So it was a moving experience for me, and I'm glad I saw the film.Unfortunately, there were some flaws. Compressing such a large story into a regular length film glossed over some details (how far away is Solaris from Earth?), and the pacing was somewhat slow at times. Like Memento, this is a brainy movie that you have to be paying attention to "get it" throughout the film. I actually prefer that.Solaris is not really a science fiction film. It's really a ghost story mystery like The Sixth Sense, although science elements are present in the background. I was really set to love this film, and was definitely captivated throughout, but without spoiling any of the plot I can tell you that the ending left me very unsatisfied. This makes it unlike The Sixth Sense which came with a snappy, clever ending that wrapped up all the mystery but retained the power of the film. This is the main reason I gave the film a low-ish rating even though I did find it moving and well-produced. It was the story that disappointed me.Who should see this film:-- arty types, definitely-- science fiction fans, well, I can't stop you. It won't hurt too much. Save it for a rainy day. But not if you hated 2001: A Space Odyssey, which was much more substantive than Solaris.-- anyone from an Eastern European culture who wants to see some famous literature on the big screenI'll give Solaris a 6 out of 10. Oh, and don't rent the old film Solyaris, which is vastly slow paced and only for the most arty.

The first time I watched this I found it a snooze fest - but 18 years on, I quite liked it second time around. It is slow moving, so you have to be in a mood for a slow film. It's filmed nice though. 6/10 does me.

SOLARISI had never seen this before, but I always found the front cover interesting. It always jumped out at me so I decided to get it on DVD.The movie is about a psychiatrist who gets a strange video message from his friend asking him to go up to a space station called Solaris to investigate some strange happenings.I did like this movie, but it was very slow. This movie went at a very steady pace all the way through. There was no action, there was no heart racing moments. This is a space drama. There are lots of dialogue and lots of flashbacks from when he was still on Earth. You will need to really concentrate on this film to fully understand it.The movie stars George Clooney, Natascha McElhone, Viola Davis & Jeremy Davies. The acting was very good throughout. Everyone did a great job. The emotions that these guys are feeling was very well played out. I can imagine that if I was going through what they are going through it would be very emotional and confusing and that is what I was getting from every one of these actors.This is not the best sci-fi film I have ever seen. Personally I prefer a film to have a little bit of action, or at least a bit of suspense to keep me gripped. I did not get bored watching this, but as I said before, because it is a very slow moving movie, it is easy to get distracted. It is like watching someone reading you a story. It is a very good story, but it felt like it was missing something.Visually it was very beautiful in places. I love space movies anyway. I always think the stars and space looks beautiful, so when it is made well in film I find it very fascinating and awesome. The planet that Solaris was near looked very pretty. The colours and effects used to make it were brilliant. I could sit and watch that for ages.All in all this film was not brilliant it is a good story, but very slow. Make sure if you watch this it is completely silent and you can concentrate on it 100% otherwise you might miss part of the plot and not understand a thing that is going on.I will give this movie 6 out of 10."Or maybe you're my puppet. But like all puppets you think you're actually human. It's the puppets dream, being human."For more reviews, please like my Facebook page:https://www.facebook.com/pages/Ordinary-Person-Movie- Reviews/456572047728204?ref=hl

Having just watched the trailer for Steven Soderbergh's remake of Andrei Tarkovsky's Russian sci-fi classic, it seems to be some kind of action-horror hybrid. In fact, it's a solemn psychodrama about a psychologist named Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) who travels to a research station orbiting a planet called Solaris, where his late wife is brought back to physical life by an unseen alien intelligence.Tarkovsky's creeping meditation is more conversational and a (very) good hour longer than Steven Soderbergh's terse remake. Perhaps if Soderbergh and (producer) James Cameron had known it wouldn't break profit, they'd have gone easier in the editing room. Or perhaps they wouldn't have made it at all, which I suppose might have saved us from Ocean's Twelve.Tarkovsky's vision is my favourite of that director's films, and is also, arguably, the most accessible. It contains a more straightforward narrative than The Mirror, a slightly quicker (though not quick) pace than Stalker, and it's less dense and stagey than The Sacrifice. I feel it's the most successful blend of story and character in Tarkovsky's canon; the best balanced both emotionally and philosophically.Soderbergh's version, while seriously truncated, is an intelligent and often elegant work. Gone are the former filmmaker's Oedipal motifs, the existential monologues, and the weightless ballet. This is a taut film about the romanticising, catastrophising power of memory.Soderbergh dispenses with the now infamous 10-minute car journey sequence taken by Henri Burton (Vladislav Dvorzhetsky). Is Burton's car journey a reference to Bowman's "Stargate" experience in Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey? Later, aboard the space station, Snaut (Jüri Järvet) makes a speech questioning whether man should be exploring new worlds before he has learned to truly communicate with his fellow man. Burton's terrestrial "journey", after his experience with Solaris, is every bit as profound as Bowman's.Natascha McElhone, while not the match of Natalya Bondarchuk, who acted everyone off Tarkovsky's screen, delivers an eerie, uncanny performance as the almost-human Rheya, "remembered wrong". Clooney's Kelvin is a more glaring, shell-shocked presence than Donatas Banionis - whether you prefer the former's range to the latter's subtlety is up to you; each belongs to their own film.Soderbergh regular Cliff Martinez provides the bubbling, electro-orchestral score, lending the images a delicate sense of the lost, the wistful, and sometimes the dread. Where Tarkovsky's script was as cold and sprawling as space itself, Soderbergh's is warm and focused. And as for the ending - well, let's just say that the young buck doesn't try and take on the elder directly, choosing instead something softer, less awesome, yet still ambiguous and fascinating. Which fairly sums up the film, I think.

Review title: George Clooney's naked buttocks, and little more.
Review_body: Empty, bland, undeveloped, and not well thought-out.  If it wasn't for two descent acting performances, of which Clooney is not one, and a few interesting sounds, I'd give it the lowest possible rating.It's like watching 50s space sci-fi.  At best, it's silly and naive.  The problem is that it's trying to be dark and serious.There's not much going on in terms of FX or sound, either.  Go see Equilibrium or Star Trek if you're looking for some sci=fi.

This is a pseudo-intellectual look into beliefs in God, Heaven, man and his place in reality. That's the problem with movies like these - they are only a look. There is no clarity, everything revolves around a vague collection of ideas thrown together in a weak attempt to look coherent but in reality is a clue into the film makers' and writers' weak understanding of reality.I loved the production better than the movie. But the ennui conversation full of empty nothing you can't grab hold of was sad and droll. Perfect for people who love to talk (aimlessly) for hours and say nothing.The tag line for this movie says: "There are some places man is not ready to go ..." yeah, THIS MOVIE! 1/10-LD

Solaris is a film that will either enrapture or level you behind. Psychologist Chris Kelvin is pleaded by old friend Gibarian, to fly from earth to space station Prometheus, where something terrible has happened. Prometheus orbits around the beautifully enigmatic planet Solaris. On arrival, Kelvin discovers scattered blood and two bodies, along with the only two survivors; Gordon and Snow. Solaris is a hushed, introspective film on the boundaries of human mental stability, isolation, loss, existence, the power of a high being, and emotional withdraws of letting go. Images and silence speak louder than words; echoing 2001: A Space Oddessy, where piercing stares tell all that is needed. The mystery of Solaris lies upon the enigmatic planet, Soderbergh only supplying little hints and clues leading to what is behind this majestic planet; strengthening the fact this demands repeat views and open thinking. The emotional drama is gripping, as Kelvin is haunted on the apparition of his deceased wife, flashes of Kelvin's memories during his time with Rheya, and the unseen visitors of Gordon and Snow. Much to the vast cold of space, Solaris seeps a coldness from its core, that bars an emotional detachment. A haunting ambiance lacking in spine chilling. Not completing the emotional bridge, a central presence of George Clooney, holds a gravitas to the proceedings. Natascha McElhone doesn't reach Clooney's presence yet haunting as Rheya. Viola Davis and Jeremy Davies as the remaining survivors are great in their supporting roles. Solaris may not be everyones brand of Scince Fiction, on its conclusion, your need to talk about it is quite strong, which is the films overall point.

Review title: Story is lost in slow boring delivery
Review_body: This story is an interesting idea and the acting is quite good. However, all of its good points including any suspense are wiped out by a painfully slow, dull and boring delivery

Steven Soderbergh's Americanized remake of Andrei Tarkovsky's Soviet 1972 science-fiction/philosophical space opera is a bold project, given that the material he's adopting--taken from the novel by Stanislaw Lem but directly inspired by Tarkovsky--is subdued and grim, with plenty of inertia (even though more than an hour of the tedious original is lopped off). Here, Soderbergh departs from the source material and wisely concentrates on the relationships between his characters rather than the philosophical concerns that grounded Tarkovsky's film. But the material remains perhaps too daunting for modern audiences, with George Clooney (rapidly becoming one of our most introspective actors) as a psychiatrist who travels to a space station surrounding a mysterious planet that sends emissaries representing the troubled pasts of the station's inhabitants; in Clooney's case, it's the apparition of his suicide wife (Natascha McElhone) that rekindles his dormant but conflicted emotions. Although it's clearly a personal film for Soderbergh about the ephemeral nature of interaction, it's unfortunately not compelling enough to be little more than another experimental challenge for him (as studied and careful as `Full Frontal' was spontaneous and indulgent), albeit a beautifully shot one (filmed, as usual, by the director under the pseudonym Peter Andrews; he also edited the film as Mary Ann Bernard) with a production design by Philip Messina that pays subtle homage to Tarkovsky's original.

"What if?". This is the question of Solaris. More specifically, "What if we could bring back our lost ones to our side?". That is the question flowing throughout Sodebergh's movie. I've never thought that I would watch a film based on a single rethorical question, but indeed, the nature of this question is what gives it the juice. And, indeed, the juices are flowing on this one. Made by an acclaimed director which is first of all a movie addict, this movie is Steven Soderbergh's gift to every people that shares with him a true passion for cinema. And nobody else. The general audience will hate it - slow paced, slow acted and slow all the way, the movie is almost like a play, tightfully enclosed in its capsule. But these few characters, these few situations are only an apparent face for an overwhelming reality - emotions are the sheer canvas of this picture. The story is so simple it reaches the most minimalistic heights in an american movie since Kubrick went into space - Dr. Chris Kelvin (Clooney) is sent to a space station near gas planet Solaris to investigate the strange occurences on it and to rescue the remainder of the crew. But when he arrives, it's clear that this is no simple bail-out mission and soon he will know that the reasons to return are far more difficult to find than the reasons to stay. The movie ends up being a strikingly lensed space drama, with the freshness of some choices (the fact that the movie has so few characters and only 93 minutes gives it a mood that is based on essence). And its simplicity is its greatest asset. Some would consider a remake of Tarkovski's work pure heresy. But Soderbergh suceeds in paying his respects, and accomplishes what every remake should be - a new insight into a known movie. A true tour de force, and a proof that when there is a will to stay out of the studio system and its sometimes corruptive formulae, there is also a way.

Solaris surely has great cinematographic qualities, a deep existential theme, a nice poetic style of narration, and an interesting ending. I didn't know Soderbergh could make this kind of movie so well.But, Solaris falls in the category of abstract sci-fi stories, which I don't like too much; and it's ultimately a bit boring.Natascha McElhone deserved an Academy Award. On the other hand, I think Clooney didn't fit that character so well.

The direction and acting is well-done in this movie.  Some of the camera work seems to be an homage to Stanley Kubrick's 2001.  Sadly the screenplay fails to engage my interest.The plot is fairly simplistic and reminds me of a plot from the 1960's Star Trek series with a little of "Forbidden Planet" thrown in.  It's a good plot, but the screenplay is extremely slow in it's pace.  In an attempt to be intriguing and enigmatic, it ends up being boring.  I think it was meant to inspire thought on the nature of religion and higher powers, but the story just dabbles and fails to complete the thought.The acting and directing keep this from being a bad movie by a long shot, but wait for it to show on cable.  There's better movies on which to spend the rental dollars.

Solaris is a movie that only works if you allow it to. It is like a drug and to experience it you have to want it. I might be young but then in my young and somewhat naive life I have experienced a bit with love and loss and I know how it feels, and I know what it can drive a person to do. George Clooney puts that on the table and shows us how most of us felt. Solaris is a weird film with a lot of emotions running through , it touches on themes of loss , grievances and not to mention acceptance which is the the most important part of the ordeal. George Clooney and Natasha McElorne do a wonderful job of taking us on a journey , I also believe in an artistic way that it is not made to make any sort of sense but in a way Steven Sodburgh wants us to just delve into our-selves , nothing gained and nothing lost...well for me anyway. The only thing I can truly say about Solaris is that if you have really felt love and lost it , and know the after shock that it leaves then it would be worth a look at. If your expecting a sci-fi Star Wars adventure then leave it. SOLARIS - 8.1 OUT OF 10There are some places that man is not ready to go...

This film, featuring the powerful duo of Clooney & Soderbergh, reimagines the Lem novel completely, and thus this film looks little like the Tarkovsky film.The most powerful element is that nothing is as it seems-due to pull of the dream planet Solaris. Reality takes a back seat to hallucination and wish fulfillment in very real and even weird ways.The poetry as a recitative device is brilliant-death shall have no dominion-and thus this ends up being, along with Tarkovsky, one of my very favorite films.Highly recommended.

For the last couple of years, film audiences have gotten Science- Fiction films mixed with Science-Fantasy.  STAR WARS, LORD OF THE RINGS and MATRIX are Science-Fantasy, where 2001,A.I.: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE, and MINORITY REPORT are Science-Fiction.  Science-Fantasy is more about locations, worlds, legend, and creatures/species.  Science-Fiction is more about taking the emotions and thoughts of the human mind that is explaining the philosophy of human existance.  Where more questions are given than answers provided.  Such as 2001, what did the monolith represent?  A.I., can a machine be intelligent enough to have emotions?  MINORITY REPORT, should the technique of preventing a crime still be used when people can possibly change their mind and not commit the crime?  Steve Soderbergh's lastest masterpiece, SOLARIS, ask the question, can a person love a being that looks, acts, and has the memory of a deceased loved one, but really isn't that person?SOLARIS is based on the Stainslaw Lem novel that was made into a long, but very well done film by Russian director Andrei Tarkovsky.  The story is set in the future, psychartrist Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) who has been suffering for the last couple of months after the sucide death of his wife Rheya (the very beautiful Natascha McElhone).  Chris is asked to go out to the space station that is above the water planet of SOLARIS where all but two of the crewmen have died.  When Chris arrives on SOLARIS, he sees that the two survivors, Snow (Jeremy Davis) and Helen Gordon (Viola Davis), are still having psychological sufferings.  As Chris investigates with what happened at the station, he wakes from sleeping one time to see a person or creature that is exactly the splitting image of the deceased Rheya.  In one of the most heartbreaking scenes in cinema, Chris dismisses this person or thing being his dead wife back from the dead and sends her out into space as he breaks down into tears.  Then a few hours later after Chris goes to sleep again, the appearance of the thing that looks and acts like Rheya appears again.  And should Chris believe that it is Rheya back from the dead?  Or is this a hallucination that is created by Chris' mind?SOLARIS is like Kubrick's 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY, in being a film that is full of philosophic questions.  I feel the reason why nimrods are dismissing and getting angry with SOLARIS is that they believe it will be as fun filled like OCEAN'S ELEVEN, or action packed like ALIENS since Soderbergh and James Cameron worked on the film.  It's not.  If there is any movie where your brain is required to be used before seeing the movie, while seeing the movie, and after seeing the movie, SOLARIS is that film!  If you don't like using your brain while watching a movie, then catch the next showing of DIE ANOTHER DAY or MAID IN MANHATTAN.SOLARIS is a film that proves that Steve Soderbergh IS one talented and versatile director.  Most entertainment shows and film audiences think of Soderbergh as the director of easy to understand films like OCEAN'S 11 and ERIN BROCKOVICH.  But this is the same brillant mind behind complex films like SEX LIES & VIDEOTAPE, THE LIMEY, and TRAFFIC.  While I personally find TRAFFIC to still be Soderbergh's best film, a hair-line fracture behind TRAFFIC is now SOLARIS.  I was so glad and pleased to see that Soderbergh respected the story and sci-fi genre by making SOLARIS into a highly intellectual film where thoughts are required, characters are the key element to a film, and technology and location are used with what they should be used for, background support!Georgy Clooney proves that he IS one of the best and underrated actors working in Hollywood.  Clooney does a fantastic job with his acting of the in-pain and confused Chris Kelvin.  But the scene that really got me emotional was the scene when Chris breaksdown in tears.  Natascha McElhone, I have always seen to be a very beautiful and underrated actress that should be given more leading roles.  In SOLARIS, McElhone manages to have one can't help but to think about their significant other (being male and female) and just wanting to love them even more.  Jeremy Davis does a fantastic job as the some-what disturbed and confused Snow, who might or might not have to answers to the happenings on the station.  And Viola Davis is good as the strong minded and conflicting Gordon.If SOLARIS proves anything, it's that Soderbergh, unlike most Hollywood directors, hasn't sold out to the evils of box office success, and continue to make films the way he wants to make them, and tell the stories the way he wants to tell them.  Why are people walking out of this movie angry and upset?  I believe it is because the film requires a lot of thought.  This same exact thing reminded me of a film that was released last year that I loved but people looking for a brainless film hated, VANILLA SKY.  And for those who hated VANILLA SKY, then stay away from SOLARIS.  But for those who like intelligence and symbolism as a main ingredant for a film, then SOLARIS is the ideal film for you.   Right now, most people will be dismissing SOLARIS as a slow, weird, and pointless film.  But ask me this question, what movie will be more talked about and praised twenty years from now, SOLARIS or XXX?  Only time will tell, but I'll be hoping it's SOLARIS. Since SOLARIS is becomming to be a box office failure, hopefully like another intellectual sci-fi film that suffered the same fate, BLADE RUNNER, SOLARIS, WILL be the next cult favorite.  This is one of the best films of 2002, and please see SOLARIS the way the film should be seen, on the big screen.  ***** (out of five) ONE OF THE BEST FILMS OF 2002!!!

It was a very well-produced, exceedingly boring movie.  I was not expecting an action film (thank God for that!), but this was the exact opposite.  What would have made a moderately entertaining 30 minutes on the Twilight Zone (with commercial breaks) is here expanded far beyond the call of necessity.

George Clooney plays Chris Kelvin, a psychologist who has recently suffered a bereavement following the death of his wife. A friend suggests that he should go and help the crew of a research station orbiting an ocean world known as Solaris and, upon arrival, it seems all is not as it should be. The crew are on edge, talking about a phenomenon they cannot understand, glimpsing individuals they thought long dead. Chris is skeptical, right up to the moment his own dead wife turns up and starts talking to him.Creepy, unnerving and with a sense of plain oddness throughout, this was pitched as a romance in space, and that's way off the mark. Whilst there is a clear romantic angle, it drips with eeriness and dread, hardly something to cuddle up on the sofa to.Soderbergh's direction is excellent, evocative and surreal and making use of some breath-taking special effects to enhance the storyline, not detract from it.If sci-fi should always be ideas driven, this sets out to do precisely what it achieves, though the slow pace may be a struggle for some.You know who you are.

I thought this was an real good film.  It was a great thought provoking film.  Sometimes I like to watch films that make me think and I don't know the ending to half way through the film.  Some people did not like this film at all.  Those people are probably not thinkers.If you like 2001: A space Odyssey then this is a film for you.  Although slow it is definitely worth the watch.  I will probably add this film to my collection.

Review title: A return to classical science fiction
Review_body: Though many may prefer the 1972, three hour(or more) Russian version of Solaris, I must say that I thoroughly enjoyed this updated version of Stanislaw Lem's masterpiece sci-fi novel by the same title. Produced by James Cameron and written/directed by Steven Sodebergh, this version of Solaris is an intelligent, thoughtful and reflective movie, a triumph of the narrative and visual which co-exist in this case in a wonderful balance. Steven Sodebergh's script, though lean, does not ignore the the essence of the book, which is that this is a love story, a search for redemption, a second chance, one to undo passed wrongs and mistakes.I won't delve into the plot of the movie or the book, save to say, that many of us could identify with the plight of the principal character, doctor Chris Kelvin (George Clooney), a man beset by the demons of his past. The sorrow, regret and pain that he carries within himself is aptly disguised by a facade of melancholy and sadness. I was very impressed with George Clooney's performance. If I ever had any doubts about his range and talent as an actor, this movie truly put them to rest. While before I used to see him as just another pretty-boy-wannabe-TV-actor, after his turns in "Three Kings" "Out of Sight", "Good Night and Good Luck" and my favourite "Syrianna" and of course "Solaris", in my mind he has cemented his acting abilities and talent beyond a shadow of a doubt. George Clooney is bar none one of the best actors working today.The cinematography is beautiful, while the CGI/F/X are excellent, supporting the movie and its overall atmosphere and look, never being intrusive or taking over. "Solaris" is a fine example of what true sci-fi can be, and can thus join the pantheon of sci-fi classics as "2001 A Space Odyssey", "Alien", "Blade Runner", "Gattaca", "Dark City", "Strange Days" and others.Natasha McElhone (Rheya) is great (and beautiful) while the rest of the supporting cast is very good (Jeremy Davies is really weird...but in a good way).The soundtrack totally captures the atmosphere and mood of the movie, which is one of melancholy and sadness. Cliff Martinez is one of the most talented musicians in the business today. Steven Sodebergh's direction is great and as expected, of great quality.If you are a fan of grand, epic scale sci-fi opera like Star Wars (not to take anything away from Star Wars and its significance for sci-fi), or prefer action and a high body count a la Starship Troopers and Total Recall, then perhaps this movie is not for you. If you want a movie with a deeper meaning and more thoughtful structure, then "Solaris" is that movie. Its appeal lies in the fact that it goes beyond a movie specifically classified as science fiction. "Solaris" is one of the best movies out there!

I never read anything about "Solaris" before viewing it and after its end the whole movie was great experience for me. Story is very interesting and it makes you think about few things. What is actually happening on board? Why are this visions coming to the main characters? And lots more. Beside story, actors are also on top. George Clooney plays main role and I have to say that this is very difficult role to play. In my opinion Clooney was very good, just like Jeremy Davies and Natascha McElhone. I didn't watch the Russian original "Solyaris" so I cannot compare it to this American one. But the story is simply great and I bow to the people who wrote this, so I probably guess that original is better (I have to find the original). If you never watched it, you will be pleased with "Solaris". It isn't long, it is interesting and very good SF movie.

This movie was directed by Steven Soderberg, who has directed such films as Traffic, and Ocean's Eleven. It's a remake of a 1972 Russian film with the same title from director, Andrei Tarkovsky. This film stars George Clooney as a therapist who is troubled by his wife's suicide, and while on a mission to investigate a strange occurrence on a space station near the planet of Solaris, he encounters his own strange occurrences; the appearance of his dead wife. The film was not very popular among audience due to the fact that it is a slow moving film. However, I couldn't help but love it for that. It takes its time to explain the strange events on this doomed space station, and Soderberg did a fine job in directing this film. I found its dialogue, and acting to be pretty good. I only wish that I were able to compare it to the original film. ***

Review title: A unique idea and script, but not very intense result. A nice recommendation to fans though.
Review_body: Space movie / fantasy / drama. A psychiatrist is called to meet the space station crew, who had gone to study Solaris, but unexplained events occur. A unique idea where a dead loved one regains flesh and blood through Solaris. He is trying to understand on the one hand, but on the other hand he is sinking more and more into that. A special script and idea, slow pace, something common for a space movie, and an ending that really confuses the viewer. Maybe if they invested more in emotion and effects it would be one of the strongest of its kind. However, the movie is still quite mild overall. Nevertheless, an interesting recommendation to all fans of the genre.

Review title: Pure crap the worst Clooney movie
Review_body: This one had bomb written all over it. I knew when they tried to do a remake of a movie that nobody had even heard of much less seen you knew it was gonna be a turkey. Clooney just doesn't cut it it's as simple as that. I knew one woman who just got up and left 5 minutes into it she could not take it anymore. Boring and thought deprived it's like Star Trek on dope. I can name you twenty sci-fi movies off the top of my head that were better without any difficulty at all. Don't watch it and I'm not telling you that so you will watch it. I mean it. Don't watch it. The word sucks doesn't begin to adequately describe how bad it is. If you do watch it you do so at the expense of your time and sanity.

Okay, I add the fact that I saw this before seeing the original one and reading the book, as I wasn't able to do any of those before.I must say, I liked the original one more. This has more romance, almost is only about the love story between Kris and Rheya (in the original one Khari), and deals less with the ocean of the planet.Now, I must add that its depiction of the solaris' appearance was very intriguing, though is far from both the original movie or the book's concept of Solaris.Now, I must say this could have been a good remake, if they added that corridor we see in the '72 one, and if they sticked a little closer to the tarkovskij plot or the lem plot. Because on the love story side and the FX side we were on the good way, just the choosal of taking out the plot about the ocean the way we see it in the book or The '72 movie could have worked. Also with an actual landing scene on the planet, that we didn't have in the previous one.This was overall a good take, just it's not as good as the previous one from the plot- message point of view.

Director Steven Soderbergh continues to challenge audiences with his remake of the 1972 Russian epic, "Solaris". The original was a strange, very demanding movie, and the remake is no different, only much shorter. This is not a sci-fi film for the people who think "Independence Day" is a sci-fi film.The year is not given, but it is clear that the story takes place sometime in a pretty distant future. Something strange has happened aboard a space station orbiting a glowing ocean planet called Solaris. Before the crew cut off contact, they were exhibiting bizarre, seemingly paranoid behavior. Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) is summoned to go to the space station and find out what happened, and upon arrival he finds a trail of blood and two of the crew members dead.In a more ordinary film, this is probably where slimy, fanged aliens would start jumping out of the shadows, but this is not that kind of movie.Apparently, the planet of Solaris is conscious. It responds to tests as if it knows it is being observed. Most disturbingly, it has the power to reach into your subconscious and replicate any person, living or dead, from your life and put them right there on the space station. This is what Kelvin finds out when he wakes up next to his wife, Ryeah (Natascha McElhone), who killed herself years ago, but is now here, seemingly in flesh and blood. What is she? Is she human or alien? The catch is that she doesn't know, either. She exhibits emotion, believes she is Ryeah and doesn't remember dying. This obviously is a moral dilemma, as she is clearly not "real", yet is a conscious, emotional being who is seemingly the same person as his dead wife."Solaris" gets even much more complicated than that, as it inter-cuts scenes of Chris and Ryeah's tragic relationship on Earth with all the confusion aboard the space station, with the ever-present glowing ocean of Solaris seeming to silently observe them the whole time, like rats in a moral maze.The movie is undeniably slow-moving and strange, and a lot of people will not like it. Some people enjoy watching movies like this that force you to examine the very nature of humanity, and some don't. If you don't like movies like that, then you will not have a good time.But for a patient and open-minded movie fan, "Solaris" is riveting, powerful stuff.

SPOILERS ---- Solaris is a planet-sized super-intelligent life form able to create flesh and blood facsimiles of people drawn from the memories of other people. This it does to the researchers on board the spaceship that is probing solaris. Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) is the shrink sent up to investigate the madness afflicting the ship. Immediately he is confronted by a copy of the gorgeous Rheya who used to be his wife or maybe girl friend and soon he is crazy too. At the end, he is back on earth and after he accidentally cuts himself and the wound immediately heals, he realizes that he himself is a creation of solaris.Fascinating how the Rheya creature becomes so depressed when she realizes that she is not really a human. She knows there is something artificial about her and at one point says something like, " I remember things but i don't remember experiencing things." I love that line.This is a remake of the 1972 Solaris which i tried to watch once and gave up due to extreme boredom. This 2002 version is slow too but it's pretty good.

Review title: Pathetic attempt to remake Tarkovsky's 1972 film
Review_body: This film is just pathetic.Yet again Hollywood attempts to remake something that just cannot, CANNOT be remade.I feel so sorry for George, I have no idea why he even took the project, he's not hard up for money and generally he's got good taste in scripts. Maybe he was on a profile-building frenzy at the time?The original, real Solaris has a lot of artistic padding in it, and the real SF action doesn't start going until well into the second half. That's Tarkovsky, he was always style over substance.But man once the original bites into the substance, it gets there. That stuff stays with you. I still shiver, unable to forget a certain tinkling glass sound...This film just has ... nothing. It's empty and cardboard.
Grown up sci-fi fron Soderbergh.Great cast and acting and thankfully shorter than the original.

Review title: Good, but it can't quite carry the weight of Stanislaw Lem's complex novel.
Review_body: This film, directed by Steven Soderbergh, is based on a novel by cult favorite Stanislaw Lem. I read the novel after I saw the movie, and Soderbergh made a film that is different from the novel, not unexpected but perhaps unhappily for Lem's fans. George Clooney plays Dr. Kelvin, a psychologist or psychiatrist, who is called out to deep space to find out what's gone horribly wrong on a space station. People are killing themselves on the station, and the survivors are clearly insane. Kelvin soon finds out why.The movie unfolds like a flower blooming, but we're still left confused, I'm sorry to say. Lem's point in his novel (at least as I understand it) is that aliens and humans will have absolutely no way to establish communications. Zero chance. None. Totally alien creatures have no basis for understanding, no way to grasp what is intended, and no way to communicate effectively. Soderbergh takes a part of the novel and makes his Solaris a love story of longing and loss. Although Soderbergh does this quite well, he still has hung his story on the frame of Lem's novel, and there's no fit. The alien novel can't support the human film.As a love story, Soderbergh's Solaris is compelling and heartbreaking as the story of Kelvin and his dead wife Rheya (played by Natascha McElhone) unfolds in bits and pieces of flashback and dreams finally becoming fully developed, and we learn what Kelvin's problem is. Clooney is masterful with his tired, sleep-deprived face showing all Kelvin's internal confusion, loss, and anguish.But the ship is staffed by the remaining crew of lunatics. Jeremy Davies is particularly good as the totally insane Snow, and Viola Davis does a competent job as Gordon, the only one with a scrap of sanity left. Whatever damage has been wrought by the alien presence is left unexplored and unexplained, and the ending is terribly unsatisfying, despite the tinkling music by Cliff Martinez, which I enjoyed.Overall, I like the movie, but it can't quite carry the weight of Stanislaw Lem's complex novel.

This film is embarrassingly awful.  It is long and drawn out.  There is a very boring and trying beginning to the cinema, and there is nothing in this work to remain in the theatre for.  One can hardly wait to exit the building in order to escape the torcher of watching such a trite uninteresting piece. Avoid it like the plague.

After watching this film I felt as if I had taken a strange trip nowhere.  I was confronted with so many flashbacks and flashforwards and flashgordons, that I was in limbo for a while, much like the characters in the film. Perhaps the director wanted to achieve this effect, I don't know.  I can tell you it seemed to place such emphasis on George Clooney and his character that it felt similar to a space version of Cast Away with Tom Hanks, as it specifically hyper-developed one character above all others for much of the film.  George is a good actor, that's not my complaint.  I just felt that I was looking too long at something other than what the movie should be about.  This film is about the discovery of a spacial abnormality, a nebula-like cloud known as Solaris.  But rather than placing the film's emphasis on Solaris, we are quizzically confronted with the torments of the main character's (George Clooney) life.  But here is the rub.  The director, in wanting you to understand Solaris, makes you go through all the extensive character conflict and development.  Trust me, while you can watch this in a oxygen-rich environment, you'll feel as if you're stuck in some empty pod on the planet "What the Hell".  This sort of reminds me when all the big underwater thriller flicks were coming out that displayed both the good and bad to the unknown (Deep Star Six vs. The Abyss).  This film was an Abyss that just went too far off into the blue yonder.  And the ending felt as if it were quietly attempting to creak into the depths of 2001: A Space Odyssey.  But there aren't any stimulating afterthoughts in this one though.

Here, they calculated an entry into the world of limited audiences as most people alive have no interest in or grasp of existence.   They took it further by also venturing into the fear-ridden world of the Religionist with a dialogue on Creation. For that, you are to be congratulated.Now for the product: Although the "I Am" concept of mind construct of our reality is as old as the earliest of Hindu philosophies, demonstrated even in the early Upanishads of 5000 years ago and carried on through the latter ones called the Vedas, only in the 20th Century did two human events finally occur to help us grasp their essential truth. This body, published with embellishments as The Coming of Seth, a decade later, reverberated throughout the world and introduced in great detail, the nature of ultimate reality.
	Solaris is a filmic depiction of this concept and at first glance it appears to be incomplete and fragmented.  Upon close scrutiny we see that it is a complete and satisfying presentation of the question of existence.
