This is ostensibly a story about a psychologist, George Clooney, who is sent to a space station orbiting Solaris to check on a mysterious malady that's affected the crew.  But the story disintegrates into a lot of new age religious junk about man creating his own universe.  It's pretty dull.The only pluses are the beautiful Natascha McElhone, the set designs, and the interesting sound track by Cliff Martinez, who seems to have made a career scoring films for Steven Soderbergh.The planet somehow is tapping into the humans' minds and creating beings from the images of people in their past.  They have physical structure and awareness, but only as far as the person remembers them.  Clooney's wife in real life committed suicide because she felt displaced and feared being left alone, so George tries to make amends with the alien life form taking her place.  If I could make sense of the muddled ending to the movie, I'd explain how things turn out, but the story falls apart and becomes incomprehensible. You get the sense that Solaris is supposed to be like Heaven or some form of afterlife, but it's not clear what the writers were thinking.Movies about aliens used to depict them as threats.  They were out to kill us, eat us, steal our women, take our planet away from us - basic caveman stuff.  But there seems to be a trend towards depicting alien life in a godlike manner - "2001", "Contact", "Sphere", etc. - like they're omnipotent benefactors out to help us earthlings.  Somewhere, there should be a middle ground where aliens act like any other physical being struggling to stay alive and make sense of this universe of ours.

I can remember watching the original Tarkovsky adaptation of Stanislaw Lem's "Solaris" many moons ago. Despite its length, lack of space battles and its massive longueurs, I was mesmerised.When I saw that Hollywood was gearing up to remake this classic Russian film, I was sceptical. I waited until the film was shown on TV rather than go to the cinema to see it. Now I wish that I'd seen it on the big screen instead.Stephen Soderberg has managed to turn in a movie that broods, shocks and entrances as much as the Tarkovsky version in a more viewable 2 hour running time. DO NOT go to see this movie if you like space battles and simple story lines. "Solaris" is a tale of love, loss and general weirdness, not "Star Wars". Not all Sci-fi has to be driven by special effects.

Where do I start? What a secret hit this was for me, saw a poster on the wall at the cinema's for this and thought George Clooney? No way I will ever watch this, I don't care for him at all, but how wrong I was. I found it sitting at the local video store and there was nothing else so I gave it a go, well I have watched this film nearly 20 times, and every time it grabs me, every time I try and work out that ending. Best sound score, and it is the most visually stunning sci-fi movie ever. I don't care for romance, but this film hits the spot! What a mind twisting story. I don't care for George C but I think he was perfect for this role. The cinematography was fantastic, the rain, the surroundings, the colors and so on. Like I said I never ever get enough of this film. I gave this film to my older brother and he loved it, my younger sister did as well, but the so called love of my life at the time canned it! But hey we are all different and sure it's not every once cup of tea. 10 out of 10 and the best film for me ever.

This is definatly one of the worst films I've ever seen. It's completely unintersting or devoids any reason to be entertaining by any legnth of the imagination. The acting is of course decent but the film has no  where to go and basically revolves around the showing of Clooneys' rear end shot. Also Natasha Mcelhone needs to not make any more movies she seems to be damning them to film purgatory as I witnessed the second encantaion of her horrid career, the first being feardotcom. I'm all about a slow moving film and I loved the first one.However the film has to be interesting and involving neither of which solaris is.  But this film is such a mess. It should have never been made, and if so never released. It's an embarrasment to all of them and I will definatly think twice before going to see another film with any of these people in it or associated with it.  Be forewarned and get ready to nap.

I should have known when I found out that this movie did not run in the Big Screen Movie Theatre but in the independent movie theatre: This is an art movie. I didn't believe that a big budget movie by Steven Soderbergh with George Clooney in it would not be "high profile" enough to be omitted by the Big Screen - but well, it was, and what a shame!This movie somehow is like a new "2001" with a clearer message and a much shorter running time - and that's a good thing! It is a contemplative experience with visual and acoustic brilliance which never gets boring though there is not too much happening on screen. Well, the casting of Natascha McElhone was certainly a big addition to the atmosphere - not because she is especially good, but because she has a certain scary quality about her which is hard to bear. The are scenes in which she is looking directly into the camera where I for my part would not like to be alone in a room with her. Soderbergh could have casted a beautiful woman - that would have made the movie a different film - but he decided to cast McElhone, and therefore gave the movie an eery, surreal touch. Well done!All in all a very satisfying movie which certainly could have been faster, longer or more action packed, but that would not have captured Stanislaw Lems spirit - and though I hardly remember the book, having read it a decade ago, I am sure that in spite of many changes the movie captures it right now. You probably won't remember this one for years - but it's certainly worth a look!

It may help you to anticipate whether or not you'll like Solaris when I say that I liked it very well, and my wife didn't. She has a plodding sort of cinematic perception, and needs a linear story line in order to keep up. I loved the time and space uncertainties, and thought it was a superb inquiry into the nature of perception, reality, and the recesses of human nature. Along that line, it brought to my mind Forbidden Planet, which demonstrated the dark power of the Id. There are similar psychological aspects to Solaris. It's beautifully photographed, by the way, and I loved the understated special effects (unlike almost any "space" story). Here's a comparison: if you like Pulp Fiction, you'll probably like this film. If P.F. makes you ask "What day is it now?", you probably won't like Solaris.

Review title: Metaphors aren't always clearly explained, I see.
Review_body: Steve Martin clearly said it right in the Academy Awards, two years ago: "The trailers give away to much of the movie". Indeed. Solaris was wrapped up in big expectation: the reported George Clooney's nudity; Steven Soderberg writing and the return of James Cameron. The story goes that a mission to the planet Solaris, in an unknown future is on the verge of jeopardy. Security teams have been sent and have not returned, and the crew has lost contact, aledgedly insane. Dr. Chris Kelvin is sent in as a specialized psychiatrist, whose head is shaken up by the recent death of his wife. When he arrives he has to deal with the strangeness of the remaining crew as well as the visits of her dead wife that abound in his thought. As producers said, the movie is all about second chances, as well as choices, being the whole thing just a metaphor. However, Soderberg messes up in the writing passing everything on the directing. The trailer suggested something different. The trailer came out as one of the best - as long with The Two Towers and X2 - of the year. Cliff Martinez's score although present wasn't there. It was needed something powerful and striking, whereas what we get is almost none. George Clooney and Natasha McHelone's performances alternate between sublime and dull, coming as a result dull, the supporting Jeremy Davies does it all on what acting is concerned. The planet Solaris, the mysterious identity that runs the whole movie only gets atractivly creepy in the end. What Solaris needed was Science Fiction atmosphere; it should make us believe that we were really in space, something that the 2000's worldwide hated (guilty pleasure to me) Supernova, had to have and to hold.4 out of 10.

This 96 minute film seems twice as long as Tarkovsky's 1972 version, which was indeed profound and moving. Save your money and see the Tarkovsky version on video or DVD.  Better yet, wait for it to come to a revival house near you, if you live in a big city.  If you don't, it may be a long wait.

Review title: The Big Star and the Comedienne
Review_body: Would have had to seen this eventually: Lem, Soderbergh, Clooney. Saw it sooner, though, mainly to discover whether Soderbergh, working apparently from the book, would somehow hit on the shot from Solyaris that's stayed most assuredly with me. It may be the very last shot in Tarkovsky's film. His camera draws back from the memory event on the planet's surface, until the phenomenon looks like a scab and the planet like flesh. It may look a bit, as well, like a sunspot or Jupiter's blemish, but the scab metaphor yields more: a wounded orb, spontaneously healing itself.Soderbergh's planet's blue, constantly spewing and drawing back to itself gaseous tendrils. Key to embracing Solaris is to forget, as much as possible, Solyaris. Clooney's a huge romantic star, with huge star baggage. Cary Grant stricken humorless in a spacesuit. Imagine the only sort of film that could have put Grant in a spacesuit. I think maybe it's the romantic comedy lurking beneath that makes Clooney's George Kelvin's tragic resignation as affecting as it is. Beneath the tragedy in Natascha McElhone's face is a big-mouthed, pouting clown.The thing about Rheya (McElhone) is her situation is actually that of each of us, not excluding George Kelvin. Each of us, in one sense or another, is imagined into being by our parents. Even the worst cases imaginable, battlefield rapists and worse, if there is worse, I'm sure somehow image offspring, imagine life created. But parents raising children, foster parents raising others' children, continue imagining, imaging, lives, just as Kelvin continues imaging Rhea and even Rheya 2 after that early plot turn. Each of us imagines and is imagined by our lovers. Each of us arrives in a world that existed with myriad complications before us, and leaves, too soon, long before it will end.Yet what Kelvin engages in, as his crashingly sane colleague Gordon, played by Viola Davis, implies, is a sort of necrophilia, a sort of onanism. See the really dark coda to A.I. in which David resurrects a sentient yet rigidly terminal manifestation of his "mother" (mistaken by many critics for Spielbergian pap).Maybe this is a film for those who experience or temperament has never led to Lem or Tarkovsky, but it's not a bad way to go.

Review title: Soderburgh's Intimacy Takes Over, Lem/ Tarkovsky's Existential Examination Fades Away
Review_body: Thanks to Steven Soderbergh's audacious attempt to make an updated version of Andrei Tarkovsky's profound but dated sci-fi classic, the contemporary spectators can easily take a look at the Polish author Stanislaw Lem's planet Solaris, which communicates with the Earthlings via physically presented human figures who appear in a space station. However, Soderbergh's signature intimacy takes over in the film; while the confusing nonlinear sequence towards the end allows the audience many different interpretations, the sensuous last scene may leave the viewers a feeling that the film's argument is romance, rather than the existential examination of Lem and Tarkovsky.Aside from Lem/ Tarkovsky, as one independent piece, the film showcases the excellence of Soderbergh's one and only intimate atmosphere, distilled by great acting from the great casts (especially George Clooney and Jeremy Davies), simple and subtle art directions for the space station and the space landscape, and quiet and pop computer compositions that are reminiscent of Terry Riley and Carl Stone.

It's a remake of a Russian film, so of course snobbish "purists" out there will tell you it can't possibly "be as good as the original." Whatever. I never saw the original, and I'll go with the prevailing wisdom that it's a good film. Okay. But I can only judge what I see, and I've seen Soderbergh's "Solaris", and it is a thought-provoking and rich film that manages to sell itself in a short running length (just over 90 minutes). I believe the original was much, much longer, but I don't believe the short running length is bad for Soderbergh's version. If anything, it leaves you wanting more.

Review title: Wow! - hold onto your mind before diving into this film - a refreshingly excellent sci-fi story
Review_body: I had not read the book, nor seen the well known earlier Russian version of this story on film, so I wasn't sure what to expect, but had at least some notion that this film would be more than just a bit "different".I was not disappointed! Folks, if your "thing" for sci-fi outer space genre' films is the usual suspect cliché' ad nauseum of invading creatures, violent chase scenes and exploding space ships, this is definitely not your film.Warning . . . warning . . . warning . . .This film requires and will induce thought.Concepts like define existence, what exactly is death, or life for that matter, is only the beginning edge of where this story takes you, as one follows George Clooney's character out into deep space aboard a corporate financed space station in orbit around Solaris.While living on Earth, he's summoned to go out to the station, to solve a "problem" that no one can understand or even describe . . .The minute he steps on board the craft, you know something's up . . . but in ways that go far outside the box of "the usual suspect" plot line.As for the characters and the actors who portray them, of course. I could watch George Clooney in just about anything, but the real star here is Natascha McElhone, as Rheya. The chemistry between these two is obvious, but Natascha has her own depth of character complexity that I cannot find words for here, but is absolutely compelling to watch.No, I'm not going to meander down a laundry list of what happens at various key pivot points in this story, as such would be tedious, and hopelessly inadequate to convey the experience this film delivers.From a technical and aesthetic perspective, this is a very beautiful, well crafted example of the artform. There is no wasted space as it were. Every scene is composed and integrated together to literally create an evolving artpiece containing a story, populated with living beings enmeshed into emotional complexities who may, or may not . . . be human, sort of . . .But that description can't even begin to hint at what is going on here in this unique story. For that, you'll just have see it for yourself.I humbly suggest investing the time to see this - you won't be disappointed

A hunk of junk is an under statement!  What a waste of time!  Why did anyone think this plot would be enjoyable?  It is worse than Star Trek Deep Space Nine!  Seriously, if you are given a choice between watching this movie or moving a 25 foot sand pile, one hand full at a time, TAKE THE SAND PILE!    It can't make up it's mind if it is in space or on earth.  Moves back and forth, and without understanding!  It acts like it knows what it is doing, but in fact, it comes over as a bunch of hog wash created by people with more money than they know what to do with for people who want to believe they have an understanding about something that is complete stupidity!

Review title: There's a reason 2001:A Space Odyssey was never remade....
Review_body: And the same should have held true with Solaris. Solaris like 2001 was based on a novel and the original Russian film directed by a luminary is every bit the epic 2001 was. In fact the movie, which has a darker vision and unlike the novel has an unhappy ending, is like a reply to 2001's vision. There is no rebirth but a lengthy kind of death because human beings carry the same pains and failings in space as they do on earth. Their weaknesses are no less relevant there. They will never be free of them and it's a simple fact of human nature.This American remake made 30 years later fails on nearly every level. It has the effects and acting but it's like a B movie with a big budget. I did try to like it but it doesnt capture the spirit of even Stanislaw Lem's novel or the Andrei Tarkovsky film.I suspect fans of Steven Soderbergh's movies are very easily entertained but fans of most remakes are too. Is it so hard to watch something made before you were born? I wasn't around in 1972 but I watched the Russian film. All three hours of it. If you want to watch The Godfather, watch that. If you want to watch some 3rd rate Mafioso movie that is clearly inspired by The Godfather, why bother when the other one is out there? Same is true with Solaris.

Review title: At first intriguing, but then a bit boring
Review_body: I haven't seen the (as I understood) classic Solaris from famous Russian filmmaker Tarkovski, of which this film (directed by Soderbergh) is some sort of remake/translation. Which is an advantage for the 2002 film I guess, since most critics thought this film was absolutely inferior to the 70s version. At first I am intrigued: what is going on aboard that space station? The film asks many questions and hardly answer any. Which is no problem for me, I do like the occasional anti-Hollywood type film that doesn't force us a nightly tied ending. But here it doesn't quite work in my opinion. Somewhere halfway through the film you figure out what is going on. And then you expect another twist because hey...we're only halfway! But that twist doesn't (really) happen. And so the second half of the film becomes just a bunch of actors talking about "it". In general I'm a fan of Clooney, but I found him quite pale and uninteresting here. McElhone does a better job. Final verdict: not really worth your time.

Review title: A decent remake for those without the patience for the original
Review_body:
With remakes, there's always going to be a comparison to the original. I think I would have liked this movie a little more if I had not already seen Tarkovsky's 1972 original. The first question with remakes I suppose should be why? I can see the reason for this film being to bring a really good sci-fi story to the younger generation that probably won't be seeing the 165min Russian original. I heard some comments that this movie was too slow or too boring. Well, in that case, I'm sure they wouldn't have had the patience for the original. I've also heard some sci-fi fans who really appreciate Soderbergh's version...in those cases, I'd consider the idea of doing the remake a success. I'm sure some of them would definitely appreciate the original, but I'm sure a certain percentage wouldn't be willing to sit through the same slow-paced story when the running time is nearly twice as long in the original. Soderbergh did a fine job with this movie and did fairly well at capturing the feeling of the original in a quicker time. If that was his vision, then I think he succeeded. He didn't really add anything new to this story. This movies is pretty much an exact, but compacted, copy of the original Tarkovsky film. The actors were adequate, but I didn't get the emotion, albeit subtle, that I got from the Russian original. I personally feel the gratuitous shots of Clooney's butt were unnecessary. In my opinion, Clooney's lead character may have been better with a lesser known actor. He plays the role fairly well and it's one of his more subtle performances to date, but you can't help but see certain Clooneyisms come out from time to time, especially when he gets upset. Though I feel Soderbergh did well to cast lesser knowns in the supporting roles. All in all, it's a decent remake bringing a solid sci-fi story to modern day fans of the genre, but I'd recommend the original to those who can make it through the epic length Russian version of this story.
**1/2 (Out of 4)

Good movie but very slow. If I didn't read the book, I don't think I would have liked it.  By removing the main concept of the book, that Solaris is a planet with a world wide sentient ocean, we remove the explanation that Solaris represents an alien form that can not be understood by man. Solaris, in the book, is the entity that unlocks the human subconscious. So what are we left with, why are we seeing these people that can teach us so much about ourselves?  I don't know but it felt to me that this film was only a reflection of our society where everything is only about ME.  What is missing from my life, how do I fulfill my needs?  I love someone else only because I see myself in them.  Maybe we have to get over ourselves and look outside, leave our subconscious alone and move on. If we weren't so self absorbed we might find a real reason for existence.

Review title: Sci-Fi it ain't; pretentious and boring it is.
Review_body: There are good films and bad films; there are very good films and very bad ones. 'Solaris' is somewhere between the bad and very bad. It's a pretentious 'style over substance' attempt to be meaningful with a story that's hard to comprehend and a script that's largely incoherent and with few sentences of more than 5 or 6 words.Some have compared this with another pretentious piece of nonsense, '2001 : A Space Odyssey' and found it wanting, which says it all. For me, Kubrick's film was beautiful but horribly lacking in real content; Solaris has neither beauty nor content and the science fiction aspect is entirely unnecessary as the love story at the centre of the film could have been set anywhere. While Kubrick had the benefit of the menacing Hal, Soderbergh has nothing; there is nothing in this film to grab hold of. People who must be presumed to be highly intelligent and rational, lose their rationality when confronted by situations which simply cannot be true.This is obviously someone's idea of great and meaningful film making, but it certainly isn't mine. It jumps around in time and place which only serves to make it even more confusing to follow. The cast are wooden in the extreme, exhibiting no real emotion and, frankly, looking as bored as I was after the first 30 minutes or so. They, of course, were being paid big bucks so got a reward for their time; I was not being paid and simply got bored. Nonetheless, I persevered to the end - more fool me.2 out of 10 at best.

I must say not right off-hand, this is not a bad film. I'm giving it a 6 out of 10. But, it could have/should have been a lot better. Soderbergh is one of the most talented directors of his generation. He puts out an enormous volume of work. In fact, within the last 12 months, he has also released "Ocean's 11" and "Full Frontal," the later of which I have not seen. "Traffic" was a riveting film. No one could argue with that. But, "Solaris' was not really a project suited for Soderbergh's talents. He seems to fare better with simple real-to-life films, "The Limey" is a great example of this. "Solaris" is also dwarfed by Tarkovsky's original, which is an enigamtic as hell yet masterful piece of work. This film lacks the depth of imagery of the original, and it is really hard to Americanize such a film which was clearly very Russian in its themes when it came out in 1972. There is some sex here, and modern special effects wizardy than you don't see in the Tarkovsky film, but it doesn't make it any more memorable. But, I think it is a noble failure, and certainly proves Soderbergh and Clooney are not afraid to take risks, alas they did it much better in "Out of Sight." Still one has to look forward to this talented director's next project, let's just hope it will not be based on a movie that's been done before.

Review title: Like staring off into space for two hours
Review_body: One of the biggest problems with Solaris is that it is being marketed incorrectly.  Perhaps this is because it doesn't even know what it is. It is NOT a romance.  I'm not sure to call it a sci-fi or not.Perhaps my preconceptions have simply become too shaped by Hollywood. Initially the movie reminded me of Event Horizon (another mismarketed film) or Alien.  Consequently, throughout most of the movie, I kept on expecting tentacles or claws to pop out of Rheya's head.  Mind you, I'm not saying that I WANTED this to happen.Herein lies one big problem.  There are plenty of thriller moments throughout Solaris.  It builds expectations and tension in the audience and then proceeds to deliver NOTHING.  Imagine a typical slasher movie in which the protagonist slowly approaches the door at the end of the hall, reaches forward, opens the door...and then the scene fades and cuts to the same protagonist eating Cheerios in the kitchen a week later. Solaris is NOT a slasher or thriller but many times it pretends to be.About 60 percent of this movie is people staring blankly into nothingness. Another 30 percent consists of the trippy swirls of Solaris.  This leaves about 15 minutes for something to actually happen.You'll hate this movie if you like closure and a plot that clicks.  I call this the "Sixth Sense" syndrome.  Ever since the S.S., audiences have become accustomed to tolerating long-winded movies that seem to wander aimlessly with the promise that the ending will deliver a magical twist that pulls everything together perfectly.  This is definitely NOT the case with Solaris.  I understand that uncertainty is one of the primary points of this movie, but I think it was a poor choice to use the movie itself as a means to demonstrate this.Even as a pure sci-fi movie, Solaris is nothing special.  There isn't a single idea or concept that hasn't already been explored more eloquently by countless other sci-fi movies.  And there's no need to present these ideas in such an unconsumable-to-the-masses form as Solaris.  A typical Star Trek episode has better sci-fi than this; plus you save 45 minutes.Throw in awful film editing and immensely annoying characters who always mumble their lines, and you end up with a frustrating movie that's generally pretentious and not very interesting.I would recommend this movie only if:A) You love movies that are so abstract and vague that you basically need to write half the movie in your head to fill in all the blanks.  Perhaps this may be considered "clever" movie-making for the thinking viewer, but I think it just boils down to bad storytelling.B) You love George Clooney, and you love his butt.  (No and No, for me)All in all, I give Solaris an imdb 4/10.  Oh and another thing. (SPOILER??):  This movie ends by flashing its title, SOLARIS, in big, bold letters across the screen.  I hate it when movies do this.  As if we might have forgotten which movie we were watching?

Review title: "I see dead people from outer space... Are they real?"
Review_body: This film had me really upset.I generally like Soderbergh's movies, especially his daring ones. So I was expecting something outstanding.He sadly missed in this movie every single opportunity to give the potentially moving story a chance to touch the viewer. To be moved by this, one has to be so sensitive that he/she cries when viewing "Dallas".Yeah, the spaceships look good. Yeah, the cinematoraphy is neat. Yeah, the woman has touching eyes (the "Emily Watson effect"). Yeah, Clooney has a nice butt. So what? This is just another of this modern and uninteresting movies which, instead of using cinematic narratives, just **illustrates**, "nicely" and "cleverly", a story like if we already knew it before... and expects from the viewer to be immersed in the story just because it's a good story. Bad news, Steven, a director's work is not only showing what he can do, using creative editing and cool cinematography... He actually has a role to play in the way the viewer relates to the story and the characters! Have you forgotten this since "Sex, lies and videos"?We know nothing about the characters, and we are asked just to deal with what happens, and the way they behave. I don't mind to feel far from the characters if a philosophical purpose is cleverly exposed or evocated, or if the audiovisual narratives incline to meditation, like in 2001. Here it's almost impossible, as the whole movie is drawned deep into a stubborn musical score that makes each scene "feel" exactly like the one before. This music seems to tell you: "nothing is happening, don't worry, you shall not be moved, or scared, or even interested, just be patient and the film will eventually come to an end"... Zzzzzzz** - the only meditation allowed is to think of the shopping list... result: people who already don't like that much slow-paced movies will HATE them after seeing Solaris. Well done, indeed, Steve, well done!There is no real emotional drive in Solaris, though the director seems to think differently. Good for him. To feel concerned by a character's emotions, one must get close to him/her. The flashbacks in Solaris are an inadequate way to fill the gaps of the early narrative, and they give only flat explanations, not meaningful inner motives. A touching love story is not made out of mere facts, neither is a good SF story.The whole thing looks pretentious and utterly empty, far too clean, intellectual and desincarnate, and the many nods to 2001 only make me think that Kubrick seems to have really traumatized directors, even talented ones like De Palma or Soderbergh, who have both been completely unable to come up with a "space opera" of their own without basically mimicking Kubrick's work, and fall into every obvious trap that lead to make boring SF movies "in the manner of 2001".When will a talented, artistic director have the guts to make a really creative, independant and meaningful new movie about the meeting of man with a cosmic intelligence, without desperatly trying to compete with 2001? Is there such a lack of imagination and creativity in the movie industry?Solaris was, for me, as interesting as a mix bewteen the worse aspects of "Star Trek", "Sixth sense" and "A.I.". How does it sound? Not very good. "I see dead people from outer space... Are they real?"The good thing about this movie is that it made me want to look at Tarkowski's original movie, hoping that the potentially excellent story was not, like in Soderbergh's movie, buried under the will to show off...

Solaris is the second movie based on Stanislaw Lem's sci-fi novel, the first one being the 1972 Soviet film (which I haven't seen, so can't give any comparison insight). It follows the trip of a psychologist named Chris Kelvin to a space station in orbit around the planet Solaris. The visuals of the planet, station, and equipment is great. The atmosphere that the special effects create feels perfect for the movie, invoking a sense of mystery and uncertainty. When Kelvin arrives, he finds that there are only two surviving members and proceeds to investigate. Ironically, he turns out to be the one that is effected the most by the planet. In short, the film revolves around the subject of memory, dreams, and emotion.The music is excellent. The dialog could have been better, but the acting was solid. George Clooney does a respectable job as Kelvin, although not outstanding. Since there are only four main characters, there is a special focus on each member of the team. The majority is centered around Kelvin and the memory of his wife, which is an interesting relationship that covers a wide range of emotions. The plot gets a little jumbled (mostly due to the constant switch between present and memory) and has several unexplained parts. Even so, it is easy to get immersed into and gives a satisfying conclusion.Solaris is a must-see for sci-fi fans or broad thinkers. It is visually beautiful and has intriguing content. Despite a few technical problems, the plot will absorb you for the whole time.

I always find it interesting to approach a movie that has people so polarized - in this case "it was sooooo slow" vs. "uplifting and incredible." That seems to go for the critics as well. My reaction was neither.I am predisposed to like this kind of science fiction - the low key and wonderful "Gattaca" comes to mind. I found the story very intriguing and atmospheric and it held my interest - at the same time I felt something was missing and it just wasn't as rich, complex and good as it should have been.I am not sure why, I think the key for me is that I was not able to really get emotionally involved with the love story - and this is first and foremost a love story. I have trouble with most love stories, due to my own particular biases, so there has to be a lot there to really identify with it. I think the problem here was the casting and acting - it could have been a lot better. The woman playing Gordon was rather flat as well.Also the script was a little too obvious.All in all, an interesting film that I am glad I saw, but I can't really get worked up about it.

Review title: Maybe the most foreign American film I've ever seen.
Review_body: Steven Soderbergh has subverted another genre again. This sci-fi is one of the strangest motion pictures I've seen in quite some time. I still don't know what I just saw an hour ago, but I think I liked it quite a bit. (I never saw the Russian original --I never cared to.) I could describe the film's plot but I don't think it would make any difference. It is a hermetically sealed psychodrama set aboard a spaceship orbiting a sentient planet called Solaris (I think). George Clooney is in top form in a very difficult role as a psychiatrist trying to figure out what the heck is driving people nuts aboard the ship. Jeremy Davies is a wonder to behold as one of the people who has witnessed many of the goings on. His performance recalls Brad Pitt's work in "12 Monkeys" (but imagine Pitt in slow motion from that film and you'll have Davies in this). It is, however, very tough film to sit through. The story doesn't unfold before your eyes so much as it thaws before your eyes. It is a 2 hour film that plays like 3. Several people in the audience walked long before this film ended and I can't say that I blamed them. Nevertheless with that said, "Solaris" does have a weird trance-like power. It isn't so much spellbinding as it is intriguing. The ending definitely raises some questions. It is a beautiful film to watch. The production is first class. It defies easy easy explanation and I doubt that it will do much box office. You got to give Soderbergh credit trying something very different. Whether he succeeded or not is not up for popular vote but is up to you --the individual viewer. It is a very unique and very strange film with an odd power. If you want entertainment go see 007 again.

So George Clooney finally airs his tush in a movie and that's basically all the good there is to be said about this movie.Summary: Well Chris is a shrink in a distant future, I didn't see any flying cars so I'll say sometime this century and one day he is contacted by some people from the government, who have a request from a friend of his, who is out in space on a spaceship orbiting around Solaris which seems to be a planet built of energy... and really bad 70's disco lights. Anyways, slowly Chris manages to get out to that spaceship, where he he finds his friend dead and only 2 other survivors left, who can't explain what is happening, but they throw him a bone and let him know that unexplainable things will happen when he goes to sleep... oh and there was a little boy running loose on the spaceship too so if anyone knows who he is, give me a clue. Anyways, onwards, Chris goes to sleep, has a dream of his wife Rhea, how they met, how they got together... and so on, but when he wakes up, Rhea is lying right next to him! He can't believe she is there considering that she commited suicide many years ago after he couldn't accept that she was pregnant with his child...so who is she?So after seeing this movie, the conclusions I've come up with is, it does resemble Vanilla Sky a little yet that movie was like a dream heading into a nightmare, whilst this was a dream becoming reality, which past ghosts become alive... creepy thought. The first 20 minutes were awfully slow and actually the whole movie was very slow and the message of this movie was so unclear even though George Clooney keeps saying there is a message in this movie... kindly write it on a piece of paper next time and show us what the message of the movie is because all I did understand was, do not get married if you don't want to have children and to prevent that from totally happening use birth-control pills or something, that's what they are made for. The movie is about getting a 2nd chance after you've really messed up in a very strange way. This movie is a complete waste of time unless some people want to see George Clooney's butt in really bad lighting on a huge screen.

Solaris(2002) is a rare example of a remake being every bit as good as it's predecessor, and in some areas exceeding Tarkovsky's 1972 version. Solaris is adapted from Polish author Stanislaw Lems novel. The film centres around Chris Kelvin(George Clooney) a troubled psychologist sent to a distant research space station, orbiting a peculiar planet called Solaris. He's sent there to investigate strange occurrences going on with the crew, as they're experiencing possible delusions of people they loved who've passed away, coming back to life.Steven Soderbergh writes and directs this adaption, which helps give the film a singular vision. Where I feel this film improves upon Tarkovsky's version, is that it explores the emotional isolation and instability of the main character in more detail. Through the duration of the film, you see the toll it takes on Chris mentally and physically, in a way that i never got from the original film. Another aspect I really liked was the cold, strange detachedness that all the characters exhibited. The long pauses during mid conversation, the empty glances, all help to sell the eerie, uncanny atmosphere of the film, at some-points during the film it felt like it was directed by David Lynch.Something the screenplay also does that i found impressive, was that it gave the characters legitimate reasons for their actions. This is something rare in genre films, usually someone does something stupid or unrealistic to further the plot along. Here the characters motives are fully realised, and you can understand and even empathise the choices they make, even if they have negative consequences.Everybody in the film gives fantastic performances. George Clooney has never better. He gives genuine emotional intensity, especially in scenes with Natascha McElhone, who plays his on screen wife Rheya, that has somehow reincarnated aboard the space station. She gives a fantastic, unsettling performance of someone who's unsure of who they really are. Is she a living, breathing organism or a ghost living through someones memories. Jeremy Davies and Viola Davis round out the cast as two survivors aboard the station. They both give outstanding supporting performances, and their their opposing view points act as counter weights to Chris's emotional contradictions.At 1 hour 40 minutes the film is a whole hour shorter then the original film. Whilst this helps to streamline the pacing, it does end up losing some of the more deep philosophical depth Tarkovsky brought to the original. The original film also had better cinematography and set design, the space station felt generic and bland in this film. Where-as Tarkovsky's version was dirty, rundown and felt lived in. These are only a couple of minor gripes that I had with this film. Over-all Solaris(2002) met and exceed my expectations. Solaris is one of the best remakes around. It's a film that has it's own singular vision, that also adds upon the original, rather then just replicating it.

I've never really enjoyed any previous work from the director- _Erin Brockovich_ was fluff and _Traffic_ was just horrible- but _Solaris_ is really quite good.The film itself is beautiful.  I and others have accused Soderbergh of a bad Kubrick imitator in the past, but he seems to have fixed that here.  The style still very much Kubrick, but Soderbergh has taken it and made it his own.  The film reminds one of both _2001_ and _The Shining_, but comes from a different place emotionally and is thus very satisfying.  The lack of audio-visual sychronization, signifying the fragile nature of human memory, is very slick and works well here.The script can only be described as high-minded. Admittedly, the trailers are a bit deceiving, leading one to think that this will be a love story. It IS, but probably not in the way that you're thinking.  For most, this will be a big disappointment.  For those such as myself, it will be a welcome reprieve from current popular films that severely underestimate the audience.Clooney is as good as I have ever seen him- this is probably the most intellectual and challenging film he's ever done.  McElhone (most recently in the underrated _FearDotCom_) shows that when she's given good material, she can really shine.A minor complaint which is becoming more and more common for me these days: can we please have the credits at the front of the movie again?  It's not a time issue, obviously- in this film, near the beginning, I saw numerous opportunities where they could have at least done a "Twentieth Century Fox presents" schtick.  Just tell us the title of the freaking movie already. You can take five seconds and do that, can't you?Overall, this is a very, very good film.  Just be warned that thought and reflection are required.

Steven Soderbergh is the second great director to film an adaptation of the highly acclaimed novel by Stanislaw Lem. The late great Soviet director Andrei Tarkovsky made the first version of the film in 1972. This version is written, directed, photographed, and edited by the rising star Steven Soderbergh. Astute observers of cinema will recognize Soderbergh as the director who had two films nominated for best picture in the same year (Erin Brockovich and Traffic). From the previews one might expect a sci-fi space film in the tradition of 2001: A Space Odyssey. This film is actually better seen as a film about the landscape of the mind that happens to be set in outer space. George Clooney plays a psychiatrist and widower who attempts to deal with his grief by burying himself in his work. He is called away from his routine when he is asked to investigate a crisis in outer space. Two astronauts have died, and the survivors have sent back messages that are mysterious and a little scary. The psychiatrist is dispatched to solve the mystery and fix the crisis.Here he encounters an astronaut known as Snow, a delightful character full of quirks and tics. It took me a while to place the actor, but I finally recognized him as Jeremy Davies, the actor who played Corporal Upham in Saving Private Ryan. Davies gives one of the great supporting performances in the film, but the real sizzle in the acting department comes from Clooney and Natascha McElhone, the actress who plays Clooney's dead wife.Playing a dead wife might not seem especially challenging but therein lies the rub. When Clooney awakens after his first night on the spaceship, he discovers a live version of his wife in bed right next to him. Clooney soon discovers that the two surviving astronauts in the spaceship have had similar experiences. People go to bed and wake to find people that they have lost and long to see, next to them in bed.What we have told to this point could almost be gleaned from the previews. To tell more of the plot is to spoil the suspense that is an important part of the experience. If the viewer choosing this film is looking for an extraterrestrial shoot-em'-up he or she will be sorely disappointed. As a love story and psychological thriller, Solaris works quite well and Soderbergh solidifies his status as one of the great directors working in film.

Review title: Dark, slow, boring, symbolic and psychological movie.
Review_body: To make a movie with an open end is a good thing as it makes you think and search further for some answers, but if the journey to that question which the movie provokes at the end is not enjoyable,then you may not feel interested enough to look for answers.The movie starts with a brief dark background about the life of "Chris Kelvin" or "George Clooney", then he was sent to the research station for unjustified reason in no time and all the events move to the station.The movie mainly is about the relationship between Solaris "the planet" and the crew on the station, but this didn't close the door against some sci-fi scenes of outer space and the station, while i found the space suits look silly and outdated.The characters here are limited, "George Clooney" appears in most of the scenes and his actions and reactions were great, and most probably the movie wouldn't survive without him. However, his character was not introduced in the best way.All other characters were taste less, they didn't add much soul nor provoke any feelings.The movie has a message that it wants to deliver, not all of people will get it nor will enjoy it, so this kind of movie is either you will love it or hate it, no grey area here.They tried to add to the darkness of the movie by the dark colors that covered most of the scenes, the slow motion of camera, and the mystery behind the whole story.Finally, it's a drama mystery movie, that runs in a single line of actions, it's boring in most of it, and you will be disappointed if you watch it after watching the trailer, as this is one of the movies that the trailer is much better than the real movie.

Review title: What sci-fi was meant to be.
Review_body: Intelligently written and directed. Plenty of tender moments that evoked poignant contemplation and really struck deep chords with me. I felt quite affected by the love story and the treatment of memory and self-awareness hidden beneath the polished sci-fi exterior. The score and visuals, as well as Soderberg's characteristic use of deliberate flashback clips all lent to a truly moving experience of the surreal. Fine performances by Clooney, Davis, Davies and McElhone. One of my select sci-fi faves.

This was the most boring movie I have seen all year. The soundtrack was brutal! It was reminiscent of an early 80's attempt at suspense. It barely kept me awake, in fact I had to watch it in 3 sittings just to slog my way through it. God, what a snoozefest. And to top it all off, all of the characters were utterly flat and two dimensional. The deliberately weird and delusional crewmember, the one straight-headed clear-thinking person, and "I still love my dead wife" caricature. And then the most obvious ending imaginable. As soon as I saw his wife heal after she drank the liquid oxygen, I said to myself "I bet that is why they showed him cutting his finger". Sure enough, he cuts it at the end and it heals. Oooh, he is some sort of alien but doesn't know it, just like the REAL version of Blade Runner. HOW BORING! How UNORIGINAL! And la-dee-da, they get their "second chance" at happiness..... barf. How HOLLYWOOD! How could Soderbergh stray so far from "Traffic"? He was the only reason I bothered to watch this movie!! What a disappointment, honestly just about the most boring movie I have ever seen. What a piece of tripe, I couldn't wait for it to end just to see if it ever picked up. It didn't. You are better off watching reruns of The Facts of Life.

Review title: Boring and bad acting don't mix
Review_body: Clooney was dull all throughout this movie.  His quiet tortured role was mesmerizing in a hypnotic kind of way.  I found the spaceship buttons, all bright and shiny, to be very annoying.  The visuals were good though throughout and even the first 45 minutes of the story were interesting.  The last half started to drag.  This is like Event Horizon meets Blade Runner in the most boring atmosphere imaginable.  4/10, because I like romantic endings.

Review title: The worst way to spend an hour and forty minutes
Review_body: I rented this movie expecting a "space adventure" as indicated on the cover. The trailer makes it seem so dramatic and full of emotion. The movie started off at a snail's pace. The dialogue was slow and boring. It took them 5 minutes (or so it seemed) to finish their sentences! The whole atmosphere was dull. "Oh well, it'll get better" I foolishly thought. So, the movie crawled on. Finally, when George Clooney made it to the space ship, I once again thought "Ok, something has to happen now..." Nothing happened. His dead wife appeared. They kept telling him "Its not human! Its not human! Somethings going on here!" No suspense. No action. Just a bunch of boring flashbacks. By the time I was half an hour into the movie, I wanted to turn it off. But the thought that a movie can't possibly be this boring all the way to the end kept me going. I tried getting into it. I really did. But I realized, there is nothing to get into. About an hour and a half into the movie, I thought "alright, its almost over, something HAS to happen now!" And then, the movie was over. And I was not happy. Not only did I waste the money on renting this garbage, but I also wasted a good hour and a half out of my life. I could have thought of so many other things to do instead of wasting my time on this so-called "movie". There is absolutely nothing intelligent or thought-provoking about it. Its a cure for insomnia, if anything. Apparently, Steven Soderbergh has never heard of PACING, as this movie moved at the pace of a demented slug. The movie is so unmemorable, I already don't remember half of it. Yes, it is "different" from other space movies, in that the other space movies usually don't put you to sleep.

A criticism of the film `Solaris' (2002) By Christopher Manning 8-3-03Ahh Science Fiction, that most marvelous of film genre. It can be used as a vehicle to the wonderful or the terrifying. It can take you to distant uncharted planets or a nightmarish future. On the surface `Solaris' appears to be about the former. Chris Kelvin is solicited by his friend to journey to the space station that is studying the titular planet. His visit will be the last attempt to solve the rather ambiguous problems plaguing the station. We soon discover that this film is much more than a space journey filled your typical sci-fi raz-taz. It's no less a journey to the very nature of how we as humans relate and perceive one another. When one considers the apparent hero of the films profession is that of a psychiatrist as apposed to say a cop or soldier. This alone should tell the audience that this film is certainly not run of the mill. `Solaris' is most certainly an exercise in minimalism. A style that perfectly suits the films subject matter. The audience is not spoon-fed a bunch of pretentious psychobabble. The story is told with raw images and raw emotions. It is both a departure from the majority of science fiction cinema and a return to what the genre is capable of.The films mages are eloquently photographed using a combination of static and handheld camera. A beautiful color palette is used to communicate to the audience where they are in the time line. Cool greys and blacks for the Solaris station. Warm earth tones for the terrestrial  flashbacks. The emotions are that of a man who has lost his wife to suicide. He is then confronted with her apparent resurrection. This being the afore mentioned problem that was troubling the resident scientists of the station. It seems that every crewmember has their own `visitor'. The origin and purpose of which is unknown. Chris has to deal with facing a woman who looks and (almost) acts exactly like his deceased wife. On the surface it would appear he is being dealt a second chance. But he and his facsimile wife soon discover that this chance is fleeting when her true nature comes to the surface. The performances are superb all around. Mr. Clooney as Chris is called upon to display a wide range of emotions. He dose so with a subtle elegance that matches the rest of the films mood. All of  the supporting roles are played nicely as well. Jeremy Davies disjointed and appropriately odd ball character plays as a good harbinger to things to come. Ultimately the overall experience of `Solaris' is a satisfying one. I havnt any real complaints about the film. It in every way represents what I love about not only a good sci-fi movie, but good movies in general. I feel the film demands a patient audience, but the reward is worth the wait.

Review title: SF for the Blade Runner/2001 crowd... not necessarily for the Star Wars crowd
Review_body: First off, if you are looking for shoot 'em up, space ship flying through the stars, hunting aliens type of science fiction, don't even bother with this film. If you are looking for a Science Fiction film that explores the human condition in the way that Blade Runner, 2001: A Space Odyssey or Contact does, then this is right up your alley.This film is not about events and actions, it's about ideas and concepts. People looking for plot points to move them along will be bored to death with this film because most of the action of this film are those that will happen in your head. It is about people, desires, regrets and what we would be willing to do if we could have that one thing we cannot have back.Some people complain about the fact that Clooney's character of Chris does very little psychiatric work in this film. But, the truth of the matter is that his occupation is used more to propel his anti-faith views. I haven't seen it mentioned, but there is a reason why there are a lot of discussion about God, religion and faith in this film.Throughout the film, Chris questions and belittles Rheya's religious views, seeing the idea of putting stock in something that he sees as fantasy as being useless and just a crutch for people deluding themselves into a happiness based on illusion. Chris comes to realize that he would give up anything to be with Rheya, whether being with her is an illusion or not. His happiness depends on her, and he realizes that accepting what he needs is not a weakness -- as accepting faith is not a weakness -- it is simply a choice to fulfill one's life, whether it be real or illusion. And, as philosophers would argue, who can really say which is which?For those who want a science fiction film to make you think (like Blade Runner does), this film is it. With a tremendous cast, beautiful production design, excellent direction, and one of the best film scores in recent years (hats off to Cliff Martinez), I have no trouble recommending this film to anybody who is in the need of an intelligent, thought-provoking film.

Review title: a modern 2001: a boring space oddessy.
Review_body: Unlike most sci fi fans, I was incredibly bored out of my mind with 2001. I found it long and boring. Much like this film. George Clooney plays another bland character that has ruined his life or had it ruined by external forces. The plot is pretty much given away in the trailers and the ending is almost never in doubt. Unlike 2001, however, this movie hasn't been considered a marvel and advancement in sci fi picture making. Quite the opposite, people really hated this film and found it very derivative. While I can see why people would say that, it really isn't that bad. Disconnected from all they hype and reviews, this movie is boring yes, but mildly interesting. It is hysterical to me, that the documentary about the film on the DVD is more action packed than movie itself.   Still, if you can divorce yourself from any hopes of excitement, this movie will be fairly entertaining.

Review title: No SFX Needed for This Character- and Plot-Driven Gem!
Review_body: Several things must handshake well together in order for me to actually recommend it to people. You know what they are: an engaging plot, believable acting, creative cinematography, and a nice film score (or nice choice in music). The story truly was a bit eerie as the plot thickened and morphed. By the end of the film, I sensed my own paranoia as I put my own mind in the situation.All the characters really drew me in to their situations - the fact that there were so few main characters (including, the planet Solaris, which I consider a character) made it even better. The scenes were amazingly shot. Not every camera was set to the best framing - what film has *every* camera shot that tight - but I cheered the cinematographer when his name flashed on the screen (and later found out that Steve Soderbergh was the cinematographer after all).Within 10 minutes of the start of the movie (watching it at home) I searched for the film score, and now have a CD. The scoring blended seamlessly with the feature. But IMHO, I can see where some people can't embrace this tight film. Working behind the camera for a news organization, I've learned quickly that people in general don't like to sit through something that doesn't move, change, and develop quickly. And they tend to enjoy film scores with a faster beat, or even something with a more dramatic flair. The scoring by Cliff Martinez was magnificent, and any other type of scoring, or adding what I call "Bruckheimer beats" (music in films produced by Jerry Bruckheimer) would have destroyed it. Some people are uncomfortable with films that have lots of "air time," which allow one to think, feel, and allow all the aspects of a movie to surround the viewer and seep in. It lacks in testosterone scenes. While I enjoy those films as well, this one I thoroughly enjoyed and will watch over and over. But I would recommend them only to people who can not only appreciate a character-driven film that relies on plot rather than adrenaline, but also wants a movie that doesn't have to spell everything out for the viewer. Does a film-goer have to rely on getting all the answers, when we can make our own conclusions, based on our own life's experiences and personalities?

In 1936, the surrealist painter Renee Magritte exhibited his most famous painting, The Treachery of Images, in New York. The painting depicts a pipe (the kind one smokes from) along with the text, "This is not a pipe." I venture it takes the average person less than two minutes to get the joke: One is looking at a picture of a pipe, not the real object. Give the average person five minutes more, and s/he will understand the painter's underlying message: Can we ever know what's real, given that all we can ever know is what our minds can interpret from our senses, filtered by our beliefs? Solaris takes 99 ponderous minutes to convey the same message. The movie is a sleep-inducing metaphysical meditation on the topic, loosely wrapped in a weak narrative, with weaker characters. I applaud George Clooney (the psychologist) for attempting to escape his romantic leading man stereotype, but he didn't have the chops for such an interior role. The script isn't kind to his undead/unreal wife, either, whose lines seem to come from a sophomore film school student. The spartan aesthetic  the sterile spaceship, the constant hum of electrical and ventilation systems, and wandering, new-age pulses of sound  sets a pensive mood, but there's not that much to think about after you realize, halfway through the movie, what the theme is.

Review title: Let the steel drums carry you away.....
Review_body: As a sort of fan of the original, this was one of the few movies that nowadays I have bothered to go to see in the cinema. Having seen it once I wasn't overly impressed by the movie as a whole, but primarily by Steven Soderbergh's extraordinary photography of Natascha McElhone's lambent beauty.Since the film has made its way to satellite and cable, however, I discover that I cannot resist putting it on and watching it again, and allowing myself to be subsumed by the utterly tragic mood. The main contributor to this is Cliff Martinez's phenomenal score in which the constant thrumming of steel drums over an ethereal orchestra carries you through long exploratory shots of the luminous sea of Solaris, or eloquent silences between characters.Clooney and McElhone are very affecting as the, almost literally, "star-crossed lovers". Unfortunately I find the two Davi(e)ses somewhat detracting from the whole, with Jeremy's "Snow" a slacker whom it is difficult to believe would qualify to fly in space, and Viola's "Gordon" seems to be out of a rather more conventional "space alien" movie - in fact her performance more than a little resembles Yaphet Kotto's in the movie 'Alien'! Ulrich Tukur as Gibarian, however, is a wonderfully understated reminder of the original material's European origins.The one failing of this movie compared to its predecessor is Soderberg's inability to portray Solaris as a character in its own right, something Tarkowsky seemingly managed with ease.

Review title: In space, no one can hear you snore.
Review_body: One tag-line for this movie is "There are some places man is not ready to go," like into the theatre playing this movie. The other tag-line is "How far will you go for a second chance?" Apparently as far as death by boredom.This movie is about regret, consequences, and redemption. Regret for actually seeing it. Consequences, waste of an afternoon and money for the DVD rental. Redemption, none.According to the director, Steven Soderbergh, the movie concentrates on the love George Clooney's character feels for his dead wife. And how far he will go to be with her again. But all he did was take 15-20 minutes of useful story, and stretched it into a 90 minute movie by adding on 70 minutes of useless garbage. Also, it seems as though he ignored the enigma of the living planet Solaris.Where the whole story could have been made on an episode of the Outer Limits, only a part of the story was used into making a major snooze fest.

Review title: Nope, not an intelligent movie though it threatens at times...
Review_body: This is a handsomely-produced movies that forgot to get a script, good actors and just cribbed from 2001 a lot.With the right material and director, George Clooney is an engaging actor, but he was completely wrong for this movie.  And the fight over showing George's ass was probably the only way this movie could hope to get any publicity.  Deleting those scenes would not have mattered in the least.There were a few instances when the movie attempted to make a point, but, unfortunately, it did not work.Nice special effects though.

I give this movie 3 stars for the serenity it depicts. It was kinda relaxed to watch it.i had an OK time while it was on my screen. But it never came close to the bestrangening and tranquilizing weirdness of Tarkovskys movie Solyaris.Which is an all time masterpiece. I had the impression that this one, the Soderbergh version was only made because American's in general are unable to bear the Tarkovsky movie.To strange and unpredictable for them. Thus said we see immediately that all the originality is left out of this Cloony- Solaris version.A meager love story...and never coming close to the esoterically bestranening appearances of the Wife in the Tarkovsky film.Somehow Soderbergh needed his film 'to make sense'. and that's the greatest failure in this very meager version of Lem's book & Tarkovsky's masterpiece. And music composed on Propellorhead software , also does'nt do the trick !

That's right, it's absolutely remarkable that 8% of all viewers have given this movie 1/10 (at the time I wrote this). Nearly 1 in 10 people think this movie is as bad as movies get. Therefore, I think nearly 1 in 10 people are a waste of resources. This is not a great movie. And I can understand if somebody doesn't think it was a good movie. But among the worst ever made? That's insane. People are stupid.

I read the book by Stanislaw Lem just before getting the film, and there are of course elements of the story well explained in the book which were removed from the film - or simply too hard to pump into a film.The plot is the following, people in a space station above the planet Solaris receive "visitors", lifelike persons from their past, all dead already. The question of their nature, their origin, their purpose is key as they are not aggressive, not "aliens in disguise".George Clooney delivers a good performance and while the film takes us miles away from a typical SF movie into a psychological drama, a debate on reality, love even, I would say that the result is surprisingly good.Still enigmatic, the very nature of Solaris, the nature of the "visitors", only tends to find an explanation through metaphysical and religious terms. It opens a debate as well on "what is a person" and "what is the essence of a person", never quite a full answer in the film, nor in the book.

A top psychologist, the highly unconvincing George Clooney, is sent on a mission to restore order aboard a lonely space station where resurrected ghosts are haunting hapless crew members.What a load of nonsense. George Clooney, the incredibly shallow actor, has unfortunately been cast in the lead role and what a horrific job he does in this dire remake of a classic Science Fiction film. It is unbearable to watch, you can tell he is acting all along, there is never a moment when you do not think that this is the pretentious George Clooney. The whole thing is a wasted exercise, it never holds attention and is a sheer dive of a film which should never have seen the light of day.

Review title: Why would you do this to Tarkovsky?
Review_body: Andrei Tarkovsky's Solaris is a flawless and thoughtful masterpiece of cinema- this is, ummm, not that.That's all I'll say.

I dreaded seeing this movie.  Even though I find Steven Soderbergh one of the most interesting contemporary Hollywood directors, I don't find him particularly gifted or with an affinity for psychologically probing movies, at least since his 1989 movie "Sex, Lies and Videotape."  Indeed as he's settled into his career as a director Soderbergh has become primarily a competent stylist, and an uneven one at that.  His most celebrated movie, Traffic, is an almost shot-for-shot copy of a BBC television miniseries, and most of the changes Soderbergh introduces to Americanize the movie are not for the better.Thus the thought of this director taking the strange beauty of Andrei Tarkovsky's 1972 Russian science fiction art film and building a George Clooney vehicle around it only brought forth a sense of foreboding, that these Americans were surely biting off more than they could chew and would embarrass themselves -- and Hollywood by extension -- with a ridiculous effort.I'm surprised to report that in visiting Solaris Soderbergh has made his best movie, and arguably the best English-language science fiction movie since 2001: A Space Odyssey.In fact the only negative comment that leaps to mind minutes after leaving the theater is that Soderbergh's Solaris is perhaps a little too similar to Kubrick's masterpiece, and thus lacks the sense of awe, surprise and discovery that we look for in science fiction.  (Since precious few science fiction movies of the last 15 years contain any of these elements one is forced to measure Solaris against a theoretical mean rather than its contemporary competition.)Like 2001, Solaris is really a meditation on the human condition, in particular a consideration of the limits of what can be defined as the individual, as human, as sentient.  It is a simple, minimalist movie that doesn't have any interest in space opera, and conceives of action not as a matter of resolving conflict, but only as a necessity of making inevitable choices.  It's "Waiting for Godot" where Estragon and Vladimir are forced to flee the stage or perish at the end of the second act, where there is no option, as in Beckett, to simply ride out the calendar.  "There's no solution," says a character in Solaris, "there's only choices.  And unless you realize that, you're going to die here."  In Soderbergh's Solaris, the demand for solutions is a flaw, an artifact of the vain human ego that wants credit for "being smarter than them," as Viola Davis' character asserts early in the film.This is not a film that is going to please the average American moviegoer, both because of its slow (but certainly not dull) pace, its focus on the psychological, and its disinterest in the notions of heroism that drive the bland balance of our moviegoing fare.  The film is paced slow not because the director is trying to drive home a point.  It is paced such in order that the viewer has time to consider, speculate and imagine himself in the philosophical position of the characters on board the spacecraft.  Viewers who would rather not figure themselves into the equation are indeed going to have some extra time on their hands watching George Clooney toss and turn in his dreams at night.  Nevertheless this is simply his best performance on the big screen, the first one where he's able to use his limitations as an actor as part of his character rather than battle (however valiantly) against them.Solaris is not the most fun movie you are going to see this winter, but it might be the best.  It's certainly a welcome change of pace from the increasingly vulgar and stupid drivel that Hollywood tries to pass off as science fiction, and perhaps best of all it suggests that Steven Soderbergh may have a higher gear that he's ready to shift into as a director, able to produce films that stand tall in the broad context of film history, and not just against the diminished stature of his contemporary competitors.

Is it possible for anyone in Hollywood to create a movie from a book where they remain somewhat faithfull to the book? Lem had three living humans on the station above Solaris, Dr.Snow, Dr.Satorius and Kris Kelvin.I know the current rage is to have african americans portray anyone these PC directors think they ought - pretty soon we will have present day Hollywood portraying President Eisenhower by Ice T or Cube or Will Smith, but for the love of God, enough is enough. There was NO Dr.Gordon in the book, and I guess Soderbergh felt he might score some bonus minority points by having a Black Female added to the cast as the station chief and Physicist. I do not might in having black actors act in roles that were written for them, just as I would oppose Mel Gibson playing Dr.Martin Luther King. But in todays' America, to be even suspected of less then fanatical enthusiasm for multicultural Diversity and changing reality to fit the current state of Political Correctness, is a crime against nature. Secondly, although the director follows the book fairly loosely, he surgically removes any of the scientific speculation which was the entire point of the book. I know that most of Hollywood considers the average american to be an idiot, and to a large degree they are right, but if Soderbergh thought he might rope in current americana by denuding the picture of intelligence, boy was he in for a suprise. Most of the people left the cinema in an irritated daze, not understanding the movie even after it had been stripped of any intellectually challenging parts. Why even bother to state thatthe movie was made from a book when the only thing that the book and movie had in common was the Title and overall concept of a sentient ocean? Looking at this movie as an original work having nothing to do with Lem's book, it isn't that bad. Great soundtrack, great atmosphere and visuals, a fairly clever, if not mundane plot. I have mixed feelings about this movie. If only Soderbergh had the courage to stick to the book, it could have been a great movie.

This film has divided audiences, even in my own household; I thought it was really good, and my wife hated it and thought it was the most boring film she'd ever seen. So fired up was she that she ranted and raved incessantly for about an hour after we came out of the cinema. So what is the film at the centre of this debate? Well, it's is Steven Soderburgh's latest collaboration with George Clooney: a slow, meditative piece of filmmaking based on the seventies Russian sf classic Solyaris.The story involves Chris Kelvin (Clooney), a grieving psychiatrist, being called on to visit a space station orbiting a strange pink and blue planet (that looks remarkably like a human brain), where strange things have been happening to those on board. The planet is causing memories of the crew to become real living things, hence the strange behaviour and refusal of the crew to leave.When Kelvin arrives he is forced to confront his own feelings about his wife's suicide when he is given another chance to be with her. The story here is really secondary to the existential questions the movie poses, and the atmosphere and emotion that it tries to portray. I feel that for the most part the movie succeeds. It is certainly a brave experiment for Soderburgh and Clooney (last seen together with Oceans Eleven), and unfortunately has not been a great commercial success in the States (partly due to bad marketing). I fear that it will suffer the same fate here in the UK, where we want our Hollywood product loud, fast and manipulative. I think it may do well in Europe though, as it is more akin to the French style of filmmaking, where more stress is on dialogue and philosophy than on all out action.

When I first heard of Solaris, I expected very little.  Soon after, I never heard anyone speak of it again.  Then, I watched the trailer one day and realized just how interesting the premise seemed.  Yet I still had no idea what to expect when I sat down to watch the movie.What I got went far beyond my expectations.  Solaris is truly a "mind-bending" picture.  It is the type of motion picture that does not leave your mind soon after you have watched it.  It has a very haunting, yet beautiful quality that sends chills up your spine.  The score also adds to the altogether strange mood of the movie.And that in itself sums up Solaris.  It is a strange movie.  So, if you don't like to think or if you're looking for large amounts of action, don't watch this movie.  And, yes, it is quite slow, but it is only as boring as you make it. I challenge you to submerge your mind in the movie and let it affect your mind.  Think about what is said and think about what you see. I dare you NOT to be affected in some way.Final grade: B+

A gathering of geniuses: Stanislaw Lem, Andrei Tarkovsky, Steven Soderbergh and James Cameron. Although I admire Tarkovsky, Soderbergh and Cameron have made a film that is better than the original and that is almost a miracle. Everything here is perfect - I consider this film the best work of Soderbergh and Cameron and I doubt they will surpass what they did here in the future. Tarkovsky is not capable of making a bad film so imagine how hard it is to surpass him - and that has happened here.

What a waste of film, after only 45 min. I walked ot of the theatre with my wife. I have never walked out of a movie before! If I had known that this was a stupid sci-fi I would have never went to this garbage, my wife and i would have rather seen Harry Potter than this. The preview for the film shows something more like a romance thriller, not a space flick. Unless you liked films like Mission to Mars or 2001, avoid this crap.

Review title: Another poor copy by Soderbergh and Clooney
Review_body: What is Soderbergh up to? A fine individual film-maker is now reduced to making inept remakes of good films - Oceans Eleven and now Solaris. Solaris isn't a bad film, just rather dull, with the two main characters incredibly wooden. George Clooney is unconvincing as the psychologist summoned to investigate the space station's mysteries, and Natascha McElhone looks beautiful, whether smiling, bewildered or distressed - but expresses only those three emotions and says little of consequence.  The visuals of space are as good as I have seen but by the (ambiguous) end of the film the impression is left that the director was more interested in the visuals than the plot, despite the legacy of Lem's novel and Tarkovsky's film - both superb. A big disappointment.

Review title: A Solaris (2002) review from a Tarkovsky fan
Review_body: I can't think of another person who admires Andrei Tarkovsky more than I. For me, he was a seer, a poet, a true artist. When I think of truly gifted filmmakers, I only think of two: Tarkovsky and Bergman, and in my opinion, Tarkovsky has ... no ... equal. When I heard that they were making another film version of Solaris, I could not even articulate my disdain. How can they take a perfectly good film, albeit, with limited special effects, by the greatest filmmaker of all time, and turn it into a Hollywood remake. Imagine Ivan's Childhood remade by Steven Spielberg, or Stalker as conceived by David Fincher. In essence, I believe that good films should never be remade, only bad ones... I could only conceive of Solaris as directed by Soderbergh, if he actually had the decency to make his own film, rather than remake the Tarkovsky version. I became more receptive before the release of Solaris when I understood that Soderbergh came across the story only through the Tarkovsky version, but by utilizing the plot structure through the original book by Stanislaw Lem. Why should I have disdain, I thought, it wasn't Tarkovsky's idea in the first place. Today, Soderbergh's film was released in my area, and I approached it without any preconceived emotions. This is what I thought: What results from Steven Soderbergh's Solaris is not necessarily a story, but really, a thought-provoking character that analyzes our drive for what's missing from our lives, no matter how closely it can be replicated. Is space travel a way of exploring worlds, or is it a way for us to "create mirrors" as one scientist states in the movie. Will we find anything that fills our need, or tells us more about ourselves? Solaris analyzes these questions. The thing that I admire about this version of Solaris is that it presents itself without fanfare, or action sequences, or unnecessary special effects. It may be classified as a science fiction film, but it's far from any Hollywood science fiction film you could conceive of. It's a very minimalist film, as demonstrated by the sequences where scientist Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) roams the corridors of the spaceship that he journeys to in the film. The sea of the planet that the ship orbits around takes memories and creates replicas of lost wives, brothers, friends, etc... Why it does this is never really explained. Sometimes the experience gives us more than any need from us to explain it. When a group of astronauts journeys to Mars in Ray Bradbury's The Martian Chronicles, only to discover their lost relatives, they can only conceive that, without skepticism, that they've been sent to heaven. It's hard to let go of the past once it's been returned to us, since everyone has something, or someone, that's so precious to us, but has been lost. So, for an initial reaction, I give my highest praise to Soderbergh and Cameron for making a film that flies in the face of the Hollywood excess I thought it would become. I give praise to this film, not from the standpoint of a Tarkovsky fan, but as a seeker.

Review title: Sci Fi For Thinking Adults Only
