Review title: Oh, my god! This is terrible/depressing/confusing...
Review_body: I must have done a lot of horrible things in my previous life to deserve this horrible movie. People say the silent scenes in the movie were dreadful, but compared to the boring conversations, it's really nothing. Let me just tell you this: after seeing solaris, I really wanted to kill myself.

Review title: My cat napped in front of the TV and I didn't care
Review_body: I'm shocked both George Clooney and Steven Soderbergh were involved with this garbage. This is one of the top ten worst films I have ever seen. It was the most boring, incoherent garbage I've had the misfortune to witness. Like I said, my cat jumped in front of my television and I didn't even care that I couldn't see half the screen. That's how much I didn't care about this film! The plot is interesting, but the delivery and super-slow paced script ruined it. All these questions the characters kept asking, (over and over and over!) I didn't know the answers to and couldn't care less about them. This movie turned what was apparently a great novel into a boring space soap opera. No, I take that back, a soap opera is much better than this. I'd watch old episodes of General Hospital that this snooze-fest. I heard that this film got a rare "F" from Cinemascore, and it deserved it! Avoid this one at all costs!

Review title: Moody drama with Lem's 'Solaris' as background
Review_body: A lot of people say that this film covers just two pages of Lem's book or that compared to Russian 'Solyaris' it lacks substance and they're probably right. But these reviews are based on comparisons. I want to know if Soderberg's 'Solaris' is good in it's own right, not from any perspective.The whole film really revolves around it's chilled, delicate mood. The sense of loneliness of the Solaris station, the bewilderment of it's crew and the strange things that happen there are presented by clean, steady pictures and narrated by one of the most original soundtracks I've ever heard. George Clooney gives a great performance so as Natascha McElhone, cast perfectly for the role of Rheya. Sometimes she has this extreme, edgy, almost hypnotic look and a penetrating glance that can send shivers down your spine. She's absolutely fascinating. Jeremy Davies also plays very well his role of Snow.'Solaris' is not perfect, but is well put together and does a good job of keeping you in a confused and shaken state.

Review title: A little too deep for most of us (I give it a 10)
Review_body: There weren't enough loud noises. Most people wouldn't know when or if they should be scared or happy. Basically, this needed to be a cheap science fiction novel on screen to get more people to like it. Good acting and beautiful sets just doesn't do it for most of us.

Review title: Don't waste your time ... rent the original
Review_body: I had high hopes for this movie. I had hoped to find a good version of Stanislaw Lem's novel. I had hoped to see a good version of the original movie, with up-to-date special effects. And, strangely enough, I had even hoped to be able to see a performance by George Clooney that could be called "good" (actually, I really just hoped for "watchable").My hopes were dashed on all counts. I guess Soderbergh figures he's a bigger name than Lem or Tarkovsky, and so all the groundwork they laid is inconsequential. This was a very bad film. We're talking "Highlander 2" bad here. Here's another film that makes that most unforgivable of errors in science fiction, as it made it all pretty damn boring. Jeremy Davies and Viola Davis are the only ones who don't seem to have phoned in their performances, though with this stodgy script, there isn't all that much difference in anyone's acting.Rent the original 1972 movie. That's one of the best science fiction movies of all time, right up there with 2001. Get past the subtitles and watch a vastly superior and much more intelligent science fiction opus than anything George Clooney could have possibly acted in.

Review title: .....did I just dream this? Hell I know I liked it whatever!
Review_body: Steven Soderbergh, it seems to me, can direct just about anything (book, play or just an interesting idea) and make the best of what it has to offer. Solaris has a lot to say and maybe a little too much for some us. It is never just entertainment, it has much more to offer. Sometime ago I read an article about dream states. The main idea of this article was that we are all of us living in a dream; and all living matter is in a dream state peculiar to it's own species and indeed peculiar to each individual within that species. Something of this idea is being worked out in Solaris. Death does not end the existence of an individual but simply transfers him or her to a different dream state. One of the questions which this raises (if you accept the validity of the 'dream' state idea) is which of these dream states may, with authority, consider itself to be the ascendant state; is any of these states entitled to consider itself the one which is the sole arbiter of truth regarding the nature of existence. Solaris, somewhere out there - where doesn't matter, is a planet which has the power to allow individuals in different states of 'being' to see and contact one another with all the attendant confusion that this obviously brings to all parties on both sides of the existence/dream barrier. This moves on to pose many more questions and dilemmas e.g. does time continue upon changing states? If it does is it synchronous with all other dream states? Etc. This film isn't really just a sci-fi flick or for that matter, a romance it's in a category that's other than that. Decide for yourself what and where it is. Soderberg floats my boat. Always has. If you're a fan too this one's for you.

Review title: Waiting to be entertained? You're missing the point.
Review_body: There's an old maxim about music that goes: "All music is sound, but not all sound is music." In a way, what this says is: one should remember the intent of something before judging its worth. In the case of cinema, it can be re-written as, "All movies are films, but not all films are movies." By this, I point to the distinction of 'movie' as a piece of filmed entertainment and 'film' as a work intended more as a creative expression with less emphasis on entertainment value. So enters Solaris.Firstly, Solaris is not a re-make of the Tarkovsky film. It is merely another interpretation of the original novel. Comparing the two films is like comparing two brothers, not a father and a son. This may seem incidental but is important when justifying the originality of each film and the lineage. Soderbergh's Solaris is, to me at least, a pure meditation on loss. It is slow but only so slow as to let the viewer react to the events, place them in their own lives, tally their effects and then place themselves back into the film. It pulses slowly and quite intentionally. To call it boring is merely to admit a lack of connection with it.Solaris is a work so specifically personal that it either destroys you or bounces off like a ping-pong ball with little ado. This is probably why Solaris is consistently either the most profound film many have seen or the most boring film many have seen. Either reaction is justified because what you get out of the film really depends on what you bring into the film.If you've ever had anyone close to you die in a way that left a mass of unresolved issues, this film addresses what is likely your greatest fantasy: what if they could come back? If you have had a great love that simply ended and you were never sure why, the film presents an allegory for what it would be like to have that again. If you live in dreams of a former life and the memories of a greater happiness in your past, the film is a vicarious journey back. What differentiates this from other films in a similar vein is that it takes place in the present. There is no time traveling involved. Characters are not transported back to their childhood to witness exactly what their past was like as a complete and entire world. It operates in reverse by sending a manifestation of the past into the brutal light of the present. This is what makes Solaris' take on remorse and lament so profound.Solaris doesn't so much celebrate fantastical second chances in life as it does brutally beg the truth of the past from the cradle of the present. Many lament the past as a greater time because it is a closed case. Where the present breeds uncertainty for the future, the past is a set, stable environment. We can choose to remember only the best qualities of someone and this inevitably snowballs into a perfect version of that person living exclusively in our own private past. Solaris brings such a person back from the dead and forces its lead character to remember why they died in the first place (sorry for being vague, trying not to be a plot spoiler.) It is not a rose-colored reality but a brutal reminder.If you can't relate to anything like this, well, this film probably just isn't for you. If you can relate to it, Solaris could send you on a pretty intense roller-coaster of emotions.I also feel that Soderbergh's Solaris is a stylistic masterpiece. Beautiful, original camera-work, set design, etc. Cliff Martinez's soundtrack is even better than his work on the film Traffic. Aside from my own personal emotional reaction to the film, I also feel it is a solid, unique piece of film-making and worth seeing.

Review title: What if the Creator is me
Review_body: --Spoilers below--The popular theme of `I am God' is taken to extremes in Solaris. The movie depicts a world built upon a nihilistic point-of-view. In the absence of objective truth, humans are left with only their subjective perceptions and the entire life experience becomes an object of humanistic creation. Therefore, human existence lies within boundaries of the greatest aspirations and the basest desires, yet; the existence is constrained by the finite capacity of the human mind. The philosophy can be summarized as, `We cannot create anything greater than ourselves.'The corporeal visitors in Solaris come from the memories of a human host. Solaris seems to analyze dreams during sleep then creates the visitors based on those dreams and memories. The central character, Dr. Kelvin, experiences the Solaris effect via the visitation of his `resurrected' wife. She has been dead for years but Solaris creates her exactly as he remembers her-and therein lays the rub. As an extension of his memory she is more automaton than human. The familiarity of her physical appearance and social responses are comforting and intoxicating. Yet the overall experience lacks the lightness of spontaneity and serendipity. Dr. Kelvin becomes trapped in a `heaven' of his own creation.There are many other themes depicted in the movie related too this central theme. If you enjoy movies that require the audience to feel and think about what they feel--then see this movie.Best Regards, Darth87 December 2002

Review title: Not bad, not bad at all (minor spoilers)
Review_body: I don't understand the other viewers' comments saying this was a horrible film. Yes, I was expecting more and for the story to go deeper than it did. Yes, there was some confusing plot elements (who was Gordon's visitor? how did the other scientist die? what happened to the security team that visited? what drugs was Snow on?!) that become even more confusing when you look at the filming script available online which diverges greatly from what finally appeared on screen. Despite that, the film raises some interesting questions about what would happen if our memories became embodied and developed their own consciousness...do they have a separate existence outside of our mind? Can they grow or develop beyond the confines of our perception of the past? The film could have been much more and although people here say it was boring, I was dying for another 1/2 hour to go more deeply into some issues...things were wrapped up too quickly and neatly for my tastes. Guess I'll be hunting for the original Russian film next!Parting words: Go see the film and make up your own mind. Considering how many really awful movies are made (Pluto Nash, The Hot Chick, Sorority Boys, etc.) calling this a "horrible film" is completely unwarranted. It may not be a "10" but it won't be a waste of your time.

this movie was a piece of crap, absolutely terrible. what a waste of my time.i tried paying attention to it but the horrific cinematography annoyed me way too much. the story was too confusing. its one of those films that gives you 1 hour and 30 mins of stupid, confusing, crap and in the last 10 minutes, tries to explain everything to you. but fails miserably.i expected more from an Oscar winning director, who directed some of my favorite films, oceans 11-13, Erin brockavich, and of course, traffic(my fav).i cant really say much more for a movie that makes no sense, thats why i tried watching it again, but i got nothing out of it. i thing people are being very generous with giving it a rating of 6 out of 10. i give it a 2 for creativity.

Review title: Precise, mindnumbing, gutsy and utterly beautiful. A Masterpiece.
Review_body: I'll make this short.Solaris is one of those movies that just don't come along very often. It's a masterpiece for which I have a deep respect.As a movie it's just amazing. The cinematography (by Soderbergh himself) is wonderfully subdued, but perfectly precise. The music made my heart hit my throat as the shuttle arrived at the Prometheus. The lighting... wow.Too bad this movie will tank because people are stupid.Thank you Soderbergh. Thank you Cameron.

Review title: Solaris is a disappointment for me
Review_body:
I feel Natascha McElhone (Rheya) just wasn't convincing in herrole.  Natascha McElhone is a very, very fine actress, but I feel shewas miscast for the part.  It doesn't make sense why GeorgeClooney's character, Kelvin, would feel the way he does aboutRheya.  I certainly did not feel that way, and for the movie to work,McElhone has to give the audience emotional reason for Kelvin tofeel the way he does.  Well, McElhone did not do it, for me anyway.Too bad, everything else the movie has is a 10!  That is; the actingof George Clooney, Viola Davis, and Jeremy Davies is superb, theSteven Soderbergh direction is first rate .  .  it does not get anybetter, the ethereal feel to the movie was right on with the story lineand it is wonderful, the script was the best, and so on, and so on. 
I also did not care for the nudity in the film, I feel it takes away fromthe movies' integrity.  Otherwise a 10 rating, I give it a 5.  Too bad, I really wanted to likethis film.

Watched this movie last night and it reminded me of the wee toy that used to dangle above my bed when I was a baby. Both are wooden and watching them made me yawn.If you like very soothing soundtracks then this might become one of your favourite movies. If you like actors who have presence, dialogue that makes sense or a plot that is at all interesting then it most certainly won't.My friend gave me this to watch 'cos he said he didn't understand it. That's because there's nothing to understand. It's a real excuse for sci-fi, and is really a supernatural love story set on a spaceship. The only problem with it is that to make a love story work you need to empathise with the characters and care about what happens to them. And in this movie you simply don't.Make your own mind up by all means, but don't expect 2001 or you'll be even more disappointed than me.

Review title: magnificent, literate film making for adults
Review_body: Magnificent! Soderbergh and Clooney have produced a literate, cerebral, adult film exploring the nature of consciousness, faith, reason, reality and love.In a career best performance, Clooney gives a deep and subtle portrayal of a man emotionally laid bare by the death and seeming resurrection of his wife played by Natascha McElhone.Soderbergh has deliberately gone for a gloomy, moody, restrained feel - think Seven with the rain but without the violence - and the lack of music to drive the plot along adds to the stark and brooding atmosphere. This is space as it probably really is - lonely, silent, exhilerating and foreboding.And talking of plot drivers, Soderbergh has obviously taken lessons from producer Jim Cameron on how to succinctly tell your story in what is little over an hour and a half, which makes a refreshing change from the usual two hour plus bloat-ware that usually takes up our screens.If there's one fly in this otherwise superbly made tonic, it's Jeremy Davies' tech/geek boy character. A cliched, hackneyed, attention- seeking performance of every over-mannered oddball that's ever been committed to celluloid.Make no mistake. We should be thankful to the filmic gods for the pairing of Soderbergh and Clooney for with fim making like this, they've proved they're on top of their game and there's room in corporate Hollywood for intelligent, measured, adult movies. Long may their reign continue.

Review title: Not exactly like the original - but nevertheless worth watching
Review_body: This movie tries to be faithful to the Russian original from 1972 (based on the story by Stanislaw Lem). The story is nearly the same - an astronaut is asked to find out what has happened on a space station that orbits the planet Solaris. As soon as he arrives on the station, he is confronted with unbelievable events that make him question reality. While Andrej Tarkowsky's version was a pure art film, with long shot sequences and a meditative touch, Sonderbergh speeds up the storytelling a lot. He focuses on the issue of a lost love, and gives the story a different outcome concerning that point. Nevertheless, he still uses some of Tarkowsky's filming techniques, like extended tracking shots and the direct glance of actors into the camera. If you like to see a film that puts up more questions than it answers, then see Solaris by Sonderbergh. If you approach it with an open mind, you'll enjoy it. Then you should give the original a try.

'Solaris' does get lots of things right. It faithfully recreates the cold, lonely, brooding atmosphere of the remote space station, rendered in cold colours, bare metal and harsh, industrial background noise. The characters are well played with what little dialogue there is. The soundtrack is subtle and complements the feel of the film. The alien planet is beautifully rendered, in fact it's visually the most colourful and complex thing in the whole film, with pulsating colours and strange, wispy cloud formations.The reason 'Solaris' probably invokes such strong reactions is that it doesn't insult the intelligence with explanations, but leaves the viewer to fill in the gaps, of which there are plenty.My main criticism of it (as a 'mainstream art-house' film) is that it is possibly a little too slick. Everything about it is visually perfect, from the planet itself to the gratuitous, crowd-pleasing Clooney butt sequence. I would prefer to have seen a little 'Alien' style grubbiness, given the dysfunction of all the film's characters. This is scant criticism for such an ambitious project and I think Soderbergh has struck a happy medium between philosophical musing and a good old-fashioned love storyI also found that the sparseness of the film doesn't leave much to be savoured on subsequent viewings.Open your mind. 6/10

I guess the rule these days are, if you're going to remake a film, make sure it's clever and it looks good. It's hard to argue with this version of Solaris on either grounds.The plot is not a direct copy of the original, which may or may not be more or less accurate as I haven't yet read the book, suggesting that Soderbergh may have interpreted the story in his own way. He proves that he's clever and can write a good story, though this version seems to provide the reader with more "what if?" details whereas the original seems to allow the viewer to ask these questions on his or her own.Maybe we are getting dumber these days ... remakes don't seem as smart as their originals.Soderbergh (as Peter Andrews) also shoots one heck of a film. In fact, I didn't know that Andrews and Soderbergh were one in the same until I saw the credits for Solaris and thought I'd seen his shooting style before. Sure enough, he also shot Ocean's Twelve, which in my opinion might be one of the more beautifully shot American films in recent days. Too bad the movie was typical Hollywood fare. It was clever and looked good. Of course I liked the original Ocean's Eleven better as well.So, while I don't think I'll be watching this update over and over again looking for new meaning as I have the original, this film made an excellent Saturday-afternoon-on-the-couch-view-once-veg-out flick, and it's finally inspired me to read the book.The original? I'm still somewhat speechless about it. See it for yourself, struggle with the meaning. Think about what you might do.Just make sure to see the original!!!

The first time I saw this movie, I hated it. I initially gave it a 4/10 in here on IMDb. The fact that I had read Stanislaw Lem's novel prior to viewing Steven's cinematographic version led me to be quite "enraged" at the various modifications made in the overall story. I must say that I was expecting a "typical" sci-fi movie and that I wasn't aiming for a love story in the first place.The second time, I enjoyed it. I changed my note to 6/10. After reading the book again in between both viewings of the film, I realized that this movie had been made this way willingly and not by mistake. I also realized that although it was different from the book in many ways ( including Solaris's appearance ), it was digging deeper into the psychological aspect of the characters than I had previously thought. Even Lem had not been able to do that in such a way.The third time, I simply loved it. I finally gave it 8/10 ( which is outstanding to me ). Like many people in here, I must have been distracted by the fact that George Clooney is in it, since he is a very famous actor and sometimes acted in horrible movies ( Batman ). I came to realize that Clooney truly outdid himself in Solaris and that all the other actors are putting an amazing performance as well. The cinematography is so beautifully done that no one can truly enjoy it through a single viewing. The soundtrack is perhaps the thing I've missed the most while I first saw this great piece of filmatography. The music is an actor itself - it remains the same, yet it changes its shape, color and tone, following the emotions represented by the images it accompanies. There is something in Soderbergh's vision of Solaris that is more otherworldly than all the sci-fi movies. Even Stanislaw Lem's original Solaris sometimes fails to describe, even with words, something similar to Steven's Solaris. Because of this, I believe Solaris not only is different - it stands alone from both the older adaptation and the book itself. It's something else.Clooney's performance which I initially saw as empty and lacking true emotion for a "sci-fi romance" turned out to be exactly what I just said - but in a good way. Kelvin, the character played by Clooney, is an empty shell. He has no reason to enjoy life. All that is dear to him is lost. He has no beliefs, no dreams, no hope. He comes to Solaris not as an explorer about to discover another planet with an open mind ready to plunge into the unknown with intellectual avidity, but as a professional doing his work as a psychologist, not even caring about Solaris. His love for what he believes is his loved one is not true love for it died with him on Earth. All that he cares about is the physical presence of his girlfriend and not her as a whole. In this perspective, he is indeed acting as an empty man with no real emotions and thus, he accomplishes something very few actors can actually do.This movie will always have its detractors for a reason that is also a paradox: it's the complexity of the movie that makes it simple looking to most. Many people fall in love without asking themselves what love truly is. They can live this way for a lifetime and enjoy life without problems. Solaris, however, explores love in a deeper, darker way and those who are not able to see complexity and imperfection through love will not understand the many scenes in this movie involving Kelvin and Rheya. What is love? Is it being one through sexual contact? Is it sharing thoughts, emotions and words with our mate? Or is it something else, something we have yet to discover? Most people disliked this movie because of its lack of usual science fiction elements - aliens, for example. The funny thing is that they are making the same mistake Kelvin does while not figuring out what Solaris truly is. It's all there. We, the human beings, are the aliens, for we do not even know who we truly are and what we are capable of. Kelvin cannot see Solaris in a way other than as a planet just like many people cannot see this film as something that is other than a sci-fi movie.With this in mind, I encourage you to view Solaris at least twice in a lifetime. Who knows, perhaps will you see this movie in a new light next time you see it - a purple and pink light, that is. ;)

I'd wager that most Sci-Fi fans won't like this movie, because while it IS a Sci-Fi, it's NOT a Sci-Fi. It's also a profound psychological exploration, a moving love story, and the jewel of this film is cleverly disguised in the metaphor of the story. When I first saw this movie, I didn't really like it. On a surface level, as merely a "sci-fi film", I thought it was slow and didn't make any sense. But on my 3rd viewing of this film just recently, the light bulb went on and suddenly it makes sense. This is now one of my favorite films of all time, a masterpiece. Icing on the cake that the acting in this film is superb, particularly by Natascha McElhone. Kudos to Steven Soderbergh for the courage to make this movie despite probably knowing that the underlying story would probably be lost by most of the audience... at least the first time around. I'm really glad I gave it another chance with an open mind. TRY to make sense out of this movie. If you get it, you'll GET IT.

No spoilers...I have the urge to go off on a tangent about the fact that Lem's novel Solaris was written BEFORE 2001: A Space Odyssey so that people might think beyond the basic, but instead I'll just get to the movie.As for this version of the story itself, alas it's missing something.  Like motivation for Kelvin's actions.  Whether it is the screenplay's fault, or if Kelvin's motivations are edited out, his whole demeanor is not convincing from the limited backstory we are given to begin with.  Add to that the sloppiness of subplots left hanging (mentioned quite well in other comments) and you are left with something that *could* have been great, or even good but which just feels empty.  Clooney's work is very good for what he has to work with, and Jeremy Davies is quite together for the not-all-together Snow.  But again, with a flawed production there is only so much they can do.3 out of 10.

Review title: I can't believe I stayed awake.
Review_body:
No spoilers, It is hard to spoil something that is already rotten. 
All I could think is. "Wow, I bet George regrets doing this one."  I am generally a fan of George Clooney, in fact O Brother, Where Art Thou? has got to be one of my favorite movies of all time and Oceans 11 was an entertaining movie by the same Director/Actor, But this flick stunk.I would comment more on the movie but it wasn't really memorable.

The more I see this movie the more I love it. The best DVD  buy, can`t stop watching. The music, the atmosphere, the story jjust does not leave you after you watch it. You`ll find yourself thinking about it and wanting to see it again and again. And every time I seem to draw a different conclusion. No need to say more...

Review title: Slow, thoughtful, stunning, but not for the action freak.
Review_body: I am a total sci-fi freak so judge this text with that in mind. Being a sci-fi freak i am constantly looking for new deep explorations of future human society and technique. The ones that affect me are really rare these days. This one did.This is a film for the more deep-minded SCI-FI fans. If you are looking for a swift action flick, just forget about this one. The only blood you'll see is the trails of earlier happenings leading up to the events of this film. The slow, moody pace talks to them who likes to make journeys in the mind and not deep down some robot infested spacehulk.So what are the keepings of this film? Well... First of all the music was awesome. It gave the film the perfect framing and together with the "outdoor" scenes it created one of the most stunning sci-fi experiences you will ever get. Guaranteed.The science/technique (as in sci-fi) in this film is secondary, which is rare in sci-fi today, the film is almost completely held up by the explorations of human psychology.The cast really perform a very fine job with this one here. I have always avoided everything with "Clooney" on the front but this has made me reconsider although he is still far down on my list. Snow and Helen are perfectly casted. Where have they dug up these two anyways?I wish i would have seen this at a movie theater. The good thing was that i could rewind and see the scene where the shuttle arrives at the space station as many times that i wanted. Awesome feeling! The scenery is just too much for a man who lives to enjoy the few moments of true science fiction.Lean back, have a beer, turn the volume up and drift away - in space and in your brain...

Heaven.  No, not the feeling that I got when I came out of the movie, but the overall theme for me.  But even though I did not feel heaven, I did find myself provoked to ask many questions, listen to many answers, and ponder them both.  Surprisingly this movie is gripping, especially with all the warnings people have put out to the impatient about being bored.  In comparison to many of the action packed crap put out today that is utterly more boring with their fiber thin plots and ambiguous reasons for creation this movie rises above the rest although it admittedly has a more methodical pace than most films, and I liked that.  It gave me time to appreciate the film before the credits rolled.The acting was superb, just superb around everything else.  A key line for me was paraphrased here, "There are no answers, just choices."  I was impressed and bought into Jeremy Davies character of Snow too, which may sound puzzling to many of you as it seems the majority feels he was an annoyance but I liked him.  Oh yeah, and Clooney and Mchelone were excellent as well, but I think there performances speak for themselves.Another thing that is almost necessary for a film to become one of my favorites is atmosphere, and this movie has it like a five star restaurant. There is just this feeling that is in the air, like it has jumped off screen and into the theater.  The ideas that are contained in this film, interpreted in any opinion, are truly refreshing and purely amazing from any point of view.  I would have to say as a gauge, if you liked AI there are a lot of similarities that would increase your chances of enjoying this movie as well.Not everyone feels this way, but the religious overtones standout in the film for me.  Whether it was intentional or not, or whether I added most of the overtones myself the planet Solaris itself carries more than just scientific weight.  And still more, there is a thoroughly convincing and deep character study about human relationships and the need for communication.  I especially enjoyed the scene where Clooney has a flashback of his wife and himself walking down the street, there was just something hauntingly emotional about it.  Steven Soderbergh should be commended, AGAIN!! for his continued drive to express something and his ability to make us think.  His vision and talent to the art form of film is something to be cherished.  I also found Cliff Martinez's score to capture each scene exquisitely and his music to be emotionally resounding.  Look for his next great score in Narc and his last great one in Traffic.And does anyone have a clue about the doorknob on the train?

Review title: a work of art on it's own
Review_body: First off I'll say I'm a huge fan of the original Solaris and I was horrified to hear it was being remade.  Especially with the names Soderbergh and Cameron attached.  So it was with great hesitation that I saw this one. This film surpassed my expectations perhaps more than anything I've ever seen.  It's not so much a remake as a reinterpretation.  Aside from Out of Sight, this is perhaps the finest acting I've ever seen from George Clooney who until today have never been the biggest fan of.  Jeremy Davies is fantastic, and completly steals every scene he appears in.  Natascha McElhone is perfect in her role and has just the right amounts of sexiness, mystery, and creepiness to her performance.  The score  and cinematography are both excellent.  And perhaps most importantly (to me at least) they didn't go ga-ga with the special effects and sets. Granted, most people in the theater didn't appear to agree.  Several people walked out.  I blame this mainly on the way the movie was marketed. Think of Solaris as more of an "indie" movie.  It's not for everyone.  If you're expecting a mindless space adventure this isn't for you.  This is a very quite film.  There are times when there is no talking for several minutes at a stretch. If you like having everything spelled out and tied up in a neat bow as the end credits roll then this isn't for you.  This is defintely a thinking mans movie...one that will stay in your mind for a while at least.  10/10

If you see only one movie this millennium, this should be it. The premise is unprecedented; the execution is exemplary; the undertones are overwhelming. If this sounds like the type of movie you would like, free free to watch it (unless you live in America).

Review title: Mis-marketed, misunderstood -- don't believe the snype, it's one of Soderbergh's best
Review_body: It's weird! It's slow! It was badly marketed with two different messages, as, A: A spooky sci-fi film! and B: A romantic love story! Problem: it is both those things, but at the same time -- you know, like a Reese's Peanut Butter Cup. No wonder no one saw it, and the few who did were bitterly disappointed. What Solaris is, is a brilliant and moody art film that uses sci-fi and romance clichés (A, something bad is happening in a far off space station; B, I miss my dead wife so much my life is empty without her) to weave a profound and fascinating parable of how people create the realities they believe in, and how that leads to a (chosen, not inflicted) life of suffering, a cross to opt to bear. Stanislaw Lem, who wrote the book in the 1960s and who was profoundly influenced by quantum theory, has written that he didn't want to see this version because it so much focused on the love story between Rheya and Kelvin, but that just seems completely misguided. Why would the theories he is talking about not address love and emotion? These -- like reality, consciousness, space, time -- are among of the defining forces of human existence, and they are perfectly at home among these more expected sci-fi concepts. Indeed, the parallels drawn between the love/sci-fi genres are what make this film such a brilliant, unusual and engaging endeavor.Here's hoping Soderbergh releases an extended director's cut, with more of everything in it (including the enthralling footage of the planet and station, together with Cliff Martinez's beautiful score). He wanted it to be short; understandable, but it would work much longer as well.

Tarkovsky's adaptation of Lem's novel takes quite a few liberties, jettisoning, for instance, the brilliant satirical elements and re-creating in its own potent terms the story's fascinating strangeness.  But Tarkovsky does remain true to the novel's central sci-fi premise: that life elsewhere in the universe may have evolved along lines so different from life on Earth that we could never fathom it.  Lem's novel, then, is an extraordinary rebuttal of all the ridiculous, anthropomorphic sci-fi scenarios in which aliens appear as strangely familiar humanoids (often demanding to be taken to some leader, in English). The new Solaris strats from the original in a far more fundamental way than Tarkovsky did, shifting the focus from the mind-bending sci-fi premise to something far more predictable and far less interesting: a rather conventional tale (told largely through flashbacks) of love, regret, and redemption.  Instead of Lem's world-wide sentient ocean, we get a few shots of some neon clouds--and virtually no explanation at all of what Solaris is.  In fact, Solaris itself becomes so peripheral to the story that one almost wonders why the filmmakers even bothered to use the name. The film will probably come as a major disappointment to fans of the original (or of the earlier film version, with its unique `Tarkovskyan' style and atmosphere).  It will also disappoint the casual cineplex viewer who expects that since Cameron's name is linked with the project that it must be some rip-roaring rollercoaster ride rather along the lines of another Aliens or Terminator II.  (Thus "miss...miss...")  Yes, the film's quite slow, but the slowness is not enigmatic and compelling as in Tarkovsky; it's mostly boring and often unimaginative.  And the performances certainly do not redeem the picture.  One in particular (the `dude' who plays Snow) is almost fascinating in its sheer badness. The difference between Lem (and Tarkovsky) and the new version is nowhere more apparent (or disappointing) than in the ending. In place of the fathomless ambiguities of the novel's conclusion (`I persisted in the faith that the time of cruel miracles was not past'), we get a rather saccharine, allegorical happy ending.  `Cruel miracles': no, there's nothing remotely to compare with that.  The shift toward allegory is strongly reinforced by an iconic (and rather pedestrian) visual allusion to Michelangelo.  At the same time, I suppose, one could see the scene as an allusion to Kubrick's `Star-Child'.  Throughout, the film's visual style and sudden fits of Ligeti-like music owe much more to 2001 than to anything in Tarkovsky--and to say that the invited comparison is not in the newer film's favor is a bit of an understatement. The filmmakers seem to depend on the beautiful stars to carry the viewer's interest, in lieu of the braintwisting thematic substance of the original(s).   Yes, I enjoyed watching Natascha McElhone's high-cheekboned face--in fact the main reason I stayed to the end was to find out the actress's name (since there are no opening credits).  But that's candy rather than nutrition.  I strongly recommend--especially to those who have yet to encounter Lem or Tarkovsky--that you stay home and either read the novel or rent the earlier version.  Having done both a couple of times, I still wished I had made that choice.

You walk into the theatre expecting something to be a good movie.  You trust an actor, you trust a director.  You put your next few hours into their hands.  But what happens?  You go and see Solaris.  And you are disappointed. You realize you could have been doing something else for the last 2 hours. You realize that you should have played with your child for those precious hours but you can't.  You saw Solaris and your time is gone and you are never going to see it again. You know the rest of the story.  Your children become distant and don't love you anymore simply based on the fact that you wanted to see a movie rather than take them to see a movie of their own.  You didn't want to see The Santa Claus. But you should have.  So take my advice.  Don't see this movie.  Spend time with your family.  Don't lose loved ones because of this horrible film. And don't waste your time watching this movie.  If you go see expect the movie to talk to you.  It will send you a message. It sends out a message the whole time, "I am a good movie, I'm a good movie."  Then at the end is says, "Oh kidding, I'm a horrible movie. Sorry you wasted your time.  You'll never see that lost time again." Moral: see something else.

I'd venture to say that every person would like to change something that happened to them in the past. I can't count the numerous things that I would like to change, but I'd settle for one. I once knew a woman that loved me and I was too full of myself to realize it. I've never found the same unconditional sort of love that she had for me over the past 25 years and I seriously doubt if I ever will again. If only I could find my way to Solaris. . .I see why George Clooney is considered by many women to be so desirable from a few of the beef-cake scenes in the movie. George has one hell of a nice body for a man his age!I've seen "The Perfect Storm" and "Oceans 11" and I thought that Mr. Clooney's acting talents were better used in "Solaris". With this performance he has made me a fan and thus, I will look forward to seeing his work in the future, rather than avoiding it.

Review title: wow can they call this a movie
Review_body: i think all i can really say was that this movie basically seems like someone woke up in the middle of the night, wrote down what they were dreaming, and the next morning made a movie script out of it. dreams are always really f-ed up and don't make any sense, so if you compare that to this movie, you'll see where I'm coming from. It wasn't artistic, it wasn't beautiful. It was a failed attempt at nothing. The music was boring as hell, the movie was INCREDIBLY slow moving and went no where. There were 10 people in the theater (on a Friday night) when I saw it and by the time it was over there were 3: me and my 2 friends. Once it ended, I felt like an ass sitting in that theater when everyone else went home and did something productive and meaningful. What a piece of sh*t. Don't waste your time.

When discussing what is out there in the universe and beyond, people often bring up very compelling questions. Unfortunately, the most intriguing ideas about the cosmos haven't translated that well to movies, making the sci-fi genre a long line of movies essentially about blowing up aliens with lasers. There are plenty of great sci-fi movies, but few stray from the never-ending battle of human vs. alien. `Solaris' deserves attention not for the mini-controversy surrounding its rating (a publicity stunt by Twentieth Century Fox because they reportedly had trouble finding ways to market the movie) but for having a premise set in deep space that doesn't involve evil aliens preying on overmatched humans.In `Solaris', George Clooney plays Chris Kelvin; a psychologist dispatched to a space station orbiting the titular planet to find out what went wrong on a routine exploration mission. When Kelvin arrives, he finds that two crewmembers are dead, and one of the two survivors has locked herself in her quarters because of what has gone on in the space station. When Kelvin finally does persuade the reclusive Dr. Gordon (the excellent Viola Davis) to talk, she tells him that `It isn't really worth talking about until it starts happening to you.'Though `Solaris' is a deliberately slow paced movie, `It' happens to Kelvin after his first night on the station; he wakes up to a kiss from his wife Rheya- who died years earlier. More haunting is the fact that she is not a figment of Chris' imagination, Rheya (played by Natacha McElhone) can recite memories of the life she and Chris shared together without any help from him. Both Clooney and McElhone fit their roles perfectly. Natacha McElhone has an intriguing beauty and she uses it to fit the haunting atmosphere of the film, and Clooney increasingly shows the wear of an intelligent man who cannot comprehend the events transpiring around him, and ends up with one of his best performances to date.What drives the film is the originality of the story. `Solaris'was written as a novel by Stanislaw Lem, and first adapted to film in 1972 by the legendary Russian filmmaker Andrei Tarkovsky. Tarkovsky's is a sci-fi classic and considered by many to be the foreign equivalent to `2001: A Space Odyssey.' Steven Soderbergh (who won Best Director for `Traffic'- itself a remake) refuses to call this `Solaris' a remake, and contends that his film is simply a new adaptation of Lem's novel.Soderbergh's argument is credible, his `Solaris' is almost half the length of Tarkovsky's near 3-hour epic, his screenplay concentrating mostly on the relationship of Rheya and Kelvin.The 1972 version eyes the scientific morals of the mission, something completely missing from the latter movie. The 2002 `Solaris' is a chilling film with great acting that asks intriguing questions about humanity, space and essentially love itself. Tarkovsky's `Solaris' is the superior film, but unlike many remakes, Soderbergh's film does not disgrace the original.
Grade: B+

Two words to describe everything about this movie: painfully boring. I'm not even one of those people who needs action in films to enjoy them. There is simply no psychological or intellectual stimulation in this movie for the basic reason that it goes so slowly. If this had been a 30-minute TV show (think Twilight Zone) it would have been more successful. I suggest if you want to see this movie, just go and rent the original.

Review title: I loved the movie, the music was amazing too!
Review_body: Man, I loved this movie... George C's acting was brilliant, and man, for a minute there, I felt so awful for that guy. I dunno how we're supposed to take movies, but I didn't watch it like some summer flick which isn't supposed to make sense...this movie is DO deep! (Even though its got elements of 2001: A Space Odyssey)And the music by Cliff Martinez...man, its really haunting, and in some ways, grows on you...especially First Sleep...I really don't care what everyone else thinks, I sure loved this movie. Oz

I looked forward to viewing this movie and found it to be pretty much a waste of time. I expected science fiction from the trailer but found it to be a boring dissertation in grieving for a lost love. In other words, it would best be characterized as "Love Story" with a space ship as its setting. In fact, I was a bit surprised that the line "Love means never having to say you're sorry" was not used in one of the flashbacks. I kept waiting for something to happen to make sense of the whole thing but was left with nothing but confusion and disappointment. I would sum it up as depressing."Skip it".

Thoughtful, intelligent and touching, Solaris demands some patience although ironically one of its failings is that it is too short! It is almost as if Steven Soderbergh realised that this movie wouldn't be to the taste of much of the cinema-going public and didn't want to try their patience.I have not read Lem's book, but I am lead to believe that it deals much more with the nature of Solaris itself and less with the relationship between the two leads. This relationship forms the major plot of the movie and this is something of a problem - we are left knowing nothing at all about the nature of Solaris or the nature of the intelligence that it contains. Perhaps this is also true of the novel. I would have liked much more to be made of the idea of this as a "first contact" situation - how would one cope if an alien intelligence chose to communicate in this way? Instead, the story is reduced to a "rationalism versus faith" parable in which a man confident in his objective, atheist view of reality is forced to follow his heart instead of his head to exorcise his past.That said, there is much here to enjoy. Natascha McElhone is perfectly cast as the mysterious Rheya. She is just utterly captivating whenever she is on screen. George Clooney plays George Clooney as usual, but turns in a competent performance. Viola Davis and Jeremy Davies are less effective - I can't help get the feeling that Davis was cast mainly because she is both female and black and they didn't want a stereotypical male, white physicist. As a scientist, the Gordon character seems awfully keen to want to destroy phenomena that are both extraordinary and unique - falling back on primitive fear instead of cool analysis.The enigmatic Solaris itself is beautifully rendered. Living up to its name it looks like a movie sequence from the solar SoHo probe studying our own star. Prominences and what could almost be cascades of alien, intelligent thought sweep across its surface. We're not even sure if it is supposed to be a star or a planet or an alien being. Coupled with the sparse soundtrack I found the Solaris object to be hypnotic. And surely it was intentional that it looks like a human ovum in that final shot?8/10

Review title: One of the best sci-fi films of recent years
Review_body: Comparisons with blade runner are certainly apt in the case of this film, not least by virtue of its brilliant visual language, excellent acting and subtle themes. An eerie sense of mystery is maintained throughout, which had me gripped until the end. In fact I felt this film was at least half an hour too short, basically ending as soon as the central theme of Kelvin's desire to resurrect his dead wife - excellently realised by the two actors - is fully played out. I was disappointed, however, that the film failed to explore in any depth the presence of the other "visitors" on the ship, which did not fit neatly in to the "life after death" theme. Of course we are told "there are no answers, only choices", but I would certainly have appreciated a deeper exploration of the choices made by the other characters. It's one of those films to leave a bittersweet taste in the mouth; for example the decision not to include Gordon's "visitor" at all I found a bit galling at first, but in retrospect may have been a brilliant device. I would have liked to have seen more about the moral dilemma facing these humans in the face of the "facsimiles".Though the acting was brilliantly restrained, I did feel the script denied the humanity of the astronauts to some extent, and would have enjoyed just a touch more psychodrama. None of the characters appeared to take any interest in each other at all, and though this was certainly consistent with the powerful character of Gordon, and though Kelvin was understandably preoccupied, the incoherence of the third character was rendered somewhat pointless by the fact that the visiting psychologist made no attempt to do his job.While I would like to point out that simply visually suggesting Philosophical themes is not quite the same as exploring them, this is still an excellent sci-fi film that fits firmly in to the tradition of Blade Runner and 2001 and the original Solaris.

Review title: There must be two movies with the same name and cast
Review_body: They must have seen a different film..that is the only explanation I have for the fact that some people apparently LIKED this incredibly bad film!! I actually read one review where the author compared this film to Bladerunner, which in my view is like comparing dog food to Filet Mignon.I could go into detail about the deficiencies in plot, the weak writing, and the performances that looked like the actors were almost as bored as their audience was destined to be, but I don't really want to relive any part of the experience, so let's just say that Solaris gets my nomination for the worst film of the decade.

Convoluted, painfully slow, pretentious rip-off of "2001."  This movie has nothing to recommend it.  Jeremy Davies performance alone is bad enough to push you over the edge.  What was his character even about?  That's just one of the many things about this stinker that made no sense.I'm not one who believes that all movies, sci-fi or otherwise, have to be tied up in neat packages by the end.  But this movie raises questions in the worst possible way.  Questions like, "What were they thinking when they made this piece of crap?" and "I spent 90 minutes of my life watching this?" The plot holes themselves raise dozens of questions but half-way in you stop expecting anything to make sense or tie together.  If you can make it to the end, you feel like you've taken a beating.The flaws don't stop there.  The sets are dreary and ugly.  The space station appears to be built entirely of drawers for some reason.  And the music runs the spectrum from annoying to grating.  The acting is lethargic at best, painful at worst.If you've not seen this one yet, do yourself a favor and pass it by.

Because of the slow pacing, the Philip Glass-ey music and the obvious references to 2001, you might get the idea that this is a thoughtful film that engages the intellect.  You would be wrong.While it's true that many recent films are all rather shallow, filled with hyperactive action-adventure (the recent Bond film comes to mind) but not much else, it does not follow that stripping a film of action and adventure automatically make it a "good" film as some here have averred.  Solaris is as devoid and sterile of genuine thought and emotion as its crash bang counterparts are.Mr. Soderbergh has made "Solaris" a post-modern love story.  The swirly colors are pretty to watch, and the soundtrack is easy on the ears.  But ultimately, this is a pretty vacuous experience.

Personally, I have nothing wrong with movies that have no action, so had no problem watching the first few min of solaris. Well, to me it looks like nothing happened. Lets try again, another few min. No, still nothing. Personally, I admit that I may have missed the "Cruicial Element of the Movie" in those few min, but if it was there, it would only be there for the most attentive viewers.Solaris drove me to a state of madness where I continually fast-forwarded parts of the movie trying to figure out what was going on. The end scene said it all, what I originally took as flashbacks from a clinically depressed guy appeared to be in correspondence to reality, and what you really have is a love story with a sub story embedded inside.This type of movie would have been better left to story. To those who disagree try actually reading. A book can offer a more driving story then a movie can, it can better reflect on the emotional aspect because words can touch multiple senses. In that regard, the emotional transition between the movie and yourself would be better facilitated in words then by sights and sounds.

Review title: Siralos. It's all backwards. A screensaver of a movie.
Review_body: Say 'Solaris' out loud but backwards.  "Siralos" sure sounds a bit like "sure a loss".  There, you got it.  Don't waste your money on this . . . er, thing.  It looks alot like an '80s computer screensaver and has about as much content.  Space is empty and this film tries to prove it.  A space warp in Clooney's career . . . or a black hole?

Review title: Can Clooney smile without forcing it?
Review_body: A solid attempt at energizing the "been there, done that" of science fiction lore.  Soderbergh might have started a road to revival in the genre of Stanley Kubrick without Stanley Kubrick.  Clooney shows anguish and pain far better than he shows happiness, satisfaction, or pleasure, so he was perfect for the role.A 6 out of 10, with considerable room for improvement.
