Anyway 7-/10(maybe the absence of small-talk confuses some American directors) I'm not arguing that it's always the case.

Review title: Lonely and lost out here in the stars (very minor spoilers)
Review_body: Solaris is a throwback to the kind of film that Hollywood made for a time in the 1970s, but hardly makes anymore.  Although movies from the genre of sci-fi/fantasy have dominated the pantheon of blockbuster movies, this is not one of them.  Solaris is more like the anti-blockbuster; its commercial prospects are grim.  It's being marketed as science-fiction/romance film, but fundamentally it's about the human condition, guilt, regret, forgiveness, loneliness, the existence (or non-existence) of God, and our attempts at connection with our fellow travellers.  It reminded me of the Kurt Weill song "Lost in the Stars" about how we were created by God, but He's left us, abandoned us to drift in space.We find out during a dinner party, that the lead character, Chris Kelvin, is an atheist and doesn't believe in God.  Human relationships should be very precious for people like him, because once it's over, once you're dead, that's it.  A lot of believers are comforted by the prospects of being reunited with your loved ones in an everlasting afterlife.  Chris Kelvin doesn't have that luxury.  The movie suggests that human relationships are very fragile and also touches upon the fundamental impossibility of really knowing another person.  The best we can really hope for is knowing ourselves.  But we should try our best to look past ourselves and get out there and make connections, to alleviate our loneliness, and not take them for granted.  After he threatens to leave his wife Rheya in a fit of rage, she commits suicide.  Many Christians believe that suicide causes your soul to be lost and damned.  So whether God exists or not, Chris and Rheya are pretty well screwed.  One of the taglines for the movie is "How far will you go for a second chance?"  Well, if you're Chris Kelvin, I'm guessing pretty damn far.I found Solaris to be similar to these movies:Vertigo (romantic illusions and not really knowing another person)Last Tango in Paris (as above, plus the suicide angle)A.I. Artificial Intelligence (meeting your maker, redemption, mortality)Blade Runner (as above)The Remains of the Day (regret, loneliness)If you liked any or, better yet, all of the above films, the chances are good that you'll appreciate Solaris.  If you hated those movies, Solaris is not for you.  This film is one challenging piece of work, "slow" and filled with "intellectual" themes and may bring out uncomfortable feelings.  If you're looking for action, don't go to Solaris.One of the year's best. (9/10)

Review title: The film equivalent of a Sharper Image catalog.
Review_body: I really wanted to like this movie. However, it came off like a Sharper Image catalog: glossy, slick, and full of a lot of cool stuff. On the other hand, I would never really buy anything out of a Sharper Image catalog. The visuals and sets are no less than stunning. The story - with its elements of love, loss, memories, and atonement - is a good one, though its execution suffers with some inconsistent points. Where Solaris falls flat is in its pacing and its acting. The movie presents itself as a thriller/experimental/sci-fi/romance/etc, but the pace never goes above a crawl. This sort of slow and atmospheric pacing works very well when done with style (Pi, for example, with its brooding intensity). In Solaris, it is mildly boring. The acting is cold and mechanical. Perhaps this is a statement on life in this future, perhaps not. In any case, it is very difficult to feel sympathy for any of the characters, as none of them are memorable enough to really get engaged in their lives or situations. Another very strange element to this film is its soundtrack. In the trailers, a sweeping and very cinematic score accompanies the actions onscreen. In the actual movie, the ambience is provided by an incessant steel drum and bell chorus. The same phrase plays throughout the entire movie. For the first hour or so, it emphasizes the isolation and repetition of a desperate situation; in the latter portion of the movie it becomes annoying. Cinematic scores are very stirring to provide emotional cues - they tell you exactly how to interpret the story. When done poorly, they seem intrusive. When done well, they subtly guide you along. If not done at all, it is a very rare movie that feels complete. Solaris is a bit difficult to review. After leaving the theater, I initially enjoyed it quite a bit. The more I thought about it, the less I liked it. See Solaris on the big screen only if you have the patience to invest time and thought in a cold and inaccessible film with some interesting ideas and great visuals. Otherwise, save it for a rental.

Review title: A thoughtful sci-fi movie, creepy, but without horror (spoilers)
Review_body: Solaris is a strange, beautiful world, remote from Earth, which is being investigated by a survey team to assess its economic potential. However abnormal occurrances have plagued the team including the suicide of the team leader and the appearance to the crew of persons from their past experience, who cannot possibly be physically present (some are known to be dead) in the survey ship.Enter psychologist Chris Kelvin (George Clooney), charged with dispeling the problems/"hallucinations", only to be beset by them himself in overwhelming measure when his dead wife appears, not once but twice (the first he ejects from the ship in an escape pod).The presence of physicist and hard rationalist Gordon (Viola Davis) does much to prevent the crew (and plot) from disintegrating into a babble of mumbo-jumbo mysticism. There are no detectable psychotropic agents which could be causing the crew to imagine these occurances. The beings rather, are constructs from the memories of the persons who knew them, created somehow by Solaris itself. As such, they are what the person who knew them thinks they were, rather than the original person. But very real enough. They exhibit an almost indestructibility (if injured or killed, they shortly self-resurrect), though Gordon develops a method of dispelling them using exotic radiation.While all understand with their minds that the appearance of these beings is undesirable ("What if this was to spread to Earth" screams Gordon), emotion overwhelms reason and Kelvin is determined to hold onto this remnant of his wife, however imperfect. There are tense moments between Gordon and Kelvin.The ending is anti-climactic and enigmatic. It is Gordon who makes the decision to return to Earth carrying the rest of the crew with her (they seem incapable of any making any significant decisions). The crew don't fall into a senseless slaughter of each other, nor do the beings suddenly turn hostile. In the deja vu sequence near the film's very end, Kelvin finds himself on Earth and cuts himself (again) while preparing a meal. While attending to the wound, he is arrested by the sudden appearance of his wife. He asks, "Am I alive... or dead?" She assures "We don't have to think like that anymore. We're together now. Everything we've done is forgiven. Everything." They fall into a long, clinging embrace which dissolves into the image of Solaris, now very reminicient of an embryo.

Review title: Soderbergh crafts a beautiful and intelligent film
Review_body: This is very simply one of the most beautiful and visual movies I have ever seen. Which is the very reason why it may not be for everyone. The movie tells the story of a troubled psychiatrist Chris Kelvin who recieves a message from his good friend Dr. Gibarian, who is a researcher on the space station orbating a planet seemingly made out of energy called Solaris. Kelvin travels to the space station where he finds two of the crew members dead, including his friend, and the other two acting very strangely. He then begins to recieve visits from his deceased wife who killed herself because of something he had said to her some years before.Seemingly being a science fiction film the audience might be expecting something very different from what they get. It is not an action movie but a film noir in the strictest sense of the word. The story is told more with imagery than dialog and moves very slowly. Though in my opinion the pacing serves to enhance the movie even more. The slowness will however chase away more restless viewers. The movie is also very thematically based serving to deal with such things as second chances, desire, love, reality, and god. Solaris won't give you anything in terms of where you go with it. It won't show you point A and point B and draw a straight line between the two. Instead it will give you point A and point Z and tell you to draw your own path with all the other points along the way.Really there is nothing I can say that will give you a correct picture of the film. This is partly due to the fact that it is so imagery oriented, and partly due to the fact that everyone I have talked to who really likes this movie has come away with a different meaning in it. I think it is best to go into the movie without any preconcieved notions about what you are going to see because I don't think there has been any movie quite as skillfully crafted in some time now.Definately not for the mainstream. Definately kind of a niche film. Definately a very deep and thought provoking movie. Definately on my top ten list. Very very intelligent and well created movie one of Soderbergh's best, but don't expect to be helped through the story like most movies do now adays.

Review title: i wonder if stanislaw lem liked this one, i did.
Review_body: i was looking to see this movie in the theatre, but somehow missed it, so the dvd had to do. i rented it last week and watched it twice in a row.must be one of the best science fiction films ever made. right now im reading the book the second time, now after some ten years, and when im through, ill buy the dvd.i dont know if soderbergh or whats his name is a genius, and i certainly cant think so of cameron (not since titanic, sorry), but this movie is.in a way it is similar to star trek 1 - the motion picture, and that means 95% of viewers will probably say its boring (save die hard trek fans maybe), but for people like me, its just excellent entertainment.computer effects and soundtrack are first class also.

I found it hard to get into Solaris. All the way through it was like i was looking at the DVD clock. I like George Clooney i think he is a great actor and i think Soderbergh is a great director. But i didn't see where this film was going or where it was trying to get too. It looked good and was well acted. But i wouldn't put myself out to watch this movie.

About 20 minutes into "Solaris," I noticed that there were some strong similarities between this film and the video game "Silent Hill 2" (this is a positive comparison, mind you, but I won't get into a discussion of SH2 here). My friend had asked me to rent it, and to be honest, I was wary of it, at first. I had heard bad things about it, and was prepared for it to be truly awful. What I got, instead, was one of the most beautiful and tragic things I've ever seen. Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) is a psychologist who has ample emotional baggage of his own. He is quiet and brooding, never letting on the torment that is going on in his mind. The pattern of his mundane life is disrupted when a couple of strangers show up with an ominous message: Chris's friend, Gibrarian (Ulrich Tukur), who is in charge of a space ship that is investigating the planet Solaris, cryptically begs Chris to come to the ship and help them, never quite divulging what is wrong. Chris obliges, and before too long, has arrived on the ship. However, he finds that Gibrarian, along with one of the other scientists, is already dead. The only survivors are Snow (Jeremy Davies), who seems eerily detached from all the madness that surrounds him, and Gordon (Viola Davis), who is paranoid and suspicious of everyone, especially Chris. Chris is unable to convince Snow and Gordon to leave right away, unsure of what is going on. In the night, Chris is visited by the apparition of his wife, Rheya (Natascha McElhone), who has been dead for three years. Thinking it a dream, Chris awakes, only to find out that Rheya is all too real.As it turns out, Solaris, for better or worse, creates 'visitors' for the crew members of the ship, which are fashioned from their feelings and memories. These visitors are manifestations of guilt, of regret, of longing, and of love. Chris, blaming himself for Rheya's suicide, is unable to fully comprehend the idea that the visitor is not real, because he so desperately needs the second chance that Rheya's 'ghost' represents. Therefore, he fights tooth and nail with Gordon, who wants to destroy Rheya and go back to earth. However, Rheya's increasing self-awareness drives her to despair, as she realizes she is not the Rheya that Chris remembers, and therefore allows herself to be destroyed. However, the ship itself is in grave danger. Snow's eerie calm was a mask for his deranged state of mind...and his treachery causes the ship to be put on a crash course with Solaris. Although Gordon is able to leave the ship, Chris, upon rumination, is not. He is left behind with Snow to face whatever is in the heart of Solaris, and what exactly he finds there is open to debate, without a doubt. Whatever it is, it provides peace, love, and forgiveness for his tortured soul. "Solaris," from it's gray, dark opening, to its beautiful, mystifying conclusion, is stunning. The music is amazingly haunting and lingers in your mind long after the last chord has faded. The visuals are stunning, and each scene is a work of great beauty. The clean, cold nature of the ship contrasts sharply with the raw power of emotion flowing between the four main characters, as they struggle with reality and unreality, and what they are and what they are not. The acting is remarkable, as well. I was a big fan of Clooney's performance in "O Brother Where Art Thou," but his work here was amazing. Fantastic. He really conveyed the brooding and suffering plaguing Kelvin's psyche, making the role his own. Natascha McElhone is also wonderfully cast as Rheya. Her confusion, her pain, and her mysterious, evasive nature are all portrayed beautifully. Both of these characters elicit so much love, sympathy, and frustration, that it's amazing how much you find yourself caring about and mourning for two souls that are as adrift as they are. Davis, Davies, and Tukur all do fine acting jobs, as well, to their credit. Davis is the force of reason on the ship, yet somewhat ominous, because one wonders who...or what...her visitor could be. Davies, the manic Snow, portrays the spooky character perfectly. He's excitable, and hyperactive, to be sure...yet, he doesn't seem to be bothered by anything around him. Tukur, as Gibrarian, really enhances the scenes he is in. The scene in which he converses with Chris from beyond the grave is very haunting and is a particular stand-out. Rarely have I seen a film that evokes as much emotion or portrays as much beauty as this one. Everything, from the sets, to the effects, to the acting, music, and visual style, form together to create a work of near perfection. My only complaint was that it was too short!What happens to Chris when he enters the heart of Solaris? There is no definitive answer to it, but trying to find one is a great exercise for the mind. See this movie with someone you love. (Next time I see my girlfriend, she's being forced to watch this...I think it would have an even more profound emotional impact on couples) 10/10

This movie is a perfect example of how science fiction should be done.  It constructs a situation which makes us question our ideas about reality, and about what it means to be human.  It's a shame so many moviegoers here and elsewhere seem to equate good sci fi with action/adventure; we miss out on a lot of great stories like this because Hollywood thinks they can't sell science fiction without boobs and explosions.

SPOILER!! This movie presents that well worn chestnut of a storyline: boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy finds girl again in the heart of a weird pink planet in deep space. I mean how many times have we seen that? It's practically a genre in itself.

Review title: The movie tries to be intelligent and thoughtful, but in that it fails
Review_body: It is highly amusing to see how this movie polarizes the critics on IMDB. Other critics were bored to death, others seem to have loved it. I  will take a more balanced approach.In my opinion, the movie could have been much more but some clear flaws make it mostly incompatible with the expectations of most people. Also the advertising and trailers made me believe I would see something much better than this movie actually delivered.The visual appearance of the space station orbiting Solaris (the planet or neutron star or whatever that may be) is great. This was definitely somewhat inspired by Kubrick's 2001. However this image is used too often in this movie. The soundtrack is unconventional and fits the mood and slow pace of this movie.Unfortunately the plot development is truly banal and in many aspects unsatisfactory. Here I have to agree with those critics who found those movie boring and uninspired.We get to see Clooney enter a space station where people have previously gone mad. Some committed suicide, others have been murdered. Obviously there have been violent fights on this space station. This is a promising lead-in and setting, similar to the movie "Event Horizon".So the audience is led into expecting a continuation of this violent theme. But there is no continuation of this. Not at all. So why did the movie show us bloodstains in the first place?There is only very few surprises in this movie. One being that everyone on the station is haunted by a mysterious visitor created by Solaris. This mysterious visitor is a construct of every person's most intense memories. So our antagonist's beloved wife reappears in physical form. By means of flashbacks and dream sequences the audience learns that his wife is long dead because she had committed suicide years ago.This unnatural visitor acts human and even experiences human emotions herself - yet she cannot possibly be human because there is no rational explanation for her existence. Also when she gets injured or killed she magically heals or reappears hours later. Slowly realizing that she is not a true human being she is getting desperate and suicidal.Still the antagonist played by Clooney misses his wife so much that he decides to embrace and accept that thing which looks like his wife. And all that is neither particularly credible nor logical. At the end of  the movie you will keep asking yourself "Why? I don't understand this character. I don't see why he acted this way.".The other two remaining characters living on this space station hardly contribute to the plot development. This movie could have delivered so much more if this story had not focused so much on the banal love story element. The director should have replaced the banality with a bit more suspense, mystery and maybe some violence. Catering for the audience's expectations is a bare necessity: Either deliver what people expect or present the unexpected! This movie does neither.The movie tries to be intelligent and thoughtful, but in that it fails. All that remains is a terribly slow pace where people actually expected to see some terrible mysteries revealed. Overall the movie presents no answers to a lot of open questions.  I don't see how this movie got funding in the first place and was marketed like this - given the uninspired script.Rating: 4 out of 10.

I'd have to say George Clooney has made some not-so-good movies, and this one is one of them. I kept waiting for something but it didn't happen for me. The acting was okay but he and Natasha weren't very selective in their movie pick on this one. When I finally figured out what was happening (3/4 way thru the movie) it was too late to stop watching so I had to finish. I have over 2,000 movies in my collection but this one is not a keeper, sorry to say. I really like George and Natasha, but this movie won't be part of my collection. I keep hoping George will come up with another good one as he is a very versatile actor and I really enjoy his other movies...the one's I've kept anyway

Solaris is slow and pointless, but full of painfully long scenes and confusing plot points.What else can I say. Steven Soderbergh attempts to turn an interesting idea into a 2001 style film. Unfortunately, throwing together a bunch of slow scenes and mystic images does little to make a great film.None of the actors involved are that bad, in fact, I felt them struggling through the material to try and pull it off. I am not a huge Clooney fan, but I felt that all involved gave it their best. The DVD even alludes to the fact that the actors did not understand what Soderbergh was doing, but trusted that it would be great. If you are still interested in this film, I suggest staring at a rock for 99 minutes as a good warm up to how it feels to watch this film.

I should point out that I didn't see the whole film - I only caught the second half. But what I saw was extremely intriguing. Two things in particular struck me. First, the pace, and accompanying music; it's a film that creeps over you at an invisible pace, and the hypnotic music does a lot to keep you sitting there. As said by other users, the pace we're used to in films, particularly sci-fi - crash, bang, wallop, atomic explosion - makes Solaris a challenge until you settle into it, but the mesmerising, haunting music has a way of fixing you where you sit, while the film's essence seeps into you.Second, the film's interesting exploration of ideas about reality: the reality of the world and people around us, and of ourselves; the part our memories play in defining and historically preserving reality and the form of our lives. It's not a theme that could have been well explored in a sensational, typically 'Hollywood' film; the effect would have been crass and not a little superficial. The pace of Solaris - what I saw of it, at least - allows one to think about the ideas present while the film slowly unfolds. A line towards the end - I don't know if it constitutes a spoiler but I'll assume it does - particularly intrigued me: "I performed all the millions of gestures that constitute life on Earth. But I was haunted by the idea that I remembered her wrong... that I was wrong about everything." It's a film that takes patience and concentration, and rewards you with moving, understated performances, a feeling of quiet unsettlement, and hours of afterthought. I'd like to see the entire thing... as well as the Russian original, and Lem's novella.

Spoiler!What if we sent a ship out and parked next to heaven?  In a cocktail party conversation, the protaganist and his friends don't seem to have a grip on what is the afterlife, except that it doesn't exist, which is a cop-out. Gordon, the main scientist left on the ship, is fighting crossing over to heaven, but our hero, Kevin, finally embraces it.  The final scene is of Kevin and his wife in heaven, as conceptualized by the author.  All is forgiven.  Lovely space philosophy; I'm glad to see mysticism in science fiction.  I plan on viewing the 1972 original Solaris.  Ain't those Russians contemplative!?!

Review title: What did this movie remind you of?
Review_body: Spoiler alert!I read the book by Stanislaw Lem and it is a real heavy-duty sci-fi book. He gets lost in long sections of scenery and techno-babble but forgets about the "heart" of the movie.  This story is so character driven - and to call it a "romance in space" is no insult.  The movie is better than the book because of what Lem doesn't do, and Soderbergh does do.Rheya - Natascha McElhone's character - finally realizes she's not a real person but a "creation" of the sentient planet Solaris.  She committed suicide years ago and the planet creates her from Chris Kelvin's (George Clooney) memories.  The heart of it all is that she says to Chris that she is suicidal because that is how she remembers herself.  The great wisdom in the movie is when he realizes that he remembered her wrong, though he never stopped loving her.The great twist that they add to the movie is that Snow (Jeremy Davies) isn't a real person but a "creation", and right from the start of the movie there are little clues to it.  Sort of like "The Sixth Sense" but you only see it after you've seen the whole movie.  This one bit just blew me away.This movie is great - even for those who never read the book - and I think it would have had better reviews if it hadn't been George Clooney.  He's good, but the story really is the winner here.10 out of 10.

Having noted that there were a number of mixed reviews of Solaris (some saying it was excellent, some saying it was awful), I decided I had to watch it to make my own mind up.And I have to say that in this particular case, I have to side with the "excellent" camp.  Solaris is a thought-provoking and emotional film revolving around a man's journey to the mysterious "Solaris" where he has to come to terms with the loss of his wife, and what Solaris might mean to him. It is certainly one that one can only come close to understanding when watched in one sitting.I thoroughly enjoyed Solaris, but admit that I was at times left completely bewildered.  However, this only came about by my own inability to comprehend what "Solaris" was, which I presume, was entirely the point.I urge anyone still sitting on the fence to watch Solaris again, with an open mind, and be prepared to accept that you probably wont understand what Solaris itself actually is.Amazing movie, and one that I will watch again.  9/10

I really missed the depth in this remake of Solaris. Scientist not interested in exploring, just in holding on to what they have got. The 1971 version left the viewer baffled with questions, guessing about reality. This version does not. The final scene is a poor attempt to have a happy Hollywood ending. It left me with a dreadful empty feeling.

Review title: Great movie if you take it for what it is
Review_body: It seems that everyone that I have spoken to has hated this movie, for the main reason being that "it was boring" or "it wasn't what I was expecting." This movie is not a typical Sci-Fi movie, it contains sci-fi aspects, but its a love story at the core (and not your normal love story either). I personally thought it was an excellent movie, and everyone's performance in it was great. But I guess this movie is not for the impatient, since its pretty much all dialogue. I'm a picky person when it comes to movies that I support, and this one has it. So if you're thinking about checking out this movie, I say its worth a shot, but maybe not with a group of friends, either alone or with your significant other.

Review title: Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from Magic. -Arthur C. Clarke
Review_body: I decided to see this film at the worst time, probably: Sick, in bed, sleeping 20 hours of the day. The day I felt a bit better, I decided I would like to watch a film. This one had come in as an add-on with the TV magazine, and I remembered seeing the posters way back in 2002 (for some reason I didn't go and see it then. Pity.). So, popped the DVD into my laptop, got my good earphones, and crawled back into bed. If you now think I fell asleep after 10 minutes, you are wrong. Despite my state, I was mesmerized. This is something I hadn't come across for a long time.From the moment you see Chris Kelvin (Clooney) sitting on his bed, head in hands, and hear the voice of Rheya (McElhone) in voice-over you know that this is not going to be a normal sci-fi film. You witness Kelvin act out the things of everyday life, making appointments with clients, holding group sessions as a psychologist, but you feel quite early on that there are demons from his past haunting him. Soderbergh also enhances this by keeping the focus on Kelvin, and having other people vanish into the blurred background, only leaving their voices to be heard.These demons are becoming more real once he reaches Solaris on his investigation mission. One of the most memorable scenes for me was the first appearance of Rheya. Kelvin darting out of his bed, hitting his head, trying to wake up and finally understanding that this is real and not a dream. Sent shivers down my spine. And while Chris loses his grip on reality, Rheya becomes more real and more aware of herself and of the fact that her existence is something "unreal". At first Rheya is only talking in formulas, but as the film progresses, she develops a new personality and we see Rheya (Solaris) becoming more like Rheya (Earth) again. And there are the two other members of the crew, Dr. Gordon (v. Davis) and Snow (J. Davies). Snow is...- weird, and Davies' creepy characterisation was spot on, IMO. You'll understand *why* Snow acts this way later in the film. The only person choosing reality instead of dreams, and incidentally the only one to survive is Dr. Gordon. She also is the one that ultimately figures out a way to get rid of the apparitions and doesn't hesitate to do so.There is another member of the cast that merits mention and that is the score. In most films, the score is either utterly forgettable or tells you the story in broad strokes and with thumping drums. In this one, it felt like a fifth character, setting the mood for a scene, and freshening up the atmosphere with a little splash of notes here and there. It also kept you in a kind of... trance-like mood in parts, thereby adding another layer to the "reality or dream?" question that permeates the film.Soderbergh took Lem's classic science fiction story and made something entirely different from it, but still a classic sci-fi story, exploring love, reality, minds and sanity.

***note this review was originally written when i was a happy idiot*** this film is so slow that it is easy to see why it is stuck at the IMDb 6/0 mark. it is a boar of the film world, whereby is can easily be struck down by the many predators surrounding it.however, i feel that it has an engrossing atmosphere and one scene that sticks in my mind is the white noise scene where Kelvin passes over to the world of Solaris (the child bridging that gap). The atmosphere of the movie gives the effect that you are actually being sucked into Solaris with the space station itself. By the end of the film, you are hypnotised within the grasp of solaris and have discovered the ability to introspect into the literal situation of -- would you go actually go back to earth IF a lost loved one -- of whom you had something to solve from within them -- came back to you in all of their glory. Their mannerisms and faults copied by the spectacle of this God-like entity.

Review title: the pieces are all there, it's just a shame they were put together badly!
Review_body: I honestly wanted to like this film, but just couldn't get on with it. The cinematography looks really good, the acting is pretty good, the soundtrack is the best element (composed by Cliff Martinez), but the film just doesn't work. I would pin it on two things; one is the direction, which doesn't let the film flow and the way the flashbacks are incorporated didn't lead me to any revelations in the film. The second element wrong with this film is that you're not surprised by anything. In a film like this you almost need a reward for spending 100 minutes watching it, but you aren't given one, there doesn't feel like any form of redemption in this film for the viewer. If you want to watch a really good film by this director then look up "the limey" which is a very good film which, like solaris, deals with elements of love and how we deal with it when it has gone. In the case of the Limey it is between a father and daughter rather than a husband and wife. There hasn't been a film that has wound me up like solaris has in a very long time and to put the boot in even more, I got more satisfaction watching American Pie presents Band Camp, and that film is one of the worst films i have ever seen!

Review title: Either love it, if tune into it,
Review_body: Or you will hate it, if you don't catch its wave. As for me, it stirred me up to the bottom of my soul. Good test: if you didn't like "A.I.", don't bother going.In some movies knowing the plot ahead of time spoils everything. Here enjoying the movie without knowing the plot ahead of time would be a serious impediment (I was lucky to have red Stanislav Lev story beforehand). I can imagine myself watching this movie over and over, and definitely plan to buy it on DVD when it is out.This movie made me think what is real in life and what is not, what is of value in life and what is not, what is a true life, what does it mean to be human, if there is anything after death - then what, what is God, etc. The multitude of themes subtly collide at the unusual angles under the surface of the seemingly slowly developing movie, which makes it difficult to get into. But if you will get into it, you may end up thinking about it - and about values in your life - for a long time, finding source of strength and inspiration.Most people in the theater hated it. I think it is one of the movie you hate the 1st time around and love more and more with each consequent time. The tempo, presentation, polyphony of the plot - everything is so unusual, that the ideas of the movie may go "under the radar screens" when you watch it the 1st time around

Have an open mind going into this one! It's fantastic but you've got to be thinking -- don't expect explosions, sex, and violence. This is a thinking person's film.It will leave you questioning reality for weeks!GO SEE IT

Review title: Did everyone else watch the same movie I did?
Review_body: Simply put, this was the worst movie I have ever seen.I usually like George Clooney and cannot imagine why he took this role. There was nothing stimulating about this movie. The 3 other people and myself all were struggling to stay awake.  This movie was the most boring, non-thought provoking movie I have ever seen.  There was nothing to make this movie worth watching.  The best part of the movie was when I was expecting there to be another hour for sure, the movie ended.  I was so happy that I was finally able to leave the theater! There were about 30 other people in the theater and you could hear everyone commenting on how horrible this film was.Please, save yourself the lost time in your life and DO NOT see this movie.

Review title: It's a shame that more people don't stop to smell the roses
Review_body: This is NOT the sort of science fiction action film that has made the genre popular with the masses, it is the sort of science fiction film that makes the genre complete - about people dealing with the world around them and coming to grips with the universe that we are stumbling around in.  THANK you to the film makers and to George Clooney who delivered a solid performance in this off-beat yet thought-provoking love story.

Review title: He should have stayed on Earth!
Review_body: I have only walked out of two movies in my whole life..this was one of them. I gave the movie more than 1 hour to improve, but it was just painful. I finally had to ask for my money back. There is silence for too long, and his wife is just creepy. As my friend said, "the highlight of the movie was George Clooney's butt, and it wasn't even that good!" it is too hard to explain how bad it is....Save your> money and go to another movie.

I think that this movie is masterpiece for the eyes. The whole concept is visual based. It is just so unique. I want to see it twice! I think that a closer look at the film is profitable. Don't blink, you might miss something vital to the plot. Very well done Mr. Soderbergh. It has been a pleasure supporting you, as it always has been!

I just can't understand why people have so much anger towards this movie. If you look at the voting graph, there's a huge peak at the bottom score 1. I guess these voters are the baseball-capped teenagers who waited the whole movie for Van Damme to come smash some faces in. Or Eminem beamed up to the spacecraft to write a rapsong about Solaris. Nowadays, a movie without a gunfight, drug use or pornography is worth nothing, I guess.
For me the movie was an unbelievable experience, where the set design, lighting and the music combined with fine acting of Clooney and McElhone formed an unbelievable eery atmosphere. One of the best movies ever. A true classic.

A nice try to compose between Solaris of Lem, Tarkovskiy and "Master and Margarita" of Bulgakov (I am talking about "All we've done is forgotten" phrase that sends me straight to Bulgakov' ending idea of "Master&Margarrita" novel). I am sure that You will enjoy this film more not seeing Tarkovskiy's one before. After all, I do not understand why Stanislaw Lem was angry with Tarkovski after the last one did his version of "Solaris"?

I don't care if it's a fierce remake. It's a very boring, dull, and dreary movie. I tried to enjoy myself, but it was hard to when all that was going on was sex scenes. First of all, the relationship between Chris Kelvin and Rehya is the weakest romance I've ever seen. It started off with them having sex, and then they talk on the streets. It describes the couple metaphorically, but I just didn't see a love their. Why did Chris push her off in space anyway? Also, Solaris. What is it? Nothing made any sense in this movie. Alive peoples bodies dead on the ship. Like it made sense. The planet is Solaris. But why did they make this? If they are doing it for sentiment then they didn't get anything in response. It was lively, but was senseless. It was very slow. Deliberation was slow and very pacing. It's very uneven. It wasn't confusing; I just want to know what Solaris did. But what was its purpose? It obviously did something to create a memory person. But how. The reason why I mostly hate it is because there are too many unanswered questions. And the whole premise and idea of Solaris is just dumb, not beautiful.

This movie was in no way worth the time or the money.  I'm not even going to waste my time going into a critique of it, I'm gonna just stick with comments on this one.  To give you an idea that I wasn't alone in my opinion, I watched quite a few people get up and leave the theater in the first hour.  After the movie was over, I asked the usher if anyone had complained and he said 20 people came up and said it was the worst movie they'd seen and either wanted refunds or to see another film.  I think that pretty much speaks for itself.I hope Soderbergh doesn't lose his edge now that he's gotten so lovey-dovey with stars like George Clooney and Julia Roberts.  There's nothing worse than watching someone waste or lose their talent by buying into a popularity contest.  After this one, I'll definitely think twice before going to Soderbergh's next film.  That's my opinion, for whatever it may be worth.

Review title: Call It Something Else, Because It Ain't Solaris
Review_body: Having read the book before I saw this I though it was a huge disappointment. They completely missed the point of the story, which was philosophical rather than emotional. Basically, the movie took an awe-inspiring "what if" thought experiment - of finding a very advanced non-human intelligence (which, surprise surprise, doesn't have two arms, two legs, a body and a head) and the problems of trying to communicate with such a radically different being, especially when it doesn't seem interested in communication, and how we can relate to it with our own limited human experience, and squeezed out all the juicy intellectual bits. Solaris was supposed to be the real star of the story and the screenplay instead turned it into background wallpaper. All that was left then, was a sappy love story set in space. It is frustrating to think about the potential that was wasted. Mr. Soderbergh could have made a classic sci-fi film here, if only he'd made an honest attempt.The funny thing is, if I hadn't read the book I would have liked the film, because it is well directed and has a nice atmospheric mood. There's nothing inherently wrong with love stories either. Just.. call it something other than Solaris, give the characters different names, don't do anything to remind me of the original story and I'd say it is a good movie. But as it is, it's an extreme disappointment.

I thought Schizopolois was hard to understand. Solaris is a film that moves at a snail's pace and by the time something happens or is said you've forgoten what happened just before. Steven Soderbergh is by far the most over rated Director in Hollywood. He's had a few good films, but he's definitely no superstar. Stay away from Solaris unless you've forgotten to refill tour sleeping pill prescription and you need something to put you to sleep.

There are many ways in which you can lose someone. Death is one of the ways. Rejection is another. Sometimes we are rejected but the boundaries are not clear enough and we cling on to shreds of hope before we accept the pain of reality. Mix the two and you have Solaris, a place where we can be tempted to believe that even the most profound and terrible loss can be redeemed.For what this film sets out to do, it does impeccably. The acting, pace and ambiance of this film do everything to allow us to reflect on, and be moved by, the themes that are explored: namely, love and loss.This film will not to be to everyone's taste because it relies completely on the audience being engaged and moved by these themes, but if you are not bored then you might possibly be moved to tears.

Review title: boring, undeveloped remake is a total waste; save your money
Review_body: The first five minutes of this film are so torpid and dull, you just know you're in for something.  You're hoping it's a set-up to pull the rug out from under you when you least expect it.  Sadly, there is no rug; the rest of the movie remains at this underwater pace all the way to its unsatisfying and hokey ending.The premise is intriguing enough, but little is done with it.  Instead of focusing on the thriller (unraveling the mystery of Solaris), the back story of Clooney and his lost love takes over.  This is dull beyond belief--partly because we know it's history and partly because Clooney's lover is a character that is so moody, aloof and unsympathetic that we really don't care about her at all.  What should have been one flashback--or at most a montage--becomes almost half the film.  And the wrap-up of the main story ensues without answering any of the mysteries of Solaris.  We never know why it does what it does.  There's nothing to spoil, here, folks.  Because there are no surprises.Then, as if the content weren't dull enough, they add insult to injury by filming the thing like a student film on a shoestring budget with unending tight shots and close-ups...as though they couldn't afford any sets.  With the amount of money amassed by the talent involved, this is not just annoying--it's unacceptable.  If it was an attempt at an effective use of claustrophobia, it failed miserably.  As does the film.  We were sold a sci-fi thriller with big names at the helm.  What we got is a cheap, poorly conceived, dismally executed, plodding shaggy dog story that should be used to calm ulcer patients and nothing more.

i sure am glad i didnt have to pay for this movie. talk about a waste of an hour and forty-five minutes of my life! can we say " 2001 space odyssey with a conscience?" what was clooney thinking ( not that his movie choices have been all that great in the past).  but hey,  i hope you dont take my advice, and you spend 1:45 of your life watching this movie too, then i wont fell like such a schmuck for doing it. peace out

I am a big fan of Andrei Tarkovsky, and I must say I was absolutely NOT disappointed by the re-make.  It is an excellent example of how Science Fiction CAN be intelligent, and while not completely a re-make of the Tarkovsky film to the frame, and different from the book, it absolutely retains the spirit of these works, while adding a few of its own twists.I know that this film hasn't exactly set the box office on fire and many of the multiplex crowd are running from the exits clutching their heads in pain, but I have one question to North America...  Are we really THAT stupid?  Come on, this film merely gives us a beautifully ambiguous dream experience that is not all that dense beyond the fact that it is based on emotion rather than logic.  I mean come on, must every movie be so logical that there is NO room left for an audience to use their imaginations, and have FUN with ambiguity?  MULHOLLAND DRIVE was an excellent example of how recent movies can not give you all the answers and work.  But that film was embraced, and this one, because it was done by a guy like Soderburgh and features Clooney seems ripe for the picking because it will attract audiences that are only there to see a movie star's ass.Very silly for the marketing departments at Fox, who obviously had no clue what to do with such a beautiful and poetic film, that they handled the film completely wrong.  This film should have opened slow and small then grown with word of mouth, not thrown out with 2,400 prints on a Wednesday!  I know it is an expensive movie, but now they have killed any momentum it might have had, at least in North America.  Hopefully for its international release, a more thoughful campaign and strategy will be used.Overall, I couldn't be more impressed and pleased with this film, from the superlative directing, acting, cinematography, music and production design, this one works full force.And the irony is that it's not even HALF as dense as the classic film Tarkovsky made of the book years ago.  So if a simplified version of such a story is getting so many audience members screaming in confusion and boredom, how are even more marginal films going to survive?  It's getting more and more difficult to see interesting, intelligent genre films that don't feature kung-fu fights and machine gun battles between their new ideas.Guess it will continue to get tougher.  I am at least one person who will continue to support and love intelligent and progessive genre cinema.Hope there's more like me.

Just watched this again. I know it's popular to use Soderbergh as a punching bag for folks' unrealized filmic ambitions, and to venerate the also-excellent (intellectual, but sorely pretentious) Russian version, but a serious, unselfconcious look at this picture shows that it's a true work of art, and one of the best, most thoughtful science fiction films ever produced. I've seen it a number of times now, and it is a movie that completely understands itself, understands the depth of the questions it's asking, and pays respect to the audience in the simple, lyrical terms of pure film. Clooney is marvelous, and doubly so for overcoming his inherent recognizability. A lovely piece of work.

All I knew of the movie in advance had been some short reviews and a brief look on the website. So I was really not expecting a science fiction spectacle like ID4 or STTNG. I guess I was hardly expecting anything at all. And this was good!I guess reviews and opinions have been somewhat controversial, I acknowledge that in several theatres people have moved out on the movie. Not so in the screening I attended. The cinema was packed with people (O.K. merely 150 seats), they were even sitting on the stairway! Nobody left during the movie, and at least half the people stayed until the very end of the credits. Now that is a scene I do not experience too often!I quickly agreed with my girlfriend that this movie was truly a piece of art - some 30 seconds into the movie. And we were not at all disappointed. I might compare it to `Out of Sight', another Soderbergh/Clooney feature that I like very much but actually many people do not. And of course some comparison to 2001 imposed itself. I liked very much how this movie challenged my spirit and provoked my thoughts.I am not going to recite the storyline, but I have to say I was deeply touched by the tragic of `new' Rheyas consciousness. Her urge to know what and who she was. And the sudden realization not to know whether anybody was `himself' anymore. Finalized by Chris' concern not to have remembered Rheya rightly.In no means this movie is fast paced or swift. It takes its time and gives the viewer time to orientate himself or - more likely -  to experience the disorientation of the characters. I was a little afraid the movie might conclude in some action feature shoot-out or similar. Fortunately this was not the case. The movies draws the complete circle back to the beginning and eventually leaves the viewer in awe.Finally I would like to express my sincere appreciation for the movies photography and editing. The focus/blur effects really contributed to center my attention. The choice of camera angels also did involve me so much more than the usual depictures of scenes. And the edited sequence of shots and scenes built just the right tension.A 9 out of 10! Really great, great cinema!

Absolutely nothing happens in this movie. Some flashbacks of couple's time together and it ends where it started. (This isn't even a spoiler because seriously - nothing happens in this movie).What did I just watch? A complete waste of time. Save yourself.

this movie is an excellent example about how trying to create art can totally mess up a great story basicly the movie is a serie of incoherent sequences and at the end you still have no idea what the movie is really about, if you can call it a movieas a scifi loving person this movie was an insult for my eyes people looking for a romantic movie might like it but if you are looking for good scifi this is not a movie you like to see

Review title: I thought it was very thought provoking...
Review_body: ********Warning Spoilers Ahead***************I'm taking it to be a message about our existence--what is god?  why are we here anyway?  what is reality?  There were obvious parallels to our own circumstances in that Rheya ponders her existence--knows she has been created by the planet--but doesn't for what purpose and cannot communicate with her creator.  I thought it had a 'spirituality' message--I even think I saw the old "God in the Sistine Chapel" shot at the end when Kelvin reaches out to the little boy.Also, maybe it was also a closer look at the human condition.    Juxtapose Kelvin's reaction at his wife's abortion, and later, shooting wife copy no. 1 into space. The message being your morality can and will change, depending on your circumstances.  I also like that Kelvin is human--and not one dimensional.  Its refreshing actually to see a bit of weakness in a "hero". I think that whole 'don't tell copy no. 1' stuff is hilarious.I liked the Kubrick-ey space shots--what else can you do? I'll think of them as 'tributes'--of course, the space station was the best and most realistic ever.  The soundtrack was good.I like that there are questions unanswered.  Like the 'formula' isn't that dead people from your past come back to life--cause Snow makes a copy of himself...we don't know what Gordon's visitor is, and doesn't Gibarian's son exist on earth?  Kelvin copies himself--so maybe he was a copy already when he got there?  Who knows?I always like sublety and get annoyed when I am hit on the head with the 'answers'.So for me I took away alot from the movie--the who are we and what are we doing here anyway theme.  They didn't attempt to answer the question--the whole point was to pose the question.  As individuals, we have to answer that one ourselves in our own way.and like the characters in the movie--its probably unanswerable.

I rented this film, then did some last minute Christmas shopping. While I was gone, my husband watched the first half of "Solaris" and turned it off - twice. He then watched "Terminator 3," which he enjoyed.After he went off to bed. I started "Solaris." Unlike my husband, I was hooked from the start, and thoroughly enjoyed being reeled in. This is what I look for in a film - a compelling, nuanced story, involving complex characters. Perhaps it appealed to me more than to some, because I have lost several loved ones in recent years, including my father who died three years ago today, and am therefore wrestling with the same questions pondered in the film. Or perhaps I'm just a sucker for a good story, deftly told.I don't think we would have necessarily had a better or worse film had Cameron written the screenplay, merely a different film altogether. I give him more credit than many on this board, as "The Abyss" is and remains a favorite film of mine, and only defied the laws of physics a few times. ;-) Certainly "The Abyss" is a quieter and more introspective film than the Terminator series, but then again, the films do examine the same themes. It might have been interesting to see what Cameron would have done with "Solaris," hopefully sans car chases.Personally, I am glad Soderbergh wrote this version, as there is very little I would change. I enjoyed every minute of it. The musical score captured and enhanced the atmosphere quite well. I remember hearing about the original "Solaris," which came out the year I started high school, but I never saw it. Having now seen this version, I'll make it a point to do so, and I'll read the book as well. I will definitely be adding this film to my collection.As for my husband, I probably won't recommend that he see it right away. Instead, I'll let him see it over time, as he did "The Shipping News," which also put him off initially. Once he got past the move to Newfoundland, he began to understand the humor I saw in the film, but he still despises its more depressing aspects. Still, he considers my taste in films weird, and to date understands neither my love for "Jacob's Ladder" nor my devotion to "Six Feet Under."But then, he doesn't like jazz, either. ;-)

Boring, boring, boring!!!!!!! A crime to sci-fi! A very very cheap copy from Even Horizon. Without blood, without horror, without capable actors, without... a plot. Was expecting a lot from the movie. Completely disappointed.

I have not seen the original...yet. So no comparison here. The whole movie I was thinking "this is flat" "this has no depth". Great visuals, score is only so-so. Acting was subdued, on purpose no doubt. Then came the positive but detached feeling afterwards. The is a mildly uplifting movie but in a out-of-body-feeling way. Watch it. Hang with it until the end. A nice job all the way around and a movie the feels like nothing else I've seen.

To say that this movie surprised me more than any I have ever watched, is an understatement. Solaris is one of the best films ever made about the power of memory, the ways we deal with pain and the unknown, and how real love is transcendent.The music and visuals (especially of Solaris itself) are hauntingly visceral in a way I can't even completely convey. The cast is dead on perfect. The story is a very simplified, economic version of the original (which in this case works just fine) and deals more with the human factor than the science. It's a shame that more people couldn't get into this movie and disliked it because it didn't meet their expectations of what a science fiction should be; Solaris dealt with consequence, love, perception, fear, reason, spirituality, and death in a way that some of the most brilliant pure dramas have never even come close to capturing. This is one of the best sci-fi films ever made and hardly anyone seems to know about it. To call it underrated is an insult to an underrated movie. Solaris has been overlooked completely, even within the sci-fi community. Of those that did see it, many didn't really get what the film is about. (I blame the marketing campaign for that to some degree, trying to sell an action or horror sci-fi movie when this film was neither of those things.) They couldn't embrace the subtle, constant tension and unconventional, subversive, underlying themes. Spiritual science fiction is one way to describe it. A haunting, hard journey of man facing his memory, his "sins" made flesh, literally. Solaris is painfully insightful about relationships and the way we remember events and people to a degree that again, words can't capture. The end of Kelvin's journey is something that people can talk about again and again, trying to figure out what really happened to him.Did he ever finally get "home"?

I had high expectations for this George Clooney movie. What disappointment. The acting was wooden and the plot - what exactly was the plot again? Clooney should buy all copies if this movie and burn them.

Review title: did the SOLARIS infection get back to Earth?
Review_body: In the USA version, they have a space station monitoring an astronomical phenomenon (named SOLARIS). NASA is running out of money so they sell the project to private enterprise, which thinks they can develop the space-station into a resort complex holiday hotel.It turns out that the astronomical phenomenon, SOLARIS is an intelligent being, that is able to materialize the most vivid memories of the space station scientists. The dead person they were closest to. Referred to as the visitors.They don't know why SOLARIS is doing this, but obviously to try and study the humans that are there, to study 'it'.George Cluney's dead wife appears as his visitor.The twist is that the scientist that sounds like he is on drugs, is actually the dead twin brother (visitor) that "SOLARIS " created from the original. When the visitor appeared in front of his brother there was a struggle because they did not know what was happening. The original was killed and the visitor took his place without anyone knowing.The black woman scientist is experimenting on her visitor, locked in her room. She tries to find ways to kill her visitor, but the visitor is able to resurrect. She makes an energy particle accelerator that disrupts the molecular bonds that keeps the visitor intact (and also seems to resurrect them), so they can't heal.The plan is to pilot the space station back to Earth, but they must eradicate the visitors first, because they don't know what would happen if they went to Earth. They cannot be allowed to infect Earth.The visitor (twin brother of the drugged out scientist) who is piloting the space-station in orbit around SOLARIS, does not tell them that the energy particle accelerator has drained the space-station fuel cells and it is about to crash into SOLARIS, until they discover he is a visitor.The black woman and George Cluney only have minutes to escape in the small space ship that George Cluney arrived in.George Cluney imagines his life back on Earth and seems to be living it at the same time as showing us that he may have stayed in the doomed space-station.As he lives his monotonous Earth life, he cuts his finger and we see it heals by itself and then his dead wife appears. He asks the question 'how can you be here, am I alive?' They changed the ending from the Russian film, to give closure. Basically they stuffed the ending, because they could have edited it a bit better so that we did not know if he stayed on the space-station or travelled back to Earth. So his wife appearing at the end could have meant that he either died at SOLARIS and imagined he escaped, or he escaped to Earth but brought the SOLARIS infection to Earth.

I really missed the depth in this remake of Solaris. Scientist not interested in exploring, just in holding on to what they have got. The 1971 version left the viewer baffled with questions, guessing about reality. This version does not. The final scene is a poor attempt to have a happy Hollywood ending. It left me with a dreadful empty feeling.

One of the few contemporary films I can't watch without crying my eyes out. I read the book and saw the Russian film in my teens, but they didn't have the same impact as Soderbergh's interpretation of Solaris. He chooses to study a human relationship more than the science(-fiction) elements, we won't find out what this celestial body is or what it wanted in the end. Not that it'd matter. "There are no answers, only choices" as one character says in the film. I wonder if Aronofsky's The Fountain will be as heart wrenching... There are too few true sci-fi films today. Granted, Tarkovsky's Solyaris is overkill on the art department :)

This movie intrigued me for some time. But upon realizing what the movie is about, I was disappointed in the message. First I see the beings do not breathe. The resurrections are referred to with disgust. The other team is not correct about flesh and bone inheriting the kingdom. Yes blood is sacred but its not dirty. We will rule on the earth for the 1000 years but everything will be wonderful. Hard for some who lack appreciation for the new opportunity, but hey, free will comes at a cost.

Review title: There's a reason this DVD only cost me five dollars
Review_body: Despite a big name for the lead role and a cool concept, this movie failed to hold my attention for more than 8 minutes at a time. So he's a psychologist, and somehow, somewhere, mankind has developed a space station orbiting a planet. Where is this planet? How did he get there in under 40,000 years? Are all psychologists qualified astronauts in the future? Why don't we ever get to see the alien-vaporizer doohickey in action? Why do we have too see George Clooney's ass and not his hot wife's? It's very likely one or all of these questions were answered during this movie, but I couldn't watch it without getting distracted. From the start, I knew at least one or more of the people on the space station weren't real.It's one of those movies where the director and writers make everything confusing so at the end you'll be like, "Whoa, what a mind f%&*!" and then you'll watch it again so the pieces fall into place better. However, with this movie, it's just confusing, and it was so dry and boring that you really don't give a crap to watch it again to see if it makes more sense.Somewhat cool camera work and decent ambient music where the only redeeming qualities. And why do a remake of a movie if the original wasn't that interesting to begin with?

There are a number of good things about this movie, but ultimately it felt to me like a lost opportunity. It raised provocative psychological issues but never carried me away or led me to anything like an epiphany. In the latter half, I was in fact a bit bored. It certainly isn't enthralling like Tarkovsky's version. Rheya's character is better developed, particularly her own psychological trauma in being a "creation" (Tarkovsky's Rheya was something of a naif in comparison). But what I missed from Tarkovsky's version is the sense of humor (this one is stiflingly earnest) and the evocative and poignant use of Bach chorales in the soundtrack. The soundtrack to this one is intriguing (a la Brian Eno, Ligeti, and Thomas Newman's scores for The Player and American Beauty), but I eventually found myself desperately longing for a cadence. Lacking the feeling of redemption communicated musically in Tarkovsky's version, this one had to rely on ham-handed statements of fact. And finally, I can't help remarking that neither Tarkovsky nor Soderbergh really convey the element of shame and sexual deviance that played such an important part in Lem's original. Both place the emphasis instead on guilt, which isn't quite the same thing, is it?

I think Jack is very generous. What can those of you be thinking about when you rate this 8, 9, or 10! What is the point of this move? The characters are not compelling, the plot barely moves, and the movie is visually uninteresting. The audience has but one desire - a quick ending.This is one of the worst movies I've ever seen.

I saw the original in the 70's and liked it very much.  In fairness to the original, I should see it again, but based on my recollection of it this remake is much better.  Clooney and McElhone are wonderful.  Soderbergh should be well on his way to Oscar nominations for best direction and screenplay, and so should Clooney for best actor.  I was struck at how emotionally moved I was while watching this film.  I had tears streaming down my face at times.  This came as quite a surprise.The screenplay is wonderfully ambiguous.  There may be strong spiritual, mystical, and religious undercurrents at work here.  But, then again, maybe not.  I expect this film will generate a good deal of discussion. Without giving too much away, I wonder how many saw the reference to "Adam and God" painting of the Sistine Chapel?This is a fabulous film.  It goes right up to the top of my list of favorite sci-fi films.  Truly serious sci-fi films are rare.  I hope this film goes on to become a major critical and financial success.George

I expected so much more from Steven Soderbergh and James Cameron.  This movie was slow from the first scene and never picked up speed.  I felt there were several holes in the story and the ending was confusing.  I hope Clooney's next movie is better.

Solaris is a unique event film that will alienate many multiplex'ers who will stray in by accident.  Fox has little idea how to market this earnest meditation on loss, and the prescreening I attended was plagued by continuous walk-outs. This picture should not have opened wide like a Jurassic Park sequel, but rather platformed in New York, L.A. and then outwards.While audiences will surely divide on the overall merits of Solaris, the final twenty minutes are among the most compelling committed to film.

Visually: Interesting. Nice contrast from the mechanical, stiff, spaceship interior and curvasious organic forms of Solaris and the hot chick with the big eyes.Concept: ..almost there, just didn't make it somehow.  I buy into the "something missing" post.I think the ending might have killed it.cc2002

Review title: A welcome explosion-free return to good sci-fi
Review_body: I understand those who argue that Solaris is slow-- there's not a single explosion or laser blaster fight in its entire 95 minutes-- but what Solaris lacks in beats per minute it makes up for by returning to sci-fi's philosophical storytelling roots, raising questions of ethics, morality, and mortality, and instilling a sense of wonder about our tiny place in the universe.Overall, Solaris is an excellent and welcome relief from Hollywood's usual botch job in the sci-fi arena.

Review title: pretentious piece of crap, watch the original instead.
Review_body: The original was very good - thoughtful and intelligent. Therefore I was looking forward to this very much - its been a while since we've gotten a 2001 type sci-fi movie, but unfortunetly what I got instead was a big budget artsy student film that constantly pulled me out of the movie every five minutes, thanks to Soderburgh's masturbatory direction. horrible horrible horrible! Go see the original instead. (which is twice as long, slow paced and in a different language but still managed to hold my attention better.)

What the hell was THAT all about? That HAD to be the most DISJOINTED, UNEXCITING, SORRY excuse for a movie that I've seen in a long time. I understand the concept, and I actually believe in another plane of existence. But this movie did nothing to bolster those beliefs. Actually, I'm not REALLY sure WHAT the movie was trying to tell us, except that sometimes you just have to let GO! JEEZ! I thought George Clooney was acceptably attractive, and LOVED the character of Snow. Very quirky, ala Dennis Hopper in Apocolypse Now. But WOW! Enough's enough already. Bottom line . . . BORING!

Review title: A creditable adaptation of a sci-fi classic
Review_body: I was lucky enough to see this film at a UK preview screening followed by an on-stage interview with Steven Soderbergh and George Clooney. However if I didn't like the film, they wouldn't have convinced me otherwise.  Luckily the film was very good, both cinematically and with good acting performances. During the interview, both their comments on Solaris backed up what I had been thinking throughout the film.I admit that it could have been better with more background on the planet itself and what had previously happened, and was perhaps a little too short to do the source material justice. However Soderbergh's  focusing on the relationship between Kelvin and his wife, and his questioning of what was human, did really work. It had echoes of the similar theme in Bladerunner.I didn't surprise me it hasn't done that well in the US, as I can't name any other, non action sci-fi film that has, 2001: A Space Odyssey being the exceptionIn summary I'd rather see Sci-fi films like this, than any number of asteroid blasting gung-ho kill the CGI alien film, that purport to be Sci-fi.  8/10 from me.

What a disappointment!The title of this piece tells it all.The original work was derivative, and this remake takes it to levels of boredom not often seen from movie makers of this supposed ilk.Don't waste your time and money.

Seen the Tarkovsky film, read the Lem novel - all that's irrelevant. Forget re-make bashing and any kind of comparison - it's usually a pointless pursuit for trainspotters. I should know, I am one!I first saw this movie dead-beat on a plane back from New York, very very sleepy and was mostly captivated by the drifting music while I dozed off. That time around I was annoyed by the glamorous looking couple in the movie. However, I wanted to hear the music again so bought the DVD and re-watched it all the way through while wide awake. Now the whole movie seems like one long dream itself, haunting and beautiful. I agree that other movies, and the original movie and book, deal with philosophical issues at greater length, but despite being fairly cold itself, this is a film about emotions and is intensely visual. Lots of sly visual allusions to other films, including obvious ones to 2001, but that always was one crazy hippy movie!Anyway, I would definitely recommend this, 10/10, if you have time, and I agree with another commentator, watch it with your lover/partner! It demonstrates that not all US movies have to be big bucks blockbusters or grungie indie movies - there's room for pure cinema (now what does that mean? :-)

Review title: The most excellent s-f book I've ever read had been turned into... into... have no idea what it has been turned into but it HURTS.
Review_body: I'm traumatized. I need to be sedated or put out of my misery.The most excellent s-f book I've ever read had been turned into... into... have no idea what it has been turned into but it HURTS. They say the movie is 'deep' and 'spiritual'. It could have been if it was something original, if it didn't happen to be based on the book so great and DEEP and SPIRITUAL.So, what was that bad about the movie? Ummmm. EVERYTHING?! 'K, no, George was fine, as he always is. He's not a good actor, he's a great actor but neither him or his buttocks could save Solaris. It died right before my eyes. *sheds a tear* Major SPOILERS to both the movie and The Book.God, I have no idea where to begin with, I don't really have a week to describe all that was wrong. Fine, the main issues would be it: First of all, the movie is a one gigantic chaos. It seems cut, jumps from one time frame to the other, there's no fluentness between scenes. I understand it's deliberate but it's more annoying than anything else. Plus, it really doesn't help that they cut out half of the book and then they hint at us that those things happened but we just didn't witness them. It creates a bloody mess, people! If I didn't read the book I wouldn't have the slightest clue what is going on! And no, it's not the typical 'if we showed it, we wouldn't have time to show the rest' case, because they have time for those pointless flashbacks and George's naked buttocks... ... ...ok, can't blame them for THAT.Yes, babes, they cut out everything about Solaris!!! What the ...!?!?!?! The book was about it, just look at the title for God's sake. What the hell, tight budget? If you paid George Clooney to show his naked buttocks around, I'm sure you could find a penny or two for some special effects. I wanted to see symetriads! And mimics! You just can't take Hamlet, decide that he can go and make the play without him. O_o Perhaps that makes me so angry. I LOVED SOLARIS - The Ocean, loved the theories, the musings, the mystery, the thrill, the unknown... but all I got was a dull romance/pseudo-psychological thingy. I had 4 favorite scenes and hoped that at least one will make it to the movie. It did not.Other things they changed? Well, that's the thing. Parts of the movie were fascistically accurate with the book, while lots of those so called Significant Details were changed. Names. They changed names. Why?! They changed sexes. WHY?! They changed Fat Black Woman into The Son but that I expected to happened. They TOTALLY changed the ending The only good thing, really, because I was not pleased with the ending in the book, seems like there was none but the fact that it turned that in here we've got A Hollywoodish Happy Ending made my stomach turn. The thing about the book was that from the beginning we were aware that Happy Ending is not possible and here? Oh, blah! Hahaha, know what really is amusing? Apparently, in the movie, the answer to everything is the fact that Solaris is alive. Well, in the book we find out about that on the 3rd page, we are just not sure what kind of 'life' is that. Is Solaris super-intelligent or is this some primordial soup? Is it the end of the evolutionary journey or just the beginning? Is it evil? Good? Can we even use those terms to describe it? What does it want? Does it want anything at all? What are we to it? Is it even aware of our presence? We don't get he answers, just theories and in the movie? 'OMG! What's going on?!' 'It's Solaris, it's alive' 'Oh, that explains everything' *headdesk* I could survive everything, the changes, the ending, the chaos but I will never forgive them, that they turned such intelligent, interesting, fascinating and thrilling story into a bad romance.One more thing, Dear People That Turned The Book Into The Movie.Next time, if you get confused what the book is about, look at the title, it might give you a clue. The book was called 'Solaris' for a reason, the main reason being Solaris, which the book was about. The title of the book was not, I repeat, it was not 'How I Met Loved My Wife'. If it still doesn't help, TRY ASKING THE AUTHOR WHAT HE MEANT BY IT, OK?!

There's little point in me repeating what so many others have already said well enough.I didn't know what to expect from this film the first time I saw it, but as the credits rolled I was left with that great feeling of satisfaction at having been entertained by a film that is deep, challenging, emotive and thoroughly entertaining. I took away a lot from this film and did a fair bit of pondering.Reactions in the room were mixed. One friend just laughed out loud with a look that suggested he just didn't get any of it, and had been thoroughly bored. I personally don't understand how you can't get this film, but it demonstrates that it's not for everyone. Then again, I know people who never once laughed at The Big Lebowski, so...Maybe it's me getting old and sentimental, but I found the interplay between Chris and Rheya, both in the past and on the space station to be quite beautifully written and acted. Through snapshots of their relationship and her growing recall of events leading to her death, you are treated to a subtly understated but powerful insight into their relationship. I found watching them through the flashbacks to be tender, touching, romantic and tragic. It's quite gently understated and softly underplayed by Clooney and McElhorne. For me, it's rare to be moved in such a way.Others have remarked on the great existential themes within Solaris, so I won't bang on about them. Suffice to say, this should be in anyone's collection. Show it to your kids and make their brains and hearts swell.

Movie buffs should note one thing before watching Solaris: this is not a remake of Tarkovsky's masterpiece. This is a movie based on Stanislaw Lem's novel Solaris, and as such, much closer to the novel than Tarkovsky's movie. Tarkovsky could, at best, be said to be "inspired by" the novel. But comparing the two would be like comparing "Star Trek: Insurrection" to "Apocalypse now", simply because they were both inspired by the same novel ("Heart of Darkness").Those looking for a grand space opera, complete with laser beams going Whizz and space ships exploding with ear-deafening booms, are also in for disappointment. This is a drama, which happens to be set in a fairly distant future. As with the best of literary science fiction, it is about people, and about here and now, although the story works by introducing elements that we don't have in the world around us today.The pace is slow, the acting is brilliant, the story is powerful. And the title of my review compares it to "2001", since it tells us just how utterly, utterly alien an alien world will be. The trailer actually says most of what you need to know: "There are places where mankind is not ready to go".

I enjoyed this movie.  I thought George was wonderful.  I also liked Jeremy's character.  I go to the movies to be entertained.  And I was most definitely entertained with this one.  There was enough science fiction in the movie to appeal to me without turning me off.

I loved this movie, I just gave it a 9 out of 10. I could see how some people may get hung up on the pacing, especially if you are used to shoot-em-up type movies. This is not a typical Hollywood plot, so it may confuse 7 out of 10 viewers. I thought it was a masterpiece however. Great directing, visually stunning, great acting, great emotional depth, and what a plot!If you like movies that are not predictable, that you can't figure out what is going to happen from the first five minutes of the film, then I would recommend this movie to you. If you are the type that likes very formulaic plots where there is a good guy and a bad guy, and in the end the good guy wins and saves the world, then this movie is maybe not for you.

Review title: A thoughtful, romantic, lovely tone poem
Review_body:
Before I saw Solaris, I thought the movie poster (featuring George Clooney kissing his co-star) might be misleading.  However, the film turned out to be very romantic, as well as intensely philosophical and beautifully shot.
Clooney continues to choose challenging roles and quality material, and director Soderbergh continues to prove his "auteur" status.  This film is entertaning while you are viewing it, and then it stays with you afterwards in an eerie, yet thought-provoking way.Overall, a fine film that may not appeal to the kiddies, but should please many deep-thinking adults.  Hardcore sci-fans should also enjoy this work a great deal.
