Review title: Shorter and more direct than the original
Review_body: This is one of those movies that gives me that sci-fi feeling I like, more so than the original Solaris (or Solyaris). The reason is much because of the newer effects and visual appeal, but mostly because of it's shorter more direct approach, you could say more commercialised, which here I don't believe is a bad thing. Also for Solaris (2002) avoiding to elaborate too much makes Solaris (2002) more thrilling than the original.I have given both the 2002 and 1972 version an 8 of 10 stars. The original Solyaris is longer and the philosophical aspect is more elaborate, and I DO think it is better in many aspects. But for me the shorter more direct approach of Solaris (2002) gives it the upper edge.

I watched this pretty much straight after watching 'The Hours' so that may be the reason I did not find Solaris as boring as many of the comments previously have mentioned. It's a pretty cute film that tries really hard to be clever but without being cheesy. It asks a few questions of life that make you think... Theres a lot of questions unsolved in regards to the plot which are slightly annoying, might reveal more in the book I guess.

Review title: Could have been so much better... (Spoilers)
Review_body: It takes a brave man to follow Tarkovsky's answer to 2001 and Steven Soderbergh is that at least. First, the good: the film looks beautiful and the score lulls you into a relaxed, observatory state of mind. The cast are attractive and the worst of the anachronisms of Lem's book have been removed. There is actually a resolution to the movie and it is far more emotionally literate than either of the originals. Saying that there is much that has been messed about with to very little effect other than to ruin the intended plot. The essence of Solaris (the book) is an exploration into Man's (I do not mean to imply gender here) method of scientific analysis and how fallible that approach would be for an intelligence that exceeded their own. The only meaningful dialogue with the vast sentience that is Solaris comes from Kelvin's unresolved regret for the loss of Rheya, his love for her and the transmission of his unconscious thoughts to the planet itself. In this adaptation (mega-spoilers here): - Solaris itself appears never to have been studied or visited and the whole idea of the 'living sea' is lost.'Coroporations' (very 21st century and totally irrelevant to the plot) want to own Solaris as 'a possible energy source'. Again, why? This is both impossible (Steven do you understand *anything* about physics?) and detracts from one of the central points about the book which is Man's pure academic struggle to understand an intelligence greater than their own. The entire space station's library in the original(s) were devoted to decades of study into the phenomenon of Solaris. In the mythology of the book the planet has formed whole schools of thought and analysis - all lost hereBerton is lost from the plot and his son becomes Gibarian's. This character then becomes the representative of the planet. Neither the book or the Tarkovsky version needed this device so why do we in this film?Snow (Snaut) has become an alien. Why? It was not necessary to the plot. The planet never knowingly killed before (Jeremy Davies is definitely vying for the most irritating portrayal of a character ever.) There are rumours that this film was butchered for theatrical release and I sincerely hope that this was the case!

What about the Soderbergh's film? What are the good and the bad points of the movie? Lem: l though I admit that Soderbergh's vision is not devoid of ambition, taste and climate, I am not delighted with the prominence of love. Solaris may be perceived as a river basin - and Soderbergh chose only one of its tributaries. The main problem seems the fact that even such a tragic-romantic adaptation seems too demanding for mass audience fed with Hollywood pap. If in the future someone else dared a faithful adaptation, I am afraid the effects would be understood only by a tiny audience.I read the book, and I think that in fact that book is about the unattainable, and inconceivable. More of the unattainable love, than Lem himself said. It is in the subconscious of the book. I really loved Soderbergh's film.It's about God too.

The movie was great. Soderberg made a great film. I love the eeriness and the slow movement of the film. This movie has done a very good job of capturing the mood of the novel. I read quiet a few reviews here that are crying about the movie being slow and hard to understand. If you want an easy to watch sci fi film , go see Nemesis (not to say that Nemesis is a not a great movie, it is). Then there are those of you who start dissing the novel. Solaris is considered one of the greatest sci fi novels of our time, so to call it second rate sci fi is just plain stupid. As for the film, this movie did something that I hoped it would, it took a portion of the book and adopted it into a fantastic, artistic film, full of psychological twists, great acting and spectacular cinematography. To recreate the book to the t is simply impossible. The genious of this book is that for the large part it happens in the mind. So no two people will see this story in the same way. It is also wrong to say that Soderberg was trying to compete with 2001 some how. Just because this is a psychological movie that happens in space does not make it a rip-off of 2001. This movie was about half the book, and i understand why. If the whole book was to be made into the movie, the film would be way too long to show in a theater. Overall, this movie was done very well, I love the book and I love the movie. To those of you who haven't seen this movie I advise the following: if you're looking to see another installment of 2001, don't go, if you're looking to see a Trek type film, don't go, if you're looking to see a picture that is nothing like you've ever seen before and which will seem different every time you watch it, while being very uncommericial, mesmorising and brilliantly made, GO SEE IT !!! 10 stars.

Review title: A rather dull film with some redeeming qualities
Review_body: Solaris has a runtime of roughly 90 minutes without logos and credits. Still, many of those precious minutes are spent on numerous stylized flashback sequences. Most of these definitely serve a purpose but take entirely too long and aren't particularly exciting to watch, being mostly dark and dim. Some of them feel arbitrary and purposefully stretched to boost the length of the film.It seems like Steven Soderbergh went out of his way to avoid exposition through dialogue, possibly out of fear of having it be too obvious or condescending. A lot of time is wasted on showing the audience that George Clooney is some kind of shrink. Yet, by the time he sets foot aboard the spaceship, we still have no idea what Solaris actually is or what kind of mission the crew is conducting. Simply knowing that might have greatly increased my enjoyment of the first half. The deliberate vagueness does not contribute to the sense of mystery at all, it just makes the characters less believable for not seeming all that bothered by it.Some credit is due for the way in which Soderbergh manages to portray the rather philosophical subject matter and have the characters explore and discuss it without breaking our suspension of disbelief. That being said, since none of this is technically original material, I think it's appropriate to base my rating mostly on artistic considerations. Intellect has little to do with one's enjoyment of this movie. It's definitely no Star Wars, but it's no 2001 either. It doesn't take a common man to get annoyed by the inconsistent pacing and dullness.

Review title: Terrible Film-making (Warning: This comment contains spoilers)
Review_body: Solaris is not a sequel, its not an action/adventure/science-fiction film or fantasy like A Star Wars or Terminator. It is way beyond opposite of all that. It is more of a dramatic, mysterious, romantic adventure in the future when a planet known as solaris is a place of energy. An energy source that would be able to contain a world with highly advanced, unwastefull or unpolluting energy. The energy source ends up being used for Earth, which brings our planet to a futuristic and highly advanced and sophisticated in mathematics and science in the energy's capability. I took the impression thats how Earth was futurelly-like. But this exotic and occasionally sexually active and erotic adventure passes like a wind blowing over a tight swindle.Starring George Clooney, and in definitely one of his most richest roles, he plays unusually in this bizarrely overrated motion picture. He is a hard-to-understand character. But in the beginning he is sent to a space-ship which impressionally is the central station for watching over Solaris. It moves around the planet like a satellite. While making sure the planet's energy is being reflected to Earth for good reasons. Strange and Bizarre activities have been happening on the ship lately. When Clooney gets their, he sees blood and dead people. He also sees blood coming from the vents on the ceiling. He realizes he and a co-pilot are the only ones left on the team. Once there were about seven of them. Clooney eventually asks what had happened, and the guy who really...speaks...like...this (the co-pilot) says a metaphorical statement. And throughout the entire movie, they don't even explain it once, which is one of the film's disappointments. But once clooney sleeps and wakes up in the middle of the night, seeing his wife (who supposedly died) is alive again. Thats where the confusion comes in. It is a mind-bending tale, with very good ideas.It shows a few long 10 minute flashbacks throughout the movie of Clooeny and his wife, their relationships, their romance, including their sex. Also when he brings her on the space station, and how he puts her in a small glass shuttle, and for some odd reason he presses the go button and lets her go off into space while she is still in their. While Clooeny's suspicion of her being dead, she appears back on the ship again. Then a random kid comes up, maybe a 7 year-old-kid. Later on, Clooney see's the co-pilot's dead body in the vents of the ceiling, which is where he had noticed the blood coming from the vents. While the co-pilot hangs out in his room, Clooney realizes that everything is just a memory. His wife who had randomly appeared on the ship was just a memory of what Clooney knows of her. Same goes for the co-pilot. Then Clooney realizes that the random kid is also just a memory. These memories that seem so real is by the strength of solaris which is how the memories are appearing in actual life.When solaris starts to implode, the co-pilot leaves, the girl just disappears, and clooney including the kid just sit in the ship, waiting for solaris to explode and kill them. It is somewhat a sad scene, Clooney's raw intensity in this scene is simply astounding. (personally the best scene of the movie). Then after Clooney dies, he's back at his house, and his wife stands their looking at him.Now, first of all this movie was absolutely the most boring movie I have ever seen. The first 20 minutes are purely raw intensity and deep in entertainment. But the rest is dreary, especially repetitive with sex and nudity. The movie is just about obsessed with it. But it is drenched Win confusion. The deliberation is always slow. The movie is slow. The movie sucks. It is the worst movie I have ever seen. Definitely up for the razzies. If you're expecting drama, expect MAJOR drama. Because it is an orall experience. These are good ideas with a terrible execution.Secondly, critics are idiots. Thye apparently loved this movie. You can see how, but I thought it was patchy, dry, dull, soulless, heartless, slow, weak, boring, and terrible. Whenever someone mentions this movie (which people never really do) I'll just laugh. Its lame. Its not anyones kind of movie, its easy to fall asleep in. What kind of a story is this. Its not even interesting. And having solaris' explosion is a lot bigger of a situation than how they should of reacted. Leaving isn't the answer. It is the Earth's frickin power source. Ultimately the world would fall apart. And the last scene was terrible. Made me feel even worse for this movie, the world is still alive, and it shows the wife appear again. Did Clooney die or just appear back at home? either way, the direction was awful, same with James Cameron's writing.THE WORST MOVIE I HAVE EVER SEEN.1/10 -- if it can go lower: 0/10.

I viewed Tarkovsky's 'Solaris' when it first came out in Moscow in about 1970/71. I admired it, but felt that it suffered from ennuie (tedium) during much of the middle. I have also read Lemm's novel. I was worried that the American version would replace its poetic philosophical style with something more action-driven. How relieved I was to view a loyal work, in pace, mystery and intelligence.! And to witness George Clooney acting with introspection, instead of cruising with his charming smile.

Review title: An artsy romantic tragedy on a sci-fi backdrop with visual and musical parallels to 2001.
Review_body: An artsy romantic tragedy on a sci-fi backdrop with visual and musical parallels to 2001.  This is a quiet and sedate movie with no explosions or violent outbursts - Jerry Bruckheimer could never have made this film.  It has intelligent and fallible characters - which is to say, believable characters, well acted.  The pace of the movie is leisurely -slow, never forced, but towards a definite conclusion.  I am surprised the studio ponied up the amount of money necessary for the well-done sci-fi effects and futuristic set design.  Doubtless having the well-known Clooney made them believe it would be a worthy gamble.  And though Clooney carries his character well, the intelligent and meditative tone to the movie almost ensures it will not be seen or distributed nearly as much as it should.

Every so often a movie comes along just like this one, a movie that hits some people deeply while causing others to scratch their head in boredom and confusion. For me, I know I liked the movie. Although I can still not figure out everything that went on, I know that I liked it. For me a movie is good if it stays with me beyond the theater. This film, and other recent films like Mulholland Drive, Memento, Fight Club, Punch-Drunk Love, and Donnie Darko has taken up much of my thinking time out of the theatre.Although in most of those movies events occur that sometimes do not make much sense, the overall movie draws you in to its complexity and makes you think outside of a theatre. The film evolves from being a simple escape into an experience, sometimes that might change the way you think about a certain aspect of your life. Such is Solaris. If you are capable and willing to lend some of your time outside the theatre to think about what went on in the movie, give it a try. It'd recommend it highly. But if all you need is a quick escape, go see Bond. **** out of *****

Review title: It's about time a good film can be seen in theaters
Review_body: Even better than the original, Soderberg brings amazing camera work along with good editing and great storytelling. People with less amount of IQ would probably not be able to understand where the movie is going, however these types of films, similar to Kubric's 2001 are made once every ten or fifteen years. If you are an action film lover you won't like this film so don't waste your time, this is also not a film for kids. Soderberg's amazing use of short focal lens throughout the film works very well with the narrative of the film. Most of you won't like it but this film will be remembered in ten-twenty years.

This is a beautifully shot movie with some very interesting themes.  It questions the limits of human knowledge as well as common belief that our mental constructs such as "designing", "creating" and "destroying" can and should be applied to the whole universe and all of existence.The movie illustrates these ideas through a largely romantic based story.For anyone who enjoys science and philosophy, I completely recommend this film!

Review title: Traffic, grocery lines or dentist anyone...?
Review_body:
Anyone accustomed to living in a large metropolitan area is familiar with the agonizing delays of traffic and waiting in long grocery lines; Universally, everyone has probably had some experience waiting for the dentist to finish his/her job......These my friends, are far more interesting than waiting for something to happen in the 2002 remake of Solaris. In fact, if you happen to be stuck in traffic on your way to see the movie and you only make it in time to see the closing credits.....you have most definitely seen the best the movie has to offer.The concept is clearly an intriguing one. The exploration of the depths of the human mind, heart and soul....The possibilities that may exist in the after-life and within the unexplored portions of the Universe as we know it...These thematic elements skillfully woven and executed, could have made for a masterpiece. Sadly, what you end up with is akin to having a 1000 piece jigsaw puzzle, only the pieces you are given are from ten different puzzles and never come close to creating a whole picture.
Not even worth watching on cable.

++ fascinating premise, keeps you thinking but is not too mysterious++ finally a movie that isn't afraid to turn off the "this is how you're supposed to feel" soundtrack and let the director, plot and characters do the work!+ wonderful cinematography, effects, and soundtrack+ 2001: A Space Odyssey references+ "Snow" character - interesting characterization, great portrayal. decent actingplot is a little thinslow paceabrupt endingOverall: Worth seeing, esp. for SciFi fans, but be in a mellow mood.  Not for the masses.  Despite its short length, it's still too long due to the slow pace, yet manages to leave you with a feeling like you've just eaten a rice cake - "where's the substance?"  For all the hype about it being confusing, i found it fairly straightforward.

When I saw the coming attractions for Solaris, I was dumbstruck.  I've be a long-time fan of Stanislaw Lem, and I'd never seen the earlier film version. I couldn't image how anyone could hope to take any of Lem's works, let alone Solaris, and make a film of it.  Having seen it, I have to admit that I'm pleasantly suprised.  While it's not exactly a faithful representation, it is a deeply atmospheric interpretation of the story.  George Clooney continues to impress me with his emotionally moving performance of Chris Kelvin, and Natascha McElhone is astonishing as his wife, Rheya.  Although I knew that I had to see this film, I had serious doubts going into it.  It may not be everyone's cup of tea, but in my opinion, by daring to create a film outside of the mainstream that interacts with the audience on an almost entirely emotional level, Mr. Soderbergh has made an important contribution to his art.  Solaris is a certifiable success.

Movies where half the audience gets up and walks out are automatically Champions. This is a spectacular film, and were it not for Equilibrium finally being released this year, this would be #1 for 2002.Were I God, there would be a special section of heaven reserved for those who dug this film.There is a sequence near the end revolving around Clooney's possible return to Earth from the station that may be the most beautiful thing I've seen on film.

An excellent movie. I found it quite moving throughout, with mature performances from all the actors (though there are only half a dozen people in it) and the best work I've seen from Clooney. I haven't read the book or seen the original but I can't imagine doing so would spoil this movie in any way. The film manages to perfectly achieve the tense atmosphere of the investigation into the mystery of existence around Solaris, and the heartache this causes the people there. The actual sci-fi is quite subdued in the movie, and this just made it more realistic for me personally (though this is the first time I've seen a Higgs field mentioned on-screen). I'm not convinced everyone in the future will wander around explaining all their technological marvels all the time like in some sf movies, and doing so just detracts from the storyline. Having the sci-fi restricted to the scenery and concentrating on the story produces a much more involving and thought provoking film.

All I can say is those that walked out halfway though (and there were a number) missed out on a beautiful experience.Visually wonderful, with excruciatingly beautiful moments of silence, and a great supporting sound track .Visually, I was reminded of 2001 : A Space Odyssey, with the atmosphere of Mr Soderbergh earlier Sex Lies & Videotape.A credible attempt at bring to the screen, what was a wonderful book. (I can't comment on how it compares with the 1972 Solyaris as I have not seen it).For those into that kind of thing you also get a good long look at George Clooney's butt.I will definitely be buying the DVD

Review title: Much better than I thought it would be.
Review_body: I haven't read the book, nor have I seen the original film adaptation. But the story seemed to be consistent, so it appears to stand alone well. There were no inconsistencies in the plot that I saw.I can't remember a Sci-Fi film, apart from 2001, which was realistic (and daring?) enough to not have sound effects when in space.Clooney and McElhone were superb. Especially McElhone. Though I don't think I've seen Clooney in such a dramatic role before.The ending was good, even though I don't like "happy endings" as a rule.I loved the music. Although there seemed to be only two main pieces, they were wielded well.The friend I saw it with thought it was boring in places. But he wanted to see "Equilibrium". He didn't understand the ending so I enjoyed explaining it to him. He also didn't understand the incorporation aspect of the "visitors". Perhaps others will have the same problem.

Review title: For those who see "meaning" in the absence of any.
Review_body: Some films take a compelling concept, and create a story that is moving, poignant, meaningful and thought-provoking.  Other films are unabashed entertainment to thrill the masses.  And then there are films like SOLARIS. Films made for only one reason: to satisfy the egos of filmmakers who actually think they're saying something.It has become its own genre.This last kind of film has a small but earnest following.  And you can bet their audience will find meaning in ANY tale.  But you can also bet they'll never agree with each other on what that meaning IS.  Oh, but that's the point, you see.  It's "interpretive".  It's subjective.  We all see different meanings in it.  That's the whole beauty of it, they say.A similar kind of film is David Lynch's MULHOLLAND DRIVE.  And it would seem that people will tend to like or dislike both.  And if you come across someone who LIKES it, don't dare suggest it's awful -- or else it's assumed you're not intelligent enough to "get it". (Or perhaps just not creative enough to have imposed your own meaning upon it -- which, let's face it, if I wanted to WRITE the movie, I wouldn't have come to see YOURS!)Personally, I prefer a story.  I prefer something that makes sense and has a forward motion.  Something that adds up -- ALL of it.  I can go cerebral and make the challenging mental connections along with the best of them.  But SOLARIS and its breed (and their followers) believe that juxtaposing images in a random or lingering fashion -- as long as you have a thread of a story -- makes for some sort of artistic masterpiece.But it doesn't.There are some very nice elements in SOLARIS.  The concept, for one.  I haven't seen the original nor read the book (which shouldn't be required when seeing a film, by the way).  But the story concept is EXCELLENT.  I would have LOVED a well-told version of this thing.Jeremy Davies also gives a dynamic performance (hammy, perhaps, but at least it was fascinating to watch).  Clooney was solid.  McElhone was radiant. Davis was good.  I enjoyed the score and the aesthetically-pleasing cinematography and the expansive set.But when Soderbergh is at the helm of a story that DOESN'T have a clear linear drive (as BROCKOVICH and OCEAN'S both did), you get self-indulgent filmmaking, pure and simple.  TRAFFIC's another example.  Great to look at, excellent acting, nice scenes -- adds up to nothing we hadn't seen on a hundred television shows.  Maybe it's just me, but I find Soderbergh the most consistently overrated director working today (well, alongside Lynch, perhaps).The worst part is that I LOVED the IDEAS behind these films.  I would've liked each of those mentioned here to have been great WITHOUT having ME supply their meanings.  I just wish the filmmakers had done their jobs (tell a story), rather than pander to those few who find meaning where there is none.If that's you, then this is your film.

I continuously warn people that rent this about how bad it is.  They rent the film then come in and tell me, "you're right it was truly awful."  The people that I work with would collectively like to vote for this as the most painfully boring, achingly slow movie of all time. Thank you.

Forgive me if I'm wrong but aren't movies supposed to have plots??  What happen here?? Great director, great actor and great (I'm the king of the world) producer.  I guess too much greatness went to their heads as this movie has neither beginning nor end.  Okay I can take the idea that the movie is slow but please show some suspense.  You know when Chris (George Clooney) sees his wife for the first time he was shocked and afraid that he ships her off into space.  But when he sees her the second time I didn't even care since there was no suspense to build up to that climatic moment. The story is depressing but they could have added some dialogue and some more suspense to keep the audience wondering until the very end. Frankly, by the time the movie ended I didn't even care that happened to these two characters.  Another problem is the other crew members on the space station; we are introduced to them and nothing more.  They might as well not been there.  I guess Steven Soderbergh added them in to add some dialogue to the story.  At least make them interesting.  In an interview Soderbergh said that he hardly used FX so it doesn't take away from the story.  Sorry Steven but there was not story to take away from.

Solaris seems to be a mysterious force that can remake or resurrect people.In a way, it is God, it is the unknown and all that ambiguity!It's a wonderful film to watch because you come away effected by it, not in an obvious way that you can dispense with easily however. I truly felt for the characters and Soderbergh's deft musing on ideas and themes are superb. I got a similar feeling from Sex, Lies.. and also Traffic. The films he make deal with fairly major issues; but seem to really effect the individual characters. Reminds me of Philip K Dick stories in a way. The story rolls out a wonderful pace, fragments of memory from various characters mixed in with visuals of the planet. Did anyone else see the strands across Solaris' surface? Reminded me of brain synapses...in the original one Russian character says something like 'the planet acts like a mind' or something like that. A lovely take on those lines I think. The acting is superb; Clooney is excellent. Who is the 'hairy' guy, who's been 'copied'? I can't remember his name, but he was in another film which had Bono from U2 in it (something Millenium Hotel?). I really enjoyed the soundtrack, really great with the visuals. The first post on this film said that the film was generally a bit dull. I didn't get that feeling at all. Acted superbly, the visuals were very simple and not over bearing. Everything seemed to work well.

I thought it was going to be a great movie when I first started to watch it. But I was about to go to sleep the whole movie, "The beginning" seemed to continued forever. Nothing happened and they got those sick dreams. It felt like the were filming the whole movie on an area of about 10m2. There's a lot greater movies out there to spend your time in front of. But if you want something that makes you go asleep this is the movie for you! The story really sucked, i cant figure how anyone can like this movie!I gave this movie 2/10, a movie as slow like this one don't deserve more.

Review title: One of the great sci-fi films
Review_body: I think this is an incredible film, and definitely ranks alongside my favorite sci-fi movies as well as my favorite movies generally. What is so wonderful about it is its sense of quiet intensity, a feeling that only films of the caliber of "2001: A Space Oddessey" manage to achieve. Also akin to that film it also achieves this wonderful sense of isolation and really create Solaris, the planet, as almost a character in its own right.There is little more I can say except that this film is brilliantly directed and paced, shot with more then a nod or two to Stanley Kubrick and impeccably acted (particularly by Clooney who really defies expectations) But also and most importantly for a sci-fi it is thought provoking and engaging.

I really wanted to like this film but the overall story made it too difficult.The acting was very good but the script was too weak for the actors to compensate.The film tried to delve into George Clooney's character's mental degradation because his deceased wife came back to life. However, he almost immediately accepted her presence and began to defy normal convention--and he was supposed to be a brilliant psychiatrist? Ultimately this movie suffers from lack of script and directorial planning, not from the acting.See this movie if you want, you'll walk away thinking there was suppose to be something more.Still, it is an intelligent effort and well-acted.

I'm not a big fan of Tarkovsky's Solaris. It's not too deep philosophically, although it's stunning visually. Lem himself didn't like Tarkovsky's film, and the reasons are clear. His novel is first of all a _science_ fiction masterpiece about Man and the Unknown, about the limits of science, about science and ethics. Most of the novel's depth was lost or trivialized by Tarkovsky. However, his film is truly haunting visually, and its imagery is unforgettable.Well, it's only by seeing this abomination that I started to really appreciate Tarkovsky. Soderberg's film is an amateurish reenactment of the classic with slightly better lighting and more expensive sets. Its faithfulness to the original is pathetic; it inherits all of the problems of Tarkovsky's film but adds absolutely nothing of its own. It just makes it worse - much worse.It's especially dreadful when you compare the heroine. Tarkovsky's Harey is incredibly beautiful, airy, touching, loving and lovable - she almost made me cry. Soderberg's Rheya is old, ugly, awkward, and delivers her lines with such cheap melodramatism that it made me cringe. In one scene, her saying "Oh my god" twice - with a tear! - was such an unbelievable soap that I nearly vomited.Clooney copies Banionis laboriously but seems to forget that he's supposed to be an actor, and actors don't normally wear such wooden faces. Snow ("Snaut") is actually somewhat funny (the best actor in the entire film, by far), though totally out of place. The black female "Sartorius" is passable but just barely.Perhaps the only reason to remake Solaris now might be to create the real Ocean, with all its complexity and unpredictability, the way it described in Lem's book. Tarkovsky could not do that due to the obvious technical limitations of 1972, and it looks like he wasn't interested in that part of the novel anyway. Yet, it's hard to believe that Solaris of 2003, with all the computer technology and whatnot, shows an even less impressive Ocean than Solaris of 1972. What did they spend the money on, I wonder? One point where Soderberg departed from Tarkovsky is the ending. Tarkovsky's ending, different from that of the novel, was striking and original. Soderberg's ending, different from that of the novel, is silly and soapish.Overall, it all feels like an unfunny parody.

CONTAINS SPOILERS! What an outstanding piece of work. This is pure sci-fi: take a wild concept - what if our memories of lost love ones could become real and take on their own lives? - and then follow the idea to its logical conclusion, as realistically as possible.Despite a slow start this film scores, largely because of the outstanding portrayals of its two central characters, Chris (Clooney) and Rheya (McElhone). Of the two, McElhone is the mesmerising heart of this film, delivering an understated but electrifying performance as a new being struggling to understand what she is, and struggling to negotiate strange memories of her pain-wracked relationship with Chris.The parallel stories of their relationship past and present play out beautifully and almost every scene delivers a thoroughly convincing emotional bombshell. And no, it isn't a chick flick. This is grown-up film-making. It feels a lot like a play - dominated by long conversations between the two main characters. But it never drags and never gets boring. On the contrary, it is totally gripping because it commands such belief in its characters and their situation.Hats off to George for a nuanced, heartfelt performance and for being enough of a professional to give over so much screen time to McElhone. There are long shots here of conversations between these two in which we see nothing of Clooney at all - just McElhone's extraordinarily beautiful, haunting face, studying her reactions as he speaks. And it works. This film will stay with you for days.Highlight: Clooney's anguish when he discovers that Rheya has aborted their child (paralleled at the end when Rheya discovers that he killed her first "copy") - a powerful scene and the kind of acting you rarely see in Hollywood movies. We need more of this stuff.

I tend to believe that movies should be judged on whether or not they accomplish what they set out to achieve. Consequently, When it comes to an adapted screenplay, I think one should try and determine what the Director and/or writer had in mind and then ask "did it work?" Well I may be breaking my own rule now, I have to admit that I don't know what was intended with this movie, beyond trying to make a film out of the novel Solaris. As a result, I can only conclude that they failed. The movie is far from awful, and movies (being the subjective beings they are) can be wonderful or otherwise, depending on the viewer. While I can understand and appreciate people loving this movie for whatever it is, it misses the mark completely when attempting to convey anything that Lem had in mind when he wrote the book. One might say that everything present in the book is in the movie, and this is essentially true, but content isn't all. The book is structured to give the reader a realistic sense of what a truly alien encounter might be like, but the film glazes over this and seems to focus on something else (to be honest, I'm not entirely sure what). Without trying to undermine anyone's interpretation of the movie, I must say it really isn't Sci-Fi at it's best and fails to give any meaningful insight into the infinite possibilities of the genre. Skip this if your a fan of the book or of Sci-Fi in general. See it if everything I just said means nothing to you.

Review title: Starring at the wall for the duration of the film would be better!
Review_body: The film was recommended to me as a great movie. I watched it, full of anticipation only to be greatly disappointed. I admit that at the beginning I found it a little interesting, but that held for only the 5 first minutes at most. Soon it became clear that this movie is not a masterpiece.Still, I fought the urge to stop the film and went through the whole movie, Dozing to sleep about twice or three and then rewinding to continue from where I left off (and I wasn't all that tired). They said it was great didn't they?While the movie poses an interesting situation at the start, it offers no insights, no clues, and no direction. It's more a drift in space with no purpose than a voyage with discoveries. I don't need any answers, but even new questions along the way are missing in this movie. It all looks like a mesh of nonsense that someone put together and justified with something like "Duuhhh, SpAcE!?".Watching the wall for the duration of the film would be much better, even without the popcorn! The deep profound thoughts about life and its meaning I could have indulged in would be a time much better spent.If you have a choice of this movie or anything else, skip the movie. If you don't, well... be strong!
Honestly the film is really boring. it was a pain to get to the end of the film. I will try to see the original hoping it will be better

This movie starts out interesting, but pretty soon it becomes silly, and much more fantasy than sci-fi. The acting is so-so. The script is often stupid/awkward, but sometimes poetic (in a good way). The characters aren't introduced much, and seem unfamiliar and hard to associate with. The movie generally doesn't evoke much emotion, except a few times, mostly because it so often induces disbelief. Certain camera shots (like seeing a character's face) feel unnecessarily long without adding substance, and at the same time, some story aspects are underdeveloped. There is no explanation for how clones of specific dead humans, with their memories, appear out of nowhere. The crew members are certain, by unknown reasons, that it's the planet below that creates them. Of course. And they are not unusually perplexed, amazed or in disbelief. The whole movie feels shallow because of this unrealism. It would have been potentially interesting to learn more about the planet Solaris.Also, more could have been done out of the main character's approach to Solaris. More emotion.At one point the characters discuss how the "visitors" are built. One of the crew members comes up with what is supposed to be a wild guess, the other one programs a particle accelerator (how come they have one on the ship to begin with?) based on that guess, and it just happens to be correct. And again, no questions asked and no explanations. There are multiple such ignored bits in this movie.The mentioned physics is bad too. Bosons do not have anti-particles, and the Higgs field gives *everything* mass, and exists everywhere. Although the Higgs was not yet experimentally confirmed by the time this movie was made, this has been theorised for some time. It would only take a simple internet search.However, the movie has some good aspects too. The visuals are beautiful. There is some really aesthetic lightning and scenery. The planet Solaris looks fascinating, and there are some nice shots of it. There are a few good story elements about love and regret, and the occasional emotional atmosphere. Background music is fitting.

Review title: Does everything possible to keep you in the theater
Review_body: The original Solaris by Andrei Tarkovsky is a cult classic.  Rent it at Blockbuster and compare.  As with all Tarkovsky's movies, it is made for the "enlightened" and does not even make an attempt to win over anybody else. You'll see how much more of the story Tarkovsky leaves off the screen - for the patient viewer to reconstruct.  Your attention will be challenged by seemingly endless visual sequences. At times the dialog is so rich with different ideas that you need to rewind a few times to simply hear it all. Thus the Tarkovsky's version would not work for general audiences - it requires too much commitment from the viewer.  I saw it in the 70s, people were walking out of the theater - just as expected.Soderbergh knows all that and makes everything humanly possible to adjust the movie to the general public's tastes.  He focuses on the most fundamental ideas.  He sticks to the tightest, most straightforward storyline.  He cuts the movie himself with the precision of Eric Clapton's guitar.  He also knows that he will lose audiences if he fails to entertain them all the time, so he casts two undisputedly beautiful actors: Clooney and Natascha McElhone, augments the couple with a wonderfully funny sidekick (Jeremy Davies). He turns every frame into a glamor shot, adds romantic love scenes (with nudity, mind you), a state-of-the-art sci-fi soundtrack and elaborate computer graphics... and still people walk out of the theater. My heart breaks.  I fear that before long movie makers will just give up.

Review title: The Best Film Since Fight Club
Review_body: Word must travel quickly in America...this is an intelligent film, and American moviegoers have proven they do not enjoy intelligent films. Despite the promotion, Solaris did terribly at the box office (who's going to compete effectively with Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry's chest, loads of explosions, and the most successful movie franchise in history?)Its a shame, because Solaris is the best film I have seen in years, and I am tough to please. It is clever, intelligent, and calculated, while still being intense and emotional. And don't let the other reviewers fool you--it has some magnificent visuals, without being over the top or unnecessary. The dialogue is subdued for most of the film, and feels closer to natural speech, instead of the quick, backtalking style that is far too popular these days. It is clear that this was a dream project for Steven Soderbergh, and I found little at all in this film that resembled his others.I feel sorry for the film industry in a way. People are going to movies less and less, and the industry knows it is because the films being produced are unoriginal, predictable, and pandering. Yet here they offer a film that is not, and the public stays away.The American people deserve the crappy movies they get. Stay tuned for Jackass II, Rob Schneider 5, and Denzel Washington Angry 14.

Review title: Space Orpheus or; how i learned to stop thinking and love feeling
Review_body: imagine yourself as a conductor supposed to play symphony of Mahler in front of teenagers. lenny bernstein might have done a wonderful job to translate the depth of (gestalt) emotions into personal touch.i was just amazed by the way steve soderberg could maintain the original movie's main frame and at the same time, get rid of the chunks of tarkovsky's fat. the way chris remembers rheya (1. their apartment doesn't have pictures 2. rheya hates chris' snobbish friends talking about metaphysical mumbo-jumbo) can justify his (or hollywood's) bias towards romance.visual style and music : A acting : Bjust a note, early in the movie, there are a few shots from the behind of chris (zoom in or still). once you can resonate your feelings with the character, you'll love this movie.

I will keep this short. This truly brilliant filmaking. The movie, of course, is not for everyone, but if you are patient and enjoy woderful visual style, solid thematic representation, and a thought provoking finale, then get out and see this film. Soderbergh is probably the best director working today, and George Clooney continues to impress.

Review title: Quite possibly the worst movie I've ever seen
Review_body: I like to think of myself as someone who truly appreciates a smart movie, e.g. one of my favorite movies last year was Memento. After hearing that this was more of a "cerebral" movie, I decided to give it a shot. The only thing "cerebral" about this movie was the droning headache from boredom I was getting. Near the end when Chris (G. Clooney) asks his wife "Am I alive or dead?" I was thinking to myself "WHO CARES??!!". This is one of the only movies I've seen at the theaters where I spent as much time looking at my watch as I did the movie.

This movie lacks a plot, suspense, interest, and anything else that a movie needs to hold your interest.  The movie is very predictable with a poorly written storyline -- no romance...no sci-fi...no intrigue.  It was a total waste of time and money (as was noticed by others who walked out during the movie).

Stanislaw Lem died a few weeks ago, and upon reading the NY Times obit I realized I had never read anything he wrote. Three books were especially recommended, so I got them all. I am sorry to report that I could not make it through "His Master's Voice," but I thought "Solaris" was inspired. After reading the book, I got the movie and watched it last night. I was more than an hour into the movie when my wife came downstairs. I ranted for a while about how disappointed I was with it, and about how little it seemed to have in common with the brilliant book. She said "So then how come you are still watching it?" Good question. I turned it off and went to bed.I guess what it comes down to is that if this movie had been called anything other than "Solaris," I probably wouldn't have minded, but "Solaris" the book and "Solaris" the movie do not overlap.

Solaris was very good. A few people in the audience were expecting Star Trek or something similar. I was quite prepared for 2001:a Space Odyssey. And I wasn't disappointed.Its not as sprawling or epic as Kubrick's 1969 masterpiece, but the long periods of silence and the understated performances from the main characters are clearly Soderbergh's reminder to us of the vast quietness that exists in space. Clooney was excellent as the troubled psychologist dealing with the suicide of his wife. He is summoned to the Prometheus, a space station orbiting the moon of Solaris. The message is vague, but tells him that "strange things have happened, and the easiest thing would be to return home, but (they) don't want to". So he goes to help out.............It was captivating. The music is mesmeric and the performances by all the lead characters add to the general eeriness.If you want a thoughtful considered piece of movie-making then it's worth watching. If you like loud explosions in space, go for Starship Troopers.

Arthur C. Clarke and Stanley Kubrick decided to make the 'proverbial good sci-fi movie' when they jointly created the film and novel 2001: A Space Odyssey. There have been few comparably good sci-fi films since. Solaris is, however, one of them.Whilst the Russian original is an epic and demanding film, Soderbergh's work should not be considered a remake. The director himself considers it his own interpretation of the book, quite apart from the earlier film. Because of this, the two should not be compared.If you hated Alien 3 because it didn't have any guns or 2001 because the ending was confusing, do not waste your time with Solaris. It is not for you.Conceptually, the story is standard psychological sci-fi fare, with simple but effective theological and philosophical themes. In this respect it breaks little or no new ground over the Tarkovsky predecessor. It has elements of romance, thriller, and drama, all necessarily set in sci-fi land, as the setting is integral to the storytelling.Visually, the Solaris future is a conservative, believable vision, reminiscent in look to that of Gatacca. Solaris space is a minimal, beautiful place to be. Not dirty and used like the celebrated Alien 'space trucker' look, Solaris vessels are gleaming, intricate and stylish, but seem to have been designed by engineers rather than artists, such is the practical realism. Their design is complemented by some of the best CG spaceship effects I have seen (incredible that it has taken this long for computer graphics to look as good as the model-based technology of 2001, Star Wars and Aliens in the 1960s and 70s).Solaris, the planet itself, is a clever piece of art, seemingly evidencing a degree of emotion by its colouring and detail, as no doubt was the intention. In the commentary to the DVD it is mentioned that many of the lingering shots of the planet were cut, which may have been necessary for the pacing of the film, but I found every shot an absorbing spectacle and would have enjoyed more.The sets and costumes also retain the sense of engineering realism combined with beauty. Soderbergh's eye for detail is evident here, as everything has a purpose and look that fits perfectly with the overall feel. Somehow, this look is original and avoids many of the clichés we come to expect of sci-fi mise-en-scene.Channel Four recently showed this on UK television and billed it along the lines of a 'George Clooney Sci-Fi Romance'. A tenuous interpretation, perhaps, but you can see why they did it. Whilst Clooney adds Hollywood star appeal, fans will be slightly disappointed, not because his work here is in anyway weak, but because he is understated, convincing and very un-Hollywood. With Solaris he adds another fine performance to an already commendably diverse filmography.Natascha McElhone too plays a difficult, emotive role without resorting to melodrama. The small supporting cast doesn't put a foot wrong, with a delightfully odd but subtly creepy performance from Jeremy Davies worthy of note.Solaris is slow, abstract, haunting stuff. The direction is subtle, dare I say almost Kubrick-esquire. The camera work is non-intrusive, solid stuff without gimmick (apart from a touch of shaky-cam in the restaurant scene where Kelvin meets Rheya) or overstatement.Add to this a beautiful, timeless score by Cliff Martinez and you have one of the better psychological sci-fi movies ever made.The majority of people will hate Solaris. Let them. Let them have instead the mindless Hollywood trash released every week and keep this treasure for yourself.

Review title: Solaris: A movie, that sparked interest, but failed to ignite the stove.
Review_body: When I hired this movie, I had no preconceived ideas and started watching with no expectations at all as I have not seen the original or read the novel.What I found was a movie that had a decent foundation, the ideas altogether held my interest, and so I continued to persist with the movie, hoping for an astounding revelation or discovery, but overall the film was astoundingly slow and there was no shock forthcoming, another negative point was the lack of connectivity between all it's parts and so I felt the film didn't really flow that well, a few minor holes were not filled, and characters were not fully developed.Overall I gave this film 3 stars, 1 positive is that it made me interested in reading the novel, and seeing the original film.

Solaris is based on a Russian movie named Solyaris. The plot elements are very similar between the two versions, but the Solyaris is quite a bit longer than Solaris. The planet/object 'Solaris' has intelligence; the capability to manifest your subconsciousness or dreams into reality. This is a common theme in Soviet era movies, for example the Russian made movie Stalker in 1979 is a quest to find a place in "The Zone" where you could basically get your wishes granted. Considering the bland lives of living in the Soviet union during that era, it's no wonder movies like this made such an impression on those people.The point of the movie is that if you could have your dreams, would you forgo reality and choose the dreams? In Solaris, the manifestations of your dreams take on a life of their own. The consequences are not predictable, so maybe dreams are best left locked up in the mind...

Review title: Thanks Mr. Soderbergh for your originality!
Review_body: This is by far the most philosophically challenging moment in the life of James T. Kirk (George Clooney), Captain of the U.S.S. Enterprise.  Lost in the Nexus during a rescue operation on board the Enterprise-B, Kirk realizes that he can fix his regrets from the past, erase his personal mistakes, while in the Nexus.  Fellow Starfleet officer Jean-Luc Picard (Viola Davis ), Captain of the Enterprise-D, also becomes trapped in the Nexus. After realizing the emptiness of life in the Nexus, Picard attempts to convince Kirk of the same.  But, will Kirk choose to remain in the Nexus and live a hollow, vapid existence, forever reliving and reshaping his past, or will he follow Picard back to reality?  I won't ruin the end for you..  you'll have to see it to believe it!

Review title: A very poor film, it must have lost millions.
Review_body: I have just totally wasted 99 minutes watching an uninteresting, unbelievable,morbidly slow and coma inducing film that failed to interest me or convince me of the validity of the storyline. I thought that with George Clooney starring in it that it would have at least been entertaining, it wasn't. The only thing I found interesting was the visual effects, these were very colourful and almost etheric. I was so pleased when it had finished. It left me wondering how much money and talent had been wasted in making it, and who where the unfortunate financial investors and how much had they lost. In my opinion the story was wafer thin and many of the questions raised were never answered to my satisfaction. It just emphasises to me that without a rock solid interesting and hopefully believable story line all the big money needed to make a film today is wasted.

This was definately one of the worst movies I have ever seen. About 20 people were in the theater and 4 of them left and a fifth kept leaving and coming back. I would have left but I paid my money and I was going to stick it out. Half the movie was silence, the other half made little sense. Who was allowed to make this movie?

Review title: Love the Scenery and Atmo of this Tape
Review_body: Calm and fascinating sci fi with an amazing George Clooney!

If you've ever been so captivated by something that you can't understand how anyone could feel differently about it, you can relate to my affection for this movie.The situation that Kelvin (Clooney's character) finds himself in soon after he arrives at the Solaris station is a dilemma as compelling and emotional as anything I've seen in science fiction.The music is hauntingly beautiful.The actors are all excellent, including Natascha McElhone, who also happens to be gorgeous in an exotic, slightly unconventional way.I don't think there's a word spoken that rings false or feels unnecessary.The third act does not disappoint.There isn't much more I can say without giving away too much, and the truth is the less you know going in, the better. Just ignore Solaris' box office and watch the first 33 minutes of this film. If you aren't absolutely hooked, well, I guess I'll accept it, but I won't understand it.

While watching "Solaris", I kept checking my watch. I found it slow in the beginning, and I found myself wondering what the point was going to be.I got more out of the movie thinking about it afterwards. Thinking about the relationship between the two lead characters, the way things can turn sour, the mistakes they made, and the regret they felt when it was too late.The movie has themes about heaven, redemption, and life after death. Although I found it slow, I enjoyed talking about it afterward, and thinking about it.

Unlike the Tarkovsky version this concentrates on the heart rather than the philosophy of the book - which is ironic since Lem objected to the humanisation in the Tarkovsky version. An emotional journey into relationships and what they entail. Soderbergh weaves a tapestry of human emotion beyond the book's boundaries, and beyond Lem's original novel, which sacrificed passion for debate. And it still manages to homage the Tarkovsky version with the water motif (rain on the window in the first shot - rain in the background in the dinner conversation scene.) Soderburgh has taken the source material and crafted an original piece of cinema which reflects both the book and the original film. And to add to that, the music's fantastic.

Solaris being classified as a Sci-Fi movie was enough to keep me from seeing it until now and ultimately I only decided to visit the Science Fiction shelves due to my enjoyment of George Clooney movies. I can therefore report my surprise as to how much I have enjoyed this movie. Chris Kelvin is a psychiatrist who when introduced to us seems to have a very busy but emotionally dissatisfying life. He is compelled to visit a space station following a mysterious plea from a friend. When he arrives at Solaris he finds that his friend is dead and he begins to discover why the crew has had trouble leaving the space station. This story is set in a science fiction surrounding, but is very much a story about relationships. In one scene Chris tells Rheya that he is the right guy for her, but we soon discover that he fails her. Ultimately Chris wants to redeem himself by saving her when offered a second chance. The movie is very slow paced, allowing for great character development. Solaris is refreshing in that it leaves many questions unanswered. It does not force feed the viewer moral judgements rather it leads us to the question and allows us to explore our own thoughts.

I saw this film last night and it's been in my head all day today. Why oh why aren't more sci-fi films like this made these days, instead of "blockbusters" like Attack of the Clones and Independence Day? I saw both of these films on release and left the theatre feeling let-down and disappointed. Not so Solaris. From the opening sequence I was captivated. Everything - visuals, music, atmosphere, acting (especially Clooney) were top notch. I've always thought he was a decent actor but this for me was by far a career best. Ok there was some unnecessary shots of his butt but who cares? Even my girlfriend, not the deepest thinker that's ever lived, confessed that she'd enjoyed it. Reading some of the user comments I gather this film bombed in America, which doesn't surprise me. If it's not a film involving gung-ho heroes killing every baddie in sight or a film where they re-write history to suit themselves - see U571 or The Patriot - they really don't want to know (my apologies to the half of America which has a brain, and I suspect there ARE a few of you!). Anyway I give Solaris a deseved 9/10. And do you know I went to see this film on a Wednesday night, the theatre was three-quaters full, and not a SINGLE person left before the end!

Review title: Don't waste your time to go see this slow laborious bore.
Review_body: I appreciate cerebral science fiction, i.e. 2001 or Blade Runner, but you have to stay awake to enjoy it.  The film does have some interesting ideas, but the film ran in slow motion so you keep waiting for something to happen or inspire you, but it never does.  You never get to the point where you care about the characters.  The big talk is seeing George Clooney's behind, but you have to be awake to see it.  Sorry, but don't waste your money to go see this movie.  Maybe video rental when it comes out in 1-2 months, but at least then you can sleep in your own living room.

The trailers totally showed a different kind of movie.  Quietness, pratically still time, numbness can all describe this movie.  I wasted my time, almost fell asleep.  There is no tension, no suspense, I know it says drama on this site rating but, the trailers sold something else.  I know I was a fool for not reading any reviews before going to see it, I'll make sure not to make that mistake again.  As my recommendation, don't waste your time and money in this film, not even the romance makes you feel the least bit of tenderness, not even for the message it tries to communicate is it worth seeing.

99 minutes to let you breathe and then take your breath away...99 minutes to let you think about what do you really need to be happy: the truth, the fiction, the memory remains or maybe just a moment would be enough...99 minutes to let you get loose into a planet only inhabited by yourself as the music takes you by the hand to hide somewhere really far away...the music, ohhh the music...

I have not seen the original 1972 Solaris movie, nor have I read the book so these comments assess the 2002 Solaris movie as an independent story without regard to its originality nor adherence to the book. Perhaps the 1972 telling is better in conception and execution and if you choose to see only one Solaris, maybe the original is the better choice, or maybe not. But in either case, the 2002 Solaris definitely has significant merits. Two days after viewing the movie, I find myself still thinking about it.So, should you watch this movie? Is it good entertainment or a waste of time? That depends, of course, on your expectations so let's help set some expectations. More than most, this film requires you to be in the right mood; if you're in the right mood with the right expectations it is a pretty good movie. But if you're not, you certainly will not like it.Is it science-fiction? It has a science-fiction setting, and some science-fiction themes running through it but those themes are minor compared to its main themes and are not explored much. There are some acceptable special effects and science-fiction imagery but they provide a counterpoint to its brooding atmosphere more than anything else.This is a fairly serious film, with central themes exploring the "human condition" and human nature. The sci-fi setting allows the storyteller to put the characters into unusual situations that just don't otherwise occur, at least in the here and now. The characters will act and react according to how the storyteller, relying on her/his own sense of human nature, thinks they will. So it's a sort of thought-experiment. If the storyteller has real insight, the characters' actions will seem reasonable to us, although perhaps only after some thought because the situations are certainly unusual.What else does Solaris offer the viewer? It is one of a short list of "puzzle" movies. Such movies tell their story without any real third-party narration. They are seen entirely through the eyes of one or more characters; the audience is required to sort out the objective facts of the story from the subjective narration. Well, maybe this isn't the best definition, but it's somehow part of it. I'm thinking of, but not comparing Solaris to, movies like Sixth Sense and Identity. What was going on? Is that scene a flashback or occurring in the present or a dream? Does just the protagonist see that or does everyone? There was no objective narration; it was presented as an intellectual puzzle to the audience to solve. (To digress momentarily, I would argue that Sixth Sense presented enough clues, and presented them early enough that figuring out the solution to the puzzle was possible early in the movie. Whereas Identity did not present enough clues until late for the puzzle to be solved, thus becoming more of a surprise-ending movie.) Solaris is rich in a brooding atmosphere. And it has a slow pace, perhaps to give the audience time to think about each clue before the next is presented.So why watch Solaris? If you're interested in solving a "puzzle" movie, one that will possibly continue to engage your thoughts after the movie is done, if you're willing to explore some very serious themes about human nature and the human condition, and if your mood matches the brooding atmosphere and slow pace, then watch, puzzle, cogitate and drink it in.Is it a good movie? Within the constraints of the above, it is better than most. My chief praise for the storytelling is the way it continued to periodically deliver us puzzle clues, unlike some other movies which deliberately withhold the clues. And I was also pleased that there was a solution at the end, consistent with the clues and with the story pushing us towards it - although the interpretation of that end solution is open to discussion. So, as an intellectual puzzle, a good challenge but a fair one.I really enjoyed the acting and somewhat enjoyed most of the cinematography. I did not enjoy the music quite as much as most viewers posting here seem to have, but it wasn't jarring nor distracting. I also found the volume of the soundtrack uneven, so make sure you have your remote handy. And the pace could have been picked up just a little, but not too much or else it would have lost its atmosphere. Overall, an 8 out of 10 but not for everyone and make sure you're in the right mood.Hope this helps.

Review title: Give it a try, but do not expect much.
Review_body: I did not see the russian version of Lem's novel, so I thougth it is a good chance to experience how someone else see Solaris. It was not. As for Solaris "himself", you see a planet of blueish light effects from afar (the novel takes you to the surface of Solaris), with absolutely no detail. As for the story, you get a love-story instead of something you can interpret the way you like. As for the ending, it has nothing in common with Lem's vision. And on top of all, it is a (very) boring movie. The novel itself does not contain much action, but when the makers of the film took the negligible side story and made it the main plot... everything gone awfully boring. And I have to tell you: Solaris isn't evil (or something like that), as you might feel in the end; and nobody knows what's "his" goal, but surely it isn't to make someone (or everyone) happy...If you want to watch a love-story in outer space, then give it a try, but if you want to watch a sci-fi movie, look somewhere else.

Review title: But come on, who knows what "love" really is?
Review_body: Steven Soderbergh's adaptation of Stanislaw Lem's novel is quite interesting and compelling. His directing could have been greater but the work still lands in the charts of good film-making and adaptations from a classical novel to screen. What is most intriguing about this particular celluloid version of the book is that there is no character development. There is no sense of particularity in the characters. You can actually even doubt the very existence of life. And what about the wife of George Clooney's character? Does she exist or not? Who is on board on this space vessel? The answer is a self-exploration of a psychotherapist for the main character, the one that George Clooney with the direction of Soderbergh accomplishes successfully. Magnificent acting, not over the top but just right. But the answer still is a contradiction. The final message of the film itself is a contradiction and there is no definite end of the story, or a beginning in the same sense.During the film you kind of accumulate the feeling of knowing the different characters but in the end doubt their even existence. This is symbol of mankind's development, evolution, meaning of life if you may - self-perspective, self knowledge and understanding.It's deep, it's chilling, it's bizarre and makes no sense at some point, because it is dreamlike. The whole film sequences seem like taken bits from a dream. don't get me wrong, it's a well-organized, well-directed, acted out to perfection and with a great score but in the end it stays up in the air. You have to feel it to understand it. Sense it to comprehend it. Let go any logic whatsoever and just ask yourself - what do you fear and desire most?And up to the point of conclusion - Love? Noun, no explanation. It cannot be enforced and it's existence is a mystery. That's what the novel is about. If you know what "love" is, you shouldn't watch this movie. But come on, who really knows what "love" really is?

Review title: do they really read the book ?
Review_body: do they really read the book ? The movie shows us only 2 pages from original book of Stanislaw Lem. Only 2 pages describes the love story, but Soderbergh decided to make the whole movie based on it. Why ? Where is the real sense of Solaris from Stanislaw Lem ?  Where is Drama and Sci-Fi ? it is only cheap Romance. I'm quite sure he never read the book. I was forced to stop the movie after 34 minutes. I would like to give -1 point to it, but, unfortunately the minimum is 1. My suggestion - watch the movie "Solyaris" from Andrei Tarkovsky (10 points).

Review title: I was very sceptical about it earlier...
Review_body:
I was very skeptical about it earlier, especially because of George Clooney. Anyways, we had our very occasional sci-fi evening yesterday, and in between Ukkonen (nice short Finnish sci-fi-action flick) and Hitch Hikers Guide BBC series this title came up. I got curios, throw out my biases, walked briskly to the store today, and enjoyed the movie on DVD.Oh, was I surprised how well Soderbergh has got it together. And don't anybody worry, Clooney handles his burden respectably.
All you Tarkovsky freaks and sci-fi puritans, please give it a chance, you might like it somewhat. I did.

Review title: "I'm sure glad that I didn't pay to see this".
Review_body: I won free tickets to see "Solaris" as did the rest of the audience at this sneak preview.  The movie was slow and confusing at times.  The audience laughed when they weren't supposed to and I saw a few people walk out. George Clooney did a fair job acting in a role that wasn't too challenging. I never saw the original and now I have no desire to.  I overheard a woman sum up my feelings when I overheard her say "I'm sure glad that I didn't pay to see this".

Some Scifi movies are classics. Some are Legends. This one just doesn't fit in anywhere. It tries so hard to be 2001 A Space Oddysey and falls so short its not funny.Its so difficult to follow a few of us thought at one stage that the player was skipping to other parts on the disk. It makes no sense whatsoever and if it moved any slower....I will give the film its due in that it is trying to be an arty scifi movie with more flair than pure scifi.But still, something thats that hard to follow just cant be appealing.If you're a classic Scifi lover of action, aliens and at least some kind of story - then I would give this one a skip.

I recently read the book Solaris from Stanislav Lem which was recommended to me by a friend. I read the book and I liked it. I liked it because of Lems very detailed description of the forms which Solaris creates and the accidents which happened there. I really must say that this 'scientific' descriptions of the happenings there were quite interesting and at some parts scaring. After I read the book I found out that there was a movie about this book and - because I really wanted to see those forms, the surface of Solaris and to compare them to those in my imagination - I watched it. But I the movie heavily disappointed me.Only about 10% of this movie represent the book. The rest is absolutely different. Different characters, different names and different storyline. Sorry, but this movie should not be allowed to be called Solaris. Read the book if you want some Science-Fiction. Watch the movie if you want a twisted Romance.

I don't know if this is a 'thinking persons' movie.  I do believe that people who are more comfortable with concrete thoughts and actions will dislike it intensely (as shown by the incredible volume of negative user reviews here).If you read, and enjoy being gently lowered into a different world by a good author, then you will probably enjoy this movie thoroughly.  If you don't enjoy external manipulation of your thoughts and feelings, you won't enjoy this movie - you will find it boring and pedantic.I thoroughly enjoyed being pulled into this dream.  Everything about it, from the beginning (no credits, it just starts) to the end, works to take you away from the norm and move you towards Solaris and its own reality.I saw the original film a few months before the new version was released. Although I respected it for the vision and style, I was not able to really feel a part of it.  Maybe because of the subtitles, or because its pace is more designed for a European sensibility, I found myself drifting away from it many times.  Clooney's Solaris, with its quiet feeling also allows me to drift, but pulls me in and holds me there.When a movie or book is able to envelop me in its dream, and actually hold me there long after the end, it has accomplished its goal.  Solaris held its pull on me long after the last view of the planet disappeared from my screen.  I was left with that dreamlike feeling and mood for a long time afterwards.  To me, that is the ultimate sign of an excellent story well directed and acted.

Review title: I just seen the sneek preview of this!
Review_body: I just saw the sneek preview of this film.  This was a great piece of art. George Clooney did an excellent job in this movie as did Sodenberg. Solaris moved along kind of slow in the beginning and ended with a great climax. This movie touched religion and the existence of other beings in the world. I would definitly recommend this film.

**SPOILERS!!!** Soderbergh has a tendency to produce good movies and bad movies, so I was somewhat worried when I walked into the movie.  It started off giving me a bad impression, but completely saved itself at the very end. Watching the movie, I was consistently reminded of the Myst game series.  Not for stylistic reasons, but simply the overall detached tone seemed to be very similar.  This movie is an example of Soderbergh's incredible ability to imply things very subtly.  Half the plot is hinted at through flashbacks, and for those people who like to think, a lot is told in so little time. This movie makes no attempt to explain the science fiction it incorporates.  Rather, it spends its short time explaining the psychology of the humans and Solaris.  People going in expecting a sci-fi will be greatly disappointed if they are expecting realism; this is a psychological movie, and explains that well. My favorite line was the last part, where George Clooney asks, "Am I alive, or dead?"  It doesn't matter, because if he believes he is happy, then it is of no consequence whether or not he is dead.  This is how the entire movie is; even we do not know whether he is actually at Earth and dreaming, or still in Solaris.  It is an exploration of the human mind, and how it reacts.  This is the type of thing that Soderbergh often attempts, and when he succeeds, delivers a

Review title: Very narrow and straight forward compared to the classic Russian Solyaris (1972)
Review_body: The original movie, although by today's standards very outdated, displayed a bigger picture, unlike the new Solaris which simply focuses on the romance between Chris Kelvin and Rheya Kelvin. Some other plot twists attached to the new Solaris were disgustingly irrelevant to the general mood of the picture and the story in general. SOLYARIS DOES NOT DO THESE THINGS.See the classic, please.

Review title: You will leave the theatre with questions
Review_body: What you'll leave the theatre with is exactly what Chris Kelvin is having to deal with when he arrives at the space station orbiting Solaris.The answers aren't given to you by Soderbergh.  You're forced to think about what is happening and why.If you're looking for an A+B=C kind of movie, Solaris will disappoint.  If you like being left thinking in a continuous loop of deciding what happened and why, you'll love this film."There are no answers, only choices.", Gibarian

Review title: pointless, idiotic waste of money - Did I forget pointless?
Review_body: As a sci-fi fan, I was surprised at how boring this film is.  The only thing I can remember equally inane was/is 2001: A Space Odyssey, which I saw in the 4th grade.  It bored me then as much as this one did (I'm now 43).This film has a deliberate lack of a musical underscore, which is usually made up for in dialog or suspense (as with Alfred Hitchcock).  Guess what? There is NO suspense; nothing whatsoever "grabbed" me and the dialog is monotonously plodding.  I even asked my wife, "Are they mumbling and whispering or is it just me?"  She assured me that they were mumbling and whispering -- THROUGH THE WHOLE MOVIE!!!!  The volume level was not just low in our theatre, either.  Some dialog and sound effects were just fine. But an INORDINATELY large amount was almost indiscernible.How did James Cameron go from "the top of the world" with Titanic to THIS?

Review title: I haven't walked out on a movie since GI Jane, but I had to.
Review_body: This movie sucks.  It reeks.  "Boring" alone doesn't say what needs to be said.  Obviously there were some good special special effects, there was some good talent (yes, George Clooney has butt cheeks) (and Jeremy Davies' deserves better scripts -- and the chance to show-off his bare butt).  But after watching the first six or eight hours (it seemed like) of this awful movie, I felt ill and had to walk out.  As I left, I noticed at least three other couples doing the same thing -- running for their lives.  Save yourself!  Leave now!  Better yet, don't even go.

I have never walked out of a movie before, until now. My nephew and I just couldn't take another minute of the boredom. This movie is so slow, so short on conversation, just plain bad. I think they were very deceptive in their advertising for this movie. I kept falling asleep, even during the Clooney shots, so you know that was a sure sign I was bored. I hope I can save someone from spending $13, take a free nap at home. I say save the money at the video store too, not even worth the $3.

This movie seemed to have some potential.  I was wrong.  Early in the film they establish the plot and the movie pretty much stops there.  The entire film is spent treading water.  We see more melodramatic acting then a cable access soap opera.  I really expected more out of Clooney and Soderbergh. The movie wasn't too long, which I appreciated.

I really wanted to like this movie, but to me it failed miserably.  I went into the film anticipating a thinker and was excited at the prospect, but I feel the execution of the film failed miserably.  Ive never seen so many people walk out of a movie half way through.  The shots were beautiful and well-done, but the story never took off and bored more than enlightened. I know everyone is jumping on the bandwagon for this movie and giving it rave reviews, but this is just a badly plotted and paced film.

I couldn't stay awake. One of the most boring movies ever produced. I liked 2001 even though I didn't understand it. This tried to duplicate the cerebral mood of 2001 but it was bad. There were some points where you were about to have an emotion or two, but it never panned out. I want my $9.50 and two hours of my life back!
this movie is pure trash and pure nonsense.Nothing makes the least bit of sense.Sappy story along with romance makes this romantic C- sci-fi chick flick.

Review title: Very good movie based on Lem's novel
Review_body: Warning: MINOR SPOILERS --------------Excellent story-telling, with great visuals, editing and music. A treat for Soderbergh fans.In my opinion, one of the central ideas of the novel was man's first contact with extra-terrestrial life, and the problems inherent to such an event. The movie refers to this a few times, perhaps more so in the ending, which is different from the one in the novel. The last scene in the novel is pretty cool too...The movie is almost entirely devoted to the love story (sub-plot), which is nicely done, with good acting by the cast.If you like 2001:A Space Odyssey (many references in the movie), are a Soderbergh fan, or like "atmospheric" movies, you will like this one.

Besides the big hype about George Clooney, the movie didn't live up to expectations. The story was dumb all the way through (regardless of any remake attempt), wanting to be a European art movie but not getting anywhere near. The best part of the movie were the scenes with "Snow" who stole the show from Clooney in my opinion.
