Wasn't planning to go, seeing many negative reviews here. I went and there are no regrets! Not for those who enjoys movies based on cartoons or comics, chewing popcorn and slurping coke. It requires you to WATCH, listen, and think. If you are not used to it - skip it, or you will be "bored" by a "slow" movie, and the only entertaining moment you'll find there will be Clooney's naked butt, but you'll decide seeing it is not worth money you spent. Otherwise, it grabs you and doesn't let you go till the very last minute. This is a deep, thoughtful and not usual Hollywood-style film which leaves lots of questions in your head for a long period of time. It is about love, dedication, choice, subconsciousness, fragility of relationships, tolerance, loss and regret. It is also about many other things, depends on your personality and life experience. Fabulous!

Ok, this was just a bizarre movie.  I generally like "slow, talking" movies, but this was too much.  There were people who left the theater during the movie, and the conversations by most after the movie involved "can we get our money back?".  The love story portion was touching, but it seems like it was buried.  There were also alot of unaswered questions.  Not a movie for me, that's for sure.

I've read the book by Stanislaw Lem and seen the film by Tarkowski and I must say that this film is not Solaris. It might be "inspired" by Solaris, but nothing more. Having said this, it's not a bad movie and a nice love story and has some interesting things, I liked all those flashbacks in particular.Anyway, if compared to the real Solaris, here's what I disliked (so be warned - SPOILERS):1) Who the f* is Gordon? Where is Sartorius? Why was he cut out? He was the most ambiguos character in the book, struggled between hating and loving the visitors.2) Where is Solaris? Lem spends half the book to describe the planet! Centuries of wasted research trying to understand that alien intelligence. Why not spend that 5 minutes to explain Solaris? It's supposed to be a SF movie, isn't it?3) Why, why, why, why had Snaut to be an aggressor? I cannot believe this! Did Soderbergh really mean it? This is definitively _not_ was Solaris is all about. And why has he forgot to talk? Nobody understands what he is saying. Incredible.4) Using the planet commercially? Sending a special forces to the space station? Argh! Why must everything be about making money and why are all space stations run by corporations? Solaris is really about search for knowledge, it is about SCIENCE fiction, Lem's station is run by a scientific community!My tip if you like SF: Watch Solaris by Tarkowsky (1972) or best: read the book!

It took me a bit to be taken in by this movie's plot.  The untransitioned shots and plot-jumps were confusing at first until the mindset of the movie was obvious.  I enjoy movies that make the viewer THINK about things in life we take for granted, which this movie does well.  Looking at the voting numbers, you will either very much enjoy this movie, or will greatly dislike it.  The serious-tone, unprevalant background music, and primary dialog-only scenes will rub some viewers the wrong way.  I feel these characteristics adds to the movie's dramatic effect and message.  I would recommend this movie to anybody who enjoys deep thinking about life, space, and time and their roles influencing human life.

For those looking for Star Wars or Men in Black, this movie is not for you. The classification of `Science Fiction/Thriller' is somewhat misleading. While it is science fiction, the film is much too cerebral to be called a `thriller.'  In truth, this film is more a testament to the power Soderbergh has in Hollywood than anything else.  It's not that the film is bad, but it certainly is not `major world wide release' material.  This is both a critique and a compliment for the film.  On the one hand, the movie going public could do with more challenging films, movies that it takes a few post viewing hours to wrap your mind around.  On the other hand, presenting a movie this inaccessible to the general public runs the risk of a financial and professional failing.  Thus, that Soderbergh could make it and release it during the Christmas movie season speaks volumes about how much pull he has (and justifiably so) in the industry.As for the movie itself, as with all Soderbergh films it is exceptionally well crafted (Traffic is, in my opinion, the most finely crafted film made in the last 20 years).  Fans of Soderbergh will not be disappointed by either the visual or atmospheric elements he brings to bear.  That begs the question whether visual and artistic merit are sufficient criteria with which to judge a film.  The answer is; it depends.  In a film such as Ron Fircke's Baraka, where there is no dialogue and there are no (specific) characters, the thematic elements can only be conveyed through visual and audio images.  Therefore, visual and artistic merit are the only criteria you can use to judge the film, and that suffices.  However, in a traditional film with characters, dialogue and action there is an expectation for thematic cohesion that Solaris seems to lack.  Because the ideas are vague and the plot non-linier, very few people will come out of this movie with a strong sense of what actually happened and what it all meant.  On the surface, that seems like not such a bad thing.  Strong art (and despite its wide release this is undoubtedly an `art film') should leave you thinking, discussing and wondering.  The problem is that if you are unable to come to any cohesive, arguable conclusions after you have done the thinking and discussing, the value of the film comes into question.  If the only value of a film that includes dialogue, character and action is for the visual and atmospheric quality, why should the former be included?
All of this is to say that we cannot simply be impressed with Soderbergh's camera work and call the film good.  Nor is it enough to say, `Wow, that film really made me think, it must be good.'  Rather, the director and writers should use the medium they employ to convey a message, and at some level that message must be obtainable by the audience they are trying to communicate with.  If the film, even after it has been discussed and analyzed by discerning minds continues to be incoherent, it has failed in to communicate and thus failed completely.The unavoidable comparison with Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey illustrates this point.  I first saw 2001 when I was twelve and I'm not sure what was more confusing, the movie or why I had watched the whole thing.  I had no idea whatsoever about what the film could mean.  However, I sat down with my father afterward and he pointed out some of the ideas and meaning.  Ideas such as that the film showed the progression of man from beast to human to whatever enlightened being Dave becomes at the end of 2001.  He showed me how the obelisk was either a catalyst for or a representation of these huge leaps in humanities advancements.  As our discussion progressed, the ideas of the film fell from confused images to a cohesive theme.  Certainly not one that was easily accessible or capable of being grasped without thought or effort, but after the effort was applied I knew, even at a young age, what was being communicated to me.  In short, the director and writer had connected.  The power of that moment stays with me even years later. Solaris, unfortunately, never lets the viewer (no matter how discerning) make that discovery or that connection.  You are left convinced that the film had something to say but despairing that you will never know what it was.  There is an overall lack of internal consistency so at no point can you track enough evidences to a defendable conclusion.  It's not so much that there are inconsistencies, but that you don't have enough evidence to support any particular idea convincingly.  It is the worst kind of argument: one with neither a conclusion nor enough evidence to support a conclusion.
Some will argue that that is precisely the nature of the film.  The fact that there is no solid answer is not only justifiable but also desirable. For that argument to be true, however, we must accept that the film either does not give us enough information or the information is contradictory. If that is the case, it lacks the fundamental aspect that makes science fiction believable, internal consistency.  The viewer is left with only confusion and chaos, neither of which justifies the medium used to present, nor the time taken to view, the material.If you appreciate the visual and atmospheric elements in film this movie is worth watching.  If you are going for the plot or themes you will likely be disappointed.  There is a subset of viewers out there who will completely enjoy this film for its existential elements and unanswerable questions. However, for those who might be tempted to see this film because they anticipate some form of intellectual edification, just rent 2001 and call my dad with any questions you might have about it.

I was very disappointed in this movie. The best way I can describe it is BORING!It was slow, dark,and one of those movies you are always wondering if it's really happening , a dream, or something else. If you are a Clooney fan and just have to see it. Wait till it hits the rental stores. I wish I hadn't waisted my money on it.

Solaris has reached Europe, Poland in particular last Friday, and very first spectators have seen the long awaited film. In general, I agree with Stanislaw Lem and his comment on Solaris, however one negative is very visible: film seems to be short (shortened); producers sacrificed some episodes from the book to make the slow action more fluent (I guess the pilot Berton testifying has been cut off) I have heard that opinion from many people surrounding me in the cinema. Steven Soderbergh, a top grade film-director is not strong and experienced in SciFi. Ridley Scott, for example, would do better job I suppose, however I respect the work of Mr Soderbergh as well. I hope Hollywood will continue to translate Lem's literature into the movie and next pictures will be even better. I gave 7 out of 10.

I was a big fan of the original adaptation, so I kind of had my doubts about this. But as it turned out I honestly think this version is better.The Tarkovsky version has stunning cinematography, but there's a humanity to Soderbergh's rendition that brought me to tears. His ability to sum up a deep and believable relationship in just a handful of scenes is amazing. You really believe that these people were and are in love.I was disappointed to see how mishandled the various advertising campaigns for this film are. I can imagine a lot of people came to see the film expecting something totally different to what they saw and left disappointed. It's NOT a ghost story, or a romance, or a horror film. It's a love story.

This is one of those movies that you will either love or hate. I have not met many people who thought it was just "ok".First of all, this movie has one of the best and most original soundtracks you will ever hear. It rivals that of Fight Club. It flows perfectly with the very cool and mesmerizing visuals throughout the movie. The story is very simple yet deep. There is even a nice little twist that brought a smile to my face. The normal witty and "to cool for school" persona that Clooney normally brings to the table is put aside for this film. Instead you find a troubled, depressed, and weak minded Dr. Kelvin which is played very well. I won't divulge into the story in hopes that if you have yet to see it, you go into it with an open mind.I can't say enough about this film. Even though I felt sad during the movie for the unfortunate Dr. Kelvin, I left the movie feeling happy and satisfied. Nothing feels left on the table, yet it leaves a bit to the imagination. My only negative is that I felt like it could have been longer. Solid 9/10.

I think the idea of this movie was a decent one, but it's not for anyone with a normal attention span.  The editing was just awful, the shots were held to long (especially reaction to dialogue) and the camera work was boring and not very creative.I understand that this is not a movie intended to thrill the eyes, but when people are yelling things like "This sucks!" out loud you know that it's not a good movie.  Don't waste your time seeing this

Review title: A film in its own right
Review_body: I liked the film very much. I can understand the criticism of some other contributors stating that the movie is not very authentic with respect to the book, although it it is called Solaris and states in its credits that it is based on the book. This is of course misleading and it would have been better to give it a different name and rather say that it was "inspired" by Lem's novel. Therefore I only gave a 9 to a film which I otherwise would have graded 10. Because in its own right I find it very well made indeed. The subject is an absolutely relevant one: Who are we? What makes us human? What is life? What is love? Do we need explanations or meaning in life? The movie concentrates on these questions, different from the book. This is a completely legitimate approach. Don't concentrate on the comparison of film and book, and you are fine. I got curious to reread the novel, and I am not expecting to find too much from the movie in it. That's OK.Also the cinematic realization and the acting was very good. The planet, the spaceship, the drama of the relationship between "humans" and "replicas". Who is human and who replica in the end? Who dreams whom? The result seems to be that being human is defined by nothing else than the relationships themselves, to persons or to the inanimate world. And in Solaris, this "inanimate" world turns out to be more alive than expected, another subject worth being explored.I really cannot understand the relative low rating of around 6 and the many negative reviews this film has received. I think it's great.

Wait a few years and this will be on Mystery Science Theatre 4000.  This movie tried to be intense, deep and thought provoking but in the end was just boring.  Ideas and characters introduced and left behind.  We meet Gordon who is terrified to leave her cabin but in the next scene she is seated with Kelvin and Snow discussing how to get off the station.  After more intense moments of Kelvin dreaming his wife back into existence, Gordon gets on the escape pod and leaves.  This first rescue team is mentioned and forgotten.  His friend, who asked him to come to the station, makes another appearance but gives nothing to move the story along.  His friend's child, who apparently the friend dreamed into existence, runs around the ship. The deep discussion at the dinner table of the existence of higher intelligence sounds like a bunch of junior high kids.  At the end Kelvin and his wife are being absorbed into the higher intelligence, and Snow get to stare, mouth wide open, up at the ceiling.  So, we have a man sent to space to find out what is going wrong (stealing from 2001 A Space Odyssey?) and then because of his great emotional turmoil, brings his wife back to life and they live happily every after in another plane of existence.  All at taxpayer expense.

Yep, awful. Didn't expect much, and it let me down. How anyone voted this as a 10 is absolutely ridiculous.Although, i must admit, watchable, i watched till the end. And the end was incredibly disappointing.Clooney is absorbed to the ship immediately, whereas you'd have to be mad to believe what happens to him even in the first few moments.You'd expect the character, a doctor going there to save them, to be reasonably sane. Yet he takes to it like a duck to water.There is know twist, the fact that one of the small parts is actually one of the beings has zero relevance to the plot. In fact that being some detracts from the film rather than increasing the storyline.Maybe i was rather generous with my vote of a 4, but as I didn't turn it off, I felt i had to give it something.

This genre-bending (or simply -ignoring) film was rightly dissed by the hoi-poloi, but should be a must-see for any serious movie goer, and especially any fan of Soderbergh's- it is one of his best. Soderbergh combines a love story with a space mystery, and brings his usual attention to the nuances of humans and their relationships to a larger, or at least more profound, stage - in orbit around a god-like planet that can shift reality by interpreting dreams and desires. It is a near-perfect match of science fiction and mature drama. Expect to see another film like it sometime after hell freezes over.

I like my sci-fi to be less horror, and more psychological. Solaris fits the bill. The movie starts like a Twilight Zone episode. We see Chris Kelvin, played by George Clooney, looking forlorn while hearing the voice of his wife. Shortly thereafter, he is summoned to take on the task of investigating anomalies on an earth spaceship that has gone somewhat rogue while orbiting Solaris. He finds himself in a bind because he is confronted with a reality that doesn't fit the reality he has come from. Is he "here"? What is "here" from "there"? His objective reality is shattered by subjective reality, which is as much known as unknown. He is tortured by this psychological enigma. Viola Davis, Jeremy Davies and Natash McElhone deliver fine performances. If you're looking for blood and gore and aliens galore...look elsewhere. This is a thought provoking piece.

i normally don't comment on films, but I was so surprised at how beautiful the visuals were for this film. The storyline, cinematography and music (electronica- similar to  Woob1194 ) fit so well together. George Clooney was also brilliant- my respects to those all who put together this film. A film like this will be remembered more as a piece of art as oppose to the high budget films that only focus on the mainstream commercial market.

I had read very little about this film before seeing it. I was aware that many people had given it good reviews and i was intrigued as I am a huge fan of all types of science fiction. I am a great fan of Stanley Kubrick. One of the first films I can remember seeing was his 2001: A Space Odyssey when I was 7 years old. My parents were rather forward thinking and took me to see it on the big screen when it was originally released. That film changed the way I saw the world and the way I would look at films for the rest of my life. I can still remember the some of the content of the philosophical discussions that the adults, who saw the film with us, engaged in after the show. The questions that came up most often were "What was the monolith" and "What was the effect it had on the beings it encountered?" "Was it a representation of God?" Solaris is a film that I feel is trying to explore the idea of what is God and what is human? But, Solaris fails miserably in trying to provoke the same thoughts and feelings that Kubrick did so well with 2001. Solaris tries too hard to be another 2001. From the thin, plodding plot line to the loud chorale music pieces that overwhelm the sound track in a number of places, it tries to be 2001. Where Kubrick wowed us with never before seen ground breaking and realistic filming techniques that produced the spacecraft visuals, that are accompanied by beautiful Strauss waltzes, Solaris keeps showing us that same pink planet visual with the same computer generated sounding audio. After reading the book, 2001: A Space Odyssey, I was able to appreciate more the genius of Kubrick in how he showed us enough to make us think about what it was we were seeing and what it meant. Solaris tried to do the same thing, but it only bored and eventually annoyed me. How many ways can a director/writer try to illustrate the same vapid question of "Is there a God (or creator, or supreme being) and does he care about humans, their relationships with each other, and their emotions" Plus, 99 minutes is a little to short of a run time to even think about exploring this question. In the end, Solaris was a tedious, boring, confusing at times, uninteresting film about people I couldn't possibly care less about. What we are not shown or not told is a lot and it cripples this story and this film. Maybe I will have a different view of Solaris after reading the book, but after viewing this film I am in no hurry to spend my time reading it.

The strange attempt to combine Tarkovsky's "Solaris" (1972) with Ridley Scott's "Blade Runner" (1982). G.Clooney is a pretty good substitution of Donatas Banionis (Kris Kelvin) and unfortunately anything but Harrison Ford (Rick Deckard), sorry.  The movie looks like just another version of Stanislaw Lem's novel, filmed in early 80s.

As a big fan of the original book I thought this had so much promise to be a true classic, bringing sci-fi and philosophy of the mind together. But I was greatly disappointed, feeling only that a great opportunity had been missed out on. While the book had a hidden depth of discussing human perception and belief, the film seemed to gloss over this, focusing rather more on the love interest, which to me(in the book) was a path for a more philosophical look at human belief. How can we believe what we see? can we truly understand our universe, or will it always remain a mystery to us?Read the book, it will tell you more than the film(and is also a damn sight faster no matter how slow you might read :P )

This movie is by the far the worst movie ever made.  Ed Wood would not have touched this bit of pseudo-intellectual nonsense.  Please, Mr. Soderbergh, remake Surf Nazi's Must Die! before you ever attempt something of this ilk again.  Pacing, Story line, Continuity, all were lacking.  I want my $8.50 and the two hours plus of my life back.  We now refer to something that stinks beyond the imagination of Gods and Men as "Solaris" bad.

Review title: First Time I Ever Saw a Crowd Mock a Film
Review_body: I have been to hundreds of movies.  Some were outstanding, some were lousy. Solaris is among the very worst.  The very mention of the film is now part of a family joke.  While watching the film, the crowd became ever increasingly vocal about how bad it was.  This crowd appeared to be very well behaved otherwise.  It was simply the level of lousy that we were watching that caused the crowd to burst elicit comments like "I would rather have root canal than watch this again", "I can't believe I spent money to see this", to simply burst out in delirium tainted laughter at watching the absurdity.  This actually made me realize that a movie could be lousy even if Andie McDowell was not in it!

At the risk of being made fun of, I'd like to say that I really enjoyed this film.  I had already been warned that it is very slow, and that definitely helped me suspend judgement until later in the movie.  If you accept the fact that the story could be told in 30 minutes, it is really easy to appreciate the unique aspects of this film.  The cinematography and set design are awesome, and the mysterious and haunting performances that the actors give rival Kubrick at his best.  If you watch this movie for the art and take the story as it comes, you definitely have a chance of liking this movie.

Very cerebral.  Begs the question of where reality lies within the conscience. Moody, atmospheric cinematography and decent acting and direction, albeit, slow-paced. If you're into a 2001-like movie that doesn't tie up all the loose ends, give it a try. I liked it, and recommend it.

Review title: Had to register to leave this negative review to serve justice!
Review_body: First of all, if the dear viewer has not seen the Tarkovsky 1978 film - watch it first for the sake of cinematography at the very least and hopefully to see that the movie is not about technical details as described in the "FAQ" section for 2002 version. 2. The presence of the song by ICP (Insane Clown Posse) early on in the film gave me a huge relief. It helped to not take the rest of it with such pain, since the movie does no justice to the novel or the Tarkovsky's version. Someone was either genius to give the hint that film is garbage just as rotten as ICP or it was made by people who aim for a cheap hit that would make a big buck "on the shoulders of giants". This film will never become a classic

***Spoiler Alert***** I too got pulled into this film and ended up watching it a few times (once with commentary).  I found it more interesting the more I thought about it.  My view on it is probably a bit different and more symbolic than most and not necessarily what was intended.  I see the whole story as Chris Kelvin's grieving process over his wife's death. That everything that goes on in the film can be seen as his going further into his own mind/memory/perceptions to heal from it; to try to come to peace with the memory of her.  The planet Solaris even resembled images of electrical activity in the brain - neurons firing.  The further he goes on his journey, the more dynamic, intense and closer Solaris gets.  The various characters could even be viewed as aspects of himself. Gordon - the ego/defensive/protective side that wants to avoid pain, change; the part that wants to be rid of Rheya's memory altogether; the survival instincts that want to get back to regular life (earth). Snow - the intellect - pure thought, but we see only a "replica" of what his intellect was since Rheya's death - the replica is disjointed, fragmented, way "out there," seeming like it should make sense but too vague to be clear.  Gibarian - the charming, outgoing, social - possible husband/father - side who becomes lost after Rheya's death - thus Chris being deadened/robotic in his dealings with the world since.  Trying to find & help the "Gibarian" aspect of himself is what sets him on the whole journey.  He ends up having to review his whole history with Rheya - all his "film clip" memories of their past.  He has to relive it all and let himself feel (the pain & pleasure) in order to move through it.  Only by fully surrendering and connecting to his child-like self (symbolized by Gibarian's son), no expectations /open to what is to come/innocence is he finally able to come to a place of forgiveness. Forgiveness of both himself & Rheya so he can be at peace with her memory and connect back to himself.

*****MILD SPOILERS AHEAD (not about the end though)****After having been through most comments posted here, I'm not really surprised to realize that, while some people loved the movie, some found it boring, to put it mildly.First, let me put it bluntly: I loved this movie. But depending on the mood the day I first saw it, I feel like I could have found a better way to spend my time. The line between the two feelings being a thin one.There are undeniable qualities to this movie: first, the music. I hadn't heard an original music that fit so well the movie since Requiem For a Dream. But unlike that of RfaD, where the music would become overwhelming, that of Solaris makes itself non-remarkable, being but another hint at the characters' state of mind, therefore brilliantly serving what should ultimately be a soundtrack's purpose (understand: compared to all those movies which just use the latest hits as loud as possible in order to sound cool, no matter if the songs actually fit what's going on). Secondly, and I know that some here don't share that view, but the visuals and the photography were stunning, and I loved the contrast between the colors used in the scenes on Earth and those aboard the station, which give most scenes this dreamy aura, again completely fitting the story. Also a word about the actors: they are very few speaking parts, but all of them have been cast well, with Clooney showing us yet another face of his talent and Natasha McEhlone simply excellent in the difficult part of Rheya, Clooney's Kelvin's deceased wife, who is the emotional core of the movie.Now about the storytelling in itself: of course, this covers only part of the book, or the original movie for that matter. But this is one of those stories where, unlike Lord of the Rings for instance, there is no real point of retelling the same story word by word. THAT would have been a waste of everybody's time. Instead, Soderbergh chooses to focus on some of the themes, namely the loss, the need for redemption, and the choices we make.But don't expect long and loud theories about all this. Don't expect moral judgments about the characters' actions. Instead, you are shown facts, the slow pace of the film allowing you space and time to put in your own thoughts and feelings.And this maybe for some the problem, and why lots of people have considered this film boring: they are times when no words are said, and little is done. Even at times, the music is completely gone, a kind of pace we're not used to in today's Occidental movie making (compared to Asian's cinema and animation)and that something that we tend to be almost afraid of somehow, like when at dinner when everyone run out of good words and pleasantries and all is left is silence. We always feel uncomfortable, because all we're left with is ourselves. Some days, we can face it. Some days, we cannot.This is exactly what happens with this movie, which, at core, is a mirror to some of our own basic human feelings, and not necessarily those we're always ready to deal with. Therefore, instead of getting dragged, we're are actually asked to participate to this emotional (and NOT intellectual) journey.But are you ready for it?*******************************Luckily for me, I was, and this is why I gave it 9/10, as I've been treated with one of the most powerful emotional journey cinema over the last few years.

Review title: Could have been better, but decent film!
Review_body: These demons are becoming more real once he reaches Solaris on his investigation mission. One of the most memorable scenes for me was the first appearance of Rheya. Kelvin darting out of his bed, hitting his head, trying to wake up and finally understanding that this is real and not a dream. Sent shivers down my spine. And while Chris loses his grip on reality, Rheya becomes more real and more aware of herself and of the fact that her existence is something "unreal". At first Rheya is only talking in formulas, but as the film progresses, she develops a new personality and we see Rheya (Solaris) becoming more like Rheya (Earth) again. And there are the two other members of the crew, Dr. Gordon (v. Davis) and Snow (J. Davies). Snow is...- weird, and Davies' creepy characterisation was spot on, IMO. You'll understand *why* Snow acts this way later in the film. The only person choosing reality instead of dreams, and incidentally the only one to survive is Dr. Gordon. She also is the one that ultimately figures out a way to get rid of the apparitions and doesn't hesitate to do so.There is another member of the cast that merits mention and that is the score. In most films, the score is either utterly forgettable or tells you the story in broad strokes and with thumping drums. In this one, it felt like a fifth character, setting the mood for a scene, and freshening up the atmosphere with a little splash of notes here and there. It also kept you in a kind of... trance-like mood in parts, thereby adding another layer to the "reality or dream?" question that permeates the film.Soderbergh took Lem's classic science fiction story and made something entirely different from it, but still a classic sci-fi story, exploring love, reality, minds and sanity.

Review title: This film is half the length of the first Solaris film but it is infinitely more boring.
Review_body: Visually this new adaptation of Solaris is simply dull, as is the plot, the cast and the dialogue. Tarkovsky managed in his version to create stunning imagery which I found extremely thought provoking but this film is just so plain that when I had finished watching I had to wonder why I ever wasted an hour of my life doing so (I say an hour as I had to resort to fast forwarding through most of the painfully irritating flashbacks). Of course I am biased; the reason why I watched this film was to see how it compared to the Tarkovsky film and to be honest I never thought Soderburg and Clooney were up to the job, the best I was hoping for was a film which didn't try to be too clever and instead came up with a few neat innovations for science fiction. Instead the film turned out to be simply the most tedious dialogue I have ever experienced set against endlessly plain futuristic style backdrops broken only by a tacky sex scene featuring an unwelcome view of Clooney's buttocks. Nothing in this film is profound, nothing in this film is entertaining and I can't think of a single reason to recommend anyone this film unless you happen to fancy the leading actors rear end.

Review title: Sometimes, you should listen to the people leaving the previous show!
Review_body: While waiting in line with my wife and four children, plus one girlfriend, we overheard quite a few comments from the people leaving the earlier showing. Nearly all were negative. One guy even looked over and shouted "run for your money back!" I was never one to listen to others comments, having liked a number of films that others hated. We entered, found seats (the theater would fill to near capacity) and settled in.The movie began, slowly, and slowed down from there. Myt wife and I kept saying, "It's got to get better." It never did. It was too long, to slow, and lacked interest. When it was over, we sighed and wondered aloud why we didn't get up earlier and sneak into a different theater. (it would not have been stealing, after what we paid to see that stinker) The acting was okay, the scenery was appropriate, the music good. It just dragged like a slug on a leaf. I have never been so anticipating an end of a movie before.My wife maintains that I'll watch any movie, regardless of content. She was right, till now. I will never view this movie again.Sorry to say, but this film has replaced all others on my "Worst Film Ever" list. I don't fault the actors, it wasn't their fault the story lacked any interest whatsoever.

Review title: A dreadful movie, totally unlike the book
Review_body: This movie sucks!I just read the book and thought it would be nice to see the movie. How wrong I was! Out of all the ingredients in the book (some would really make good scenes in a movie) almost none are included in this slow unentertaining movie. It totally sucks! It's nothing more than a rather strange and uninteresting love-story, instead of a mind-dazzling sci-fi movie. It is not intriguing at all and you will only be left witch a sense of profound bore after seeing it. It does not engage you, you don't care about the characters, and nothing really happens at all worth mentioning or worth your time (or mine).Don't bother watching it, it's a complete waste of time!/Linus

I saw this movie in its original release in theaters and I don't think that I will be able to stop thinking about it ever. This was one of the most beautifully shot movies I've seen in a long while. The story was a powerful emotional journey which asked many questions about love and life.First the look of this movie, there were so many interesting cinematographic techniques used that I was never bored looking at this movie. The scene when Clooney was at a group session but all the other people were blurry blew me away. Every scene sparked a question, a thought or an idea - what a nice change: a movie that makes you think and not just react. The story of meeting your dead loved one in a space ship above a mysterious planet prompted so many thoughts of what that would be like. Would it be desirable? Would it be everything I hoped? The feelings portrayed in this movie over feelings about a lost loved one felt so true that I thought I was watching my own story on the screen. How would I feel if my lost ones suddenly came back to me? The line that Clooney's wife says that she is only from his memory was so true and yet he doesn't care. Could I turn my back on that person even though it wasn't really her? Mind-blowing!The main criticism of the film was its pacing, some say it is slow but I prefer to say deliberate which leaves time to consider all that's happening. There isn't a lot of physical action in this movie but it's not about that. We have so many movies where all of our senses are under constant assault in order to take advantage of the new technology and not leave us bored that it is a relief to see a movie that is quiet and carefully paced so that we can ponder the questions asked. So many new movies are so frenetic that they seem afraid to show us a movie about people and ideas. Not Solaris. If you want to see a movie that's asks interesting questions while showcasing it in a fabulous looking film, check this one out. And if you like this one I highly recommend Code 46 which is just as good and underrated.

It is a film you should lose all expectations of formulas so common in most movies. It gives the feeling of watching a play where there is a stage but also intimacy that is difficult to find on film. Don't expect the film-makers to hold your hand and guide you through the plot they have, thankfully, given you more credit. You meet the characters in a time and place in which life is in progress, in other words, events have taken place and they are moving into another stage of activity. After the movie you will have questions in your mind of not just the movie but of reality and perceptions within your own life. You will think about it for days and will ponder such things as God, gods, universe, reality, hope, and what is truth?

Review title: If you hate this movie, you're the problem of today.
Review_body: To the people who love blow-em-up movies and rated R, "Oh! I've seen this movie and it's all gory and you haven't so there!" kind of people are the problem of today. I can't tell if they're incredibly stupid or are trying to impress people. These people are also the kind of people who hate Solaris.The people who say it's "too boring" are the people with too low of patience and are probably amazed that it doesn't have anyone's limbs flying off. Those who say they don't get it are either not very smart, not very patient, or don't give the movie a chance and say "Oh, well blow this..." in the first five minutes. The movie was beautifully composed with the scenes flowing into each other wonderfully and the music giving the perfect touch to the deepness of the movie. (some spoilers...)And in case if you really didn't get it, it's about a guy who's wife had committed suicide in an argument about her unborn son, and his live is a total waste. Every day is depressing to him. So, he gets requested to go on a trip to a space station observing a strangely acting planet. He finds distraught people there, and none of them really give a straight out answer to what's going on. So that night, he dreams about his wife again, and in the morning, she's right next to him. Not remembering how she got there, the guy locks her into a space capsule and sends her off knowing that it couldn't be his wife. He later speaks to the crewmates and they find that the planet seems to be sending them people from their lives that they probably feel guilt over from their memories. The next morning she's there again, and when she finds out that he sent her off in the capsule from a crewmate, she commits suicide like he remembers her; suicidal. So, they find out that Snow had a visitor (himself) and when Snow tried to kill him, he kills Snow.(If you look in the beginning, the blood stain's there from the start. I think Snow had already died before he got there.) He tells them that Solaris is dragging them in and that they should leave. So the other crewmate and him runs to the pod. She rushes in and starts activating it. He's faced with the decision of whether he should go back to his life and live in guilt and depression. (definatly spoilers)If you think about it, Solaris was really giving them all a second chance. It told the other crewmate(forgot her name) that she should go through Snow because she wasn't ready for Solaris. The guy who stayed behind, the main character, had died but seemed that when he woke up he was back on Earth with his wife again. Who really knows about Snow. He was kind of weird from the start.

Review title: Honestly, no idea how it got such a high score
Review_body: I'd watch any genre of films, as long as it's a quality film. Solaris isn't that, wonder how could anyone score it higher than 5, boring, mundane and the whole movie could fit in 10 minutes rather than hour and a half.

As I said - this movie sucks!I don't know why this movie title is Solaris. If somebody have ever read the Lem's book, then he knows that the book is about PLANET (not some pinky animations) and about humankind. This is not some foolish love story (although there is a love theme, but it is for better understanding the human nature). I wonder why people voted so high on this picture. Without reading the book it is not understandable! The plot is a knot of randomly picked issues from the book and doesn't make any sense at all.This movie really let me down. This movie is simply bad. My vote: 2 (so high for I love the book).

My husband, our two teens and I viewed this film when it appeared on a cable channel one Friday evening. According to the review in the television guide, it was a three star movie. And given that it sported George Clooney, we expected good things. All the better that it was science fiction, too.The sets are very convincingly done, the sound and lighting are interesting, and the acting excellent. Few complaints about the cinematography except for one scene with fast panning that could have been skipped - that effect was annoying. The movie has one fatal flaw, and that is simply a bad storyline that is slow to the point of being arduous and so lacking in substance as to border on being stupid. The best sets, lighting, music, and acting cannot cure a film with essentially no plot.Don't rent this one.

This is a film that deals with a variety of philosophical issues in enough depth to provoke thought and discussion, without doing all the work for the viewer. The relationship between the two leads in convincing and very well acted. As for the philosophical issues, it looks at the nature of personal identity, the boundaries of what can be known and what can't, the existence and nature of God and whether those topics can even be addressed by humans, and of course, what happens after death. What makes the film interesting is that it sounds out the questions without in any way seeking to supply the answers, except to suggest that those answers cannot be trite. It cleverly references 2001 A Space Odyssey. I think it needs two or three views to get the full benefit, but it does re-pay repeated watching.

Not only was this the worst Sci-Fi movie that I've ever seen, it was also one of the worst movies of ANY genre that I've ever seen. When it comes to movies, I'm really not that critical and I think I'm fairly open-minded. I sincerely cannot understand how anyone could find a single redeeming quality about this movie -with the possible exception of someone that could benefit from video sales. It was awful. Nothing exciting or even remotely interesting happens in this film. Basically, a guy goes to space to figure out a "mystery". Unfortunately, he doesn't figure it out and then the movie is over. Now, maybe the film-makers simply ran out of tape before they could film the actual ending of this movie, in which case I'd really be interested in seeing it. All in all, this movie would not be worth watching unless someone was paying you to watch it. Don't buy it, don't rent it, don't watch it on cable or VHS or any other form of media. You will never be able to get the time back that you wasted watching this movie. The thought has crossed my mind that perhaps this movie was a tool used by psychologists conducting some kind of test. Maybe they were measuring how much money an obvious flop could generate on one actors fame, i.e. George Clooney. Or perhaps the for-mentioned psychologists were attempting to test the "emperor's new clothes" parable in modern times. For those of you not familiar with this story, let me make the analogy of a notable wine connoisseur saying that a glass of urine was actually an exquisite white wine. Then, said connoisseur waits for other wine connoisseurs to either be honest by saying the wine tastes like urine or to agree out of fear of not having a discriminating enough palette to detect how wonderful the wine really is. Speaking of urine, if I could urinate on the director of this movie, I would.

Review title: Lets not call it sci-fi shall we?
Review_body: When did Steven Soderbergh start imitating David Lynch? George Clooney's character goes to a far away space station in response to a distress call from his friend. Apparently the planetoid that the space station is orbiting has the power to create a faux human being that exists in the minds of the astronauts. For the protagonist Chris Klein its his wife.Although, the camera work is competent, there is nothing all that awe-inspiring about the concept or the performances for that matter. The story (if the movie has one) is so predictable that you would literally doze off.Solaris falls into that class of movies which are so vague that only Film School 'pseudo' know-it-alls would like to sit and analyze every inane frame just to show off how much more perspicacious their understanding of the fine art of film-making is. Thankfully most movie goers do not have to go to film school to realize what cinema is about. They just use their brains.

I am the author of (thus far) five books on cinema, and Solaris is, by far, my favorite film of all time. I think it's a beautiful, quiet meditation on love and loss. I can see why people are bored by it. It's an intellectual film for intellectual people. If you get it, you get it. If you don't, you don't. It doesn't make you dumb. It just means you have no taste. :)This is not a film for the Fast and the Furious crowd. I have always considered it a sister film of Malick's The Thin Red Line, which was also misunderstood for the same reasons. I recently read that Soderbergh is planning to direct a Malick screenplay... Does it get any better than that? I think not.

Review title: not very good, and not very clear
Review_body: This film is alright, but for the first 45 minuets, i had no idea what was going on. it didn't explain things that should be obvious. the plot wasn't very good either, for i didn't see one. A depressed psychologist, goes to a ship (dont know what is for) because a friend asked for him there because things were happening. He didn't say what though. the ending wasn't very clear what happened either. was he dead? was she just one of the 'visitors'. it wasn't very clear. George Cloony was also not very good in this film. His acting was just not up to scratch. It did not have enough character development in ti, too. at the end of the film, i felt i did not know the characters, and i felt highly unsettled. It could have been better.

Review title: A Strange Combination of "Star Trek: Generations" and "Alien"
Review_body: A strange combination of "Star Trek: Generations"' idea of the Nexus (a paradisaical astronomical phenomenon which may have distinctly malevolent byproducts) and "Alien"'s small-crew-trapped-in-an-eerie ship, "Solaris" pushes some mental buttons but not hard enough to lose the audience--perhaps not even hard enough to engage the audience. It has some tension but is comparatively laid-back (especially when compared to films like "Alien").I was surprised to see Clooney's character, Chris Kelvin, exhibit some true traits of a psychologist. While not exhibited with much depth, the blindness of the character to his own manipulability was intriguing.The vocal tics and absent-mindedness of Davies' character, Snow, added a little depth to the character, although after a few minutes the audience hits bottom with Snow. This feeling of "shouldn't there be more to him?" is resolved in the last minutes of the film.Overall, not a particularly vibrant or active film, but it has its interesting points.

Review title: allow it to take you into its vibe
Review_body: i think this movie wasn't brilliant, but i liked its vibe, thats the most important thing. i think if you are a little drunk , you will enjoy this movie even more.the dreamy and surreal quality of this movie captivates you, if you let it. one needs to let go, and then he will enjoy it even more.initially , i thought that Natascha M would suddenly turn into this horrible disfigured monster, right when there was a touching , beautiful scene going on, {which is typical of horror flicks ] , but the pleasant surprise was that she didn't! she didn't turn into a monster or anything! and i was so relieved, i figured that out after 30 minutes, and then i relaxed, i could let my guard down.the main reason for watching this movie for me , was Natascha. she is so beautiful, i could just look at her face, her body for hours on end. and its not just the attractive face, its her complete body language..........she is such a beautiful woman, a real woman, and her personality will just make any man melt, and fall in love with her.and the end , is so awesome, it was a perfect ending. i loved it!!

Solaris is Steven Soderbergh's adaptation of Stanislaw Lem's novel "Solaris" and remake of Andrei Tarkovsky's Cannes prized "Solyaris". Considering these fact there are too ways of approaching this film: reading Lem's novel/viewing Tarkovsky's movie or none of both. I myself, doing the former two, was very disappointed by this movie. Although this movie is significantly better than most movies that come out of Hollywood it is utterly sloppy compared to Tarkovsky's adaptation. Shure, this movie get's you thinking more than most popcorn flicks, and yes, this is not your average action-adventure-E.T. killing S.F. but the movie fails to focus on the questions it raises.One of Lem's main theme's in his book is man's inherited incapacity of communicating with profoundly alien entities. And profound alien entity is just what Solaris is. That is right - Solaris is not just the planet where most of the film is set but Solaris, or better yet, Solaris' ocean is an entity, a being, possibly a rational being. It is capable of reading human thoughts and capable of forging "real life illusions" of friends or family members that haunt the minds of the astronauts living on the space station on Solaris. The fact that "Solaris" sends these messengers out, and the fact that the final solution of the characters is to destroy them signifies just this impossibility to establish a connection with the planetary mind. Now you might not get all this just by watching Soderbergh's movie simply because it fails to illustrate these problems either by means of plot, dialogue or plain visual effects. In fact the movie is very poor at explaining what Solaris, the purpose for it is researched and completely cuts out an important part of the original plot that explains the mysterious encounters of a pilot in Solaris' atmosphere.This remake is one hour shorter than Tarkovsky's version and unfortunately it shows. Some people compared this title with 2001: A Space Odysee because of it's long cuts and it's slow and little action. In fact comparing it with Solyaris one can only have the impression that the director made a bet that he could get all the story in an under 100 minutes film.Unfortunately the result lacks consistency. It is hard for the viewer to follow the themes of the movie unless he is already familiar with them from the book or from "that old Russian movie".The director hoped this will turn out to be a smart movie like his previous "Traffic" but he ended up with this pseudo art movie. It is too low key and psychological for "Star Wars" fans and too Hollywood for "2001" fans.Rated 4 out of 10 for mediocre, better luck next time,never remake something that's already perfect the way it is

quite simply the most boring film in the history of films. i would rather eat my own eyes than watch this film again. in fact i already scratched half my arm off in frustration while the movie was on. if you are a geek and enjoy watching paint dry, this film is perfect for you. if you prefer to watch a film and not have to worry about falling asleep, stay far away and never even think of this film. the most exciting thing to happen in this film is someone shouting at another person. it starts off OK, with the film building some suspense. however this goes nowhere, and you end up shouting at the screen for something to happen. the acting is lousy and no way George Clooney's best. the story line is just too plain as well. you have to watch George Clooney (who i think is is every single scene in the film, so you start getting fed up with him) as he starts having hallucinations with the rest of the crew of the ship he explores.how long can you sit and watch someone else seeing something that isn't there. this is only my opinion and you may actually enjoy it as others have, but this is probably unlikely since you can have just as much fun poking a cardboard box with a stick for 2 hours. you have been warned.

There are a number of interpretations that can patch together a resolution for this picture if one is not particularly troubled by plot holes and logical conundrums. For instance, a giddy fantasist could conclude that the main character has reached out to an alien life form and has fallen in love with it: a real wham-bang love story. A determined sci-fi fan might see Blade-Runner-style tragedy. A prodigiously sane person completely unexperienced in mental illness might suppose that main character succumbs to madness. A quick cynic might conclude that passive-aggressive aliens adroitly manipulate the main character's unresolved feelings of love and guilt re: his suicide wife to achieve their nefarious ends. A Socratic person might conclude that if such is the case, the main characters's embrace (a la Cypher in The Matrix) of an illusory "wife" in favor of reality is pitiable. A moralist might find the same choice reprehensible; an existentialist, absurd; an aestheticist, disgusting.I don't subscribe to the any of the more generous interpretations. In fact, I am deprived of any interpretation at all, because the story failed to sustain my interest. I freely admit to fast-forwarding through many of the dull silences and duller (though fast-cut) dialog. The picture did not create enough of an illusion for me to suspend my disbelief sufficiently to care about what was actually happening. Here is why the execution, in my view, failed: 1. In what is actually a short picture, the pace is glacial and the film at times downright boring, especially after it is clear that these "aliens," if aliens they are, intend to employ only mild-mannered psychology and low-key guilt trips to obtain their ends (as opposed to ray-guns, spatulas, creepy mind-f#@ks, or anything else that might possibly inspire fear). If any kind of tension is to be sustained, the "visitors" phenomena ought to be able to inspire dread of some kind in the viewer. This side of the balance fails however because there is no fight in the main character, who falls for the aliens' machinations almost immediately, with the unsurprising result that the human stakes are too low. We might feel pity for this weak-willed guilt-sodden sap, but hardly fear. Conversely, if one tries to interpret the "visitors" phenomena in a positive light, tension also fails, for the same reason: it is obvious that the love-smitten main character will do nothing to harm these visitors. Likewise, that the only other human crew member (if she IS human -- you decide), partly because she is so underdeveloped, likewise poses no real danger to any friendlies. Furthermore, one never gets the impression that the phenomena, however interpreted, represent any ill to the main character that amounts to even one-third of a hill of beans. The main character just isn't man enough.2. Some reviewers clearly were impressed with the emotional reality of the main character-"wife"/visitor relationship. I didn't find much emotional depth, despite all of the in-your-face edits. If we are to be able to imagine we are viewing a picture in which a main character is faced with aliens, human-shaped vorpal bunnies, self-created revenants, mental illness, what have you, the picture ought to be more frightening. Instead, we are left with a main character who weakly succumbs to phenomena that somehow manage to be more soporific than anything else, probably because they spend most of the picture rehashing the main character's relationship with his dead wife. With a weak MC and little sense of threat (i.e., something at stake), my response can only be, WHO CARES?

Review title: one of the slowest , worst movies I've ever seen
Review_body: i didn't even finish watching it ... and i cant say that about many movies ..me and my GF, both fell asleep about 3/4 of the way through ..maybe I'm a bit bias, cuz i don't want any "love story" in my sci-fi , and i require some sort of thought provoking dialog every 20 minuets or so ... this is why i didn't like the movie .. in fact i cant think of a single reason i would like the movie .. the directing was pretty terrible, the casting was mediocre and the story didn't seem to exist in any thought provoking sense at all.. whether or not i am bias, due to my obsession with sci-fi .. imho this movie was complete trash and a waste of time for everyone involvedmaybe if you enjoy being tormented with a inkling of suspense for over an hour straight and then falling asleep this movie is for you .. if you really love recent Hollywood sci/fi movies that try to be overly dramatic and artistic, you would probably enjoy this .. but i don't know why anyone would enjoy that hehe

I love this movie, hands down. The music is perfect; among my favorites. True, it's a bit slow in the beginning, but then the movie just send you reeling. The story is captivating. On the surface, it's just a love story, but after watching, you'll realize it's so much more than that. Steven Soderburgh is an absolute genius. If you ever get the chance, watch the original Russian film, as well as reading the book. This movie is just a small part of a great story. In regards to the movie, there are some differences from the book, but I still count it as my favorite. Clooney does surprisingly well in his role, and Viola Davis (Gordon) takes to her role well, even though Gordon was a male in the original. however, Natascha McElhone's (Rhea) performance is particularly breathtaking. She captures the character in ways that can only be seen by watching the movie. I just...just watch the movie. Now.

"How can you be so sure if you don't know whether it is real or not?" If you cannot prove it but you choose not to believe, why cannot I choose to believe? Like Carl Popper said, scientists have been trying hard to distinguish themselves from metaphysicians, however, science in itself involves a huge amount of metaphysics. Because it is based on a lot of very fundamental assumptions that you can never prove.This world, I would like to say, is contaminated by materialism. There was once a time we people could tolerate and probably accept the existence of all different kinds of believes and we all tried so hard to understand this world. But now, like what scientists would not like to admit, we adore science too much as the flies' passion on rotten foods. We suddenly stopped thinking. We are satisfied with what we have and we are crazy playing with it. We are not only enjoying it, we want more. Still not knowing what we are and why we are here, we keep a thirst for the things that don't even know if we are supposed to possess.All creatures, with or without a brain, do stupid things when they are satisfied. Once upon time we were so happy declaring that we were unique. However, after years, we turned no more than the dirty monkeys in Gulliver's trip. So we came to Solaris, with great ambition and unexplainable confidence. We came here for the entire human race on the Earth, although we still don't have a single clue of what we are on that planet for.A lot of humanists sensed this huge question mark. Kubrick's 2001 also demonstrated a possibility of getting closer to the keys of big questions by not depending on science too much. If there are most arrogant scientists, the craziest words they could possibly say might be, OK gentlemen, we are familiar enough with our planet. Only the most stupid of the most arrogant believe that we can explain things even out of this planet, such as in Solaris, using what we learnt on Earth.I know that my interpretation involves some subjective thoughts and feelings. However, I can be sure that Soderbergh doesn't deny the possibility of multiple explanations of the world or the universe and he believes that we have the right to choose among them."Hello, Neo. Look, here is a Matrix inside which people live regularly with rules created by God and guaranteed by computers. Also, you have the power of destroying it. What do you think? To be, or not to be?" Solaris is such an elegant movie with profound retrospection, beautiful photography and reasonably good acting. It is set on a stage that seems so strange but so familiar. It could be Solaris. It could also be inside our mind. Soderbergh reminded us again, that if there is anything that makes us human race so special, it is the spirit we possess. It is that we do something that the creatures who only have a brain cannot understand.

I know there are rabid fans of this film, but I personally found it slow-moving and dull, driven by an attempt to make it very artsy. Believe me, I appreciate artsy movies that are not typical Hollywood, but this one just didn't do it for me. I assume the original 1973 Russian film is better than this as (from what I've read) also seems to put the people in a slightly different context.To me the pacing and cinematography was like a poor blend of 2001 and Blade Runner. The idea is interesting, but I would have been more satisfied with this film if it had been 45 minutes long rather than 90. Even though I'm a sci-fi fan, I am not surprised that I had not heard of this movie earlier, although it has such a well-known actor as George Clooney.

Review title: I actually signed up to IMDb to write a review on this movie
Review_body: Yes, I actually signed up to IMDb to write a review on this movie.Having seen the original 70s film and reading the book, this version seemed utterly boring and badly developed.The 70s version will really boggle your mind, if you'll have the patience to watch it from start to finish. I would not recommend seeing this movie if you've read the book or seen the original movie.

firstly, if you've read the book: forget it.if you haven't read the book: relax and soak up the beauty of Soderberg's directing.its a very bad idea to compare the film to the book of Solaris. In my opinion, the book is a great read, if somewhat derivative and at points tedious. The film is one of my all time favourites. Soderberg does not try to do a remake, or a film of the book, he does what anyone who has any sense does. he takes the idea that works in the book. and changes it to work as an excellent film. the combination of the screenplay, directing, acting and cliff Martinez' awesome, atmospheric soundtrack all come together and make Solaris nothing short of a masterpiece.The film is really like an art exhibition in a way, some people may not enjoy, but if you're going to watch it, do so with an open mind and just enjoy the truly superb piece of film making.

This film will not appeal to those who think Star Wars and Star Trek is what sci-fi is about. The film caters more for the intellectual sci-fi buff. A psychological thriller come love story dealing with ones inner most guilt and desires. Thought provoking well presented film. Clooney is cast in a role far removed from the genre he usually stars in. Not having read the book or seen the original I had no preconceived expectation and found the film watchable although it could be slow at times. The special effects are believable especially the majestic opening scene as Clooney's ship approaches the space station orbiting Solaris. The score does the job of setting the mood. Overall not a bad film.
